Criticism of Israel's actions comes from both international allies, like the United States, and regional players, with warnings of disastrous consequences for an Israeli ground offensive in Rafah.
Lastly, the article mentions the ongoing Lok Sabha elections in India, unrelated to the main topic, and provides a brief update on the voting process.

item.title: Met Gala 2024: What is the event and why is it such a big deal?
item.description:
The Met Gala, also known as "fashion's biggest night," is an annual fundraising event for the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute. Held on the first Monday in May, it's the only wing of the museum that self-funds, doing so through this exclusive party. The event is invitation-only, with celebrities dressing according to a yearly theme that also aligns with the Costume Institute's exhibition. This year's theme was 'Sleeping Beauties: Reawakening Fashion,' focusing on historical fashion pieces too delicate for regular display.
The Costume Institute boasts a collection of over 33,000 fashion items, dating back seven centuries. The Met Gala itself began in 1948 and has evolved into a high-profile, globally recognized event, largely attributed to Vogue editor-in-chief Anna Wintour, who has been organizing it since 1999. Tickets are highly priced, with this year's tickets at $75,000 and tables starting at $350,000, often purchased by major brands.
The event is shrouded in mystery, with guests not allowed to carry phones, but it's known they view the Costume Institute's exhibits before dinner and enjoy performances by high-profile entertainers. This year's hosts included Bad Bunny, Jennifer Lopez, Zendaya, and Chris Hemsworth, with Indian actress Alia Bhatt among the attendees. The gala is sponsored by various brands, including TikTok, Loewe, and Condé Nast.

item.title: Expert Explains: A brief history of religion-based reservations in India; the question of Muslims’ inclusion
item.description:
The article discusses the complex issue of religion-based reservation in India, a secular country. It explores whether such reservations undermine the principle of secularism and if Muslims have been given reservations by reducing quotas for other groups. The Indian Constitution has evolved from promoting formal equality to substantive equality, allowing for affirmative action and special measures for backward classes. The Supreme Court has interpreted equality as a dynamic concept that may necessitate differential treatment for historically disadvantaged groups.
**Key points include:** - The Constitution allows for reservation for backward classes not adequately represented in state services. - Article 15 prohibits discrimination on the grounds of religion, among others, but allows for special provisions for the advancement of backward classes. - Some Muslim castes have received reservation not because of their religion but because they were classified as backward classes. - Historical context shows that Muslim castes have been included in the OBC list and given reservations without affecting the quotas for SCs, STs, and OBCs. - Legal precedents affirm that reservations for Muslims do not conflict with secularism and that they can be considered for reservation if found socially backward. - Various commissions and government actions have sought to provide reservations for Muslims, often leading to legal challenges and court decisions that have shaped the current reservation policies.
The article concludes with the ongoing debate and legal scrutiny over the reservation policies for Muslims in India, highlighting the tension between the need for social justice and the principles of secularism. Prof Faizan Mustafa, Vice-Chancellor of Chanakya National Law University, provides expert commentary on the subject. The article also briefly mentions unrelated content, including updates on the IPL 2024 points table and other news snippets, which are not directly related to the main topic.

item.title: What is the banned organisation Sikhs for Justice?
item.description: The article discusses a recommendation by Delhi Lieutenant-Governor V K Saxena for an NIA probe against Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal. The probe is suggested due to allegations of Kejriwal's party receiving $16 million from Sikhs for Justice (SFJ), a banned pro-Khalistan group in the US. SFJ, led by Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, aims for Sikh self-determination and the creation of Khalistan. Despite advocating non-violence, SFJ has been criticized for glorifying past acts of terrorism and its leaders have made veiled threats against non-Sikhs. India has labeled Pannun a terrorist and banned SFJ under its Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act. Multiple cases are registered against Pannun and SFJ in India. The article also briefly mentions unrelated content about the current standings in the IPL 2024 points table.

item.title: Why is the launch of Boeing’s Starliner significant?
item.description: Boeing's Starliner spacecraft is set for its first crewed test flight to the International Space Station (ISS) on May 7, launched from Kennedy Space Center. This mission is significant for Boeing as it could make them the second private firm, after SpaceX, to transport NASA crew to and from the ISS. The Starliner, a partially reusable crew capsule, will carry astronauts Barry "Butch" Wilmore and Sunita Williams, who will test manual flight control and onboard systems. The mission aims to dock with the ISS for about 10 days and will be closely monitored, especially during the return journey for its heat shield and parachute performance. Success in this mission is crucial for Boeing, which has faced delays and technical issues, and for NASA, which seeks to diversify its commercial spaceflight partners. A successful mission would also challenge SpaceX's current dominance in the commercial space sector.

item.title: Why are cancer cases soaring in India?
item.description:
The article discusses the rising cancer cases in India, highlighting individual stories and broader health trends. Praful Reddy, an IT professional with lung cancer, and 12-year-old Dipti with Wilms tumor, represent the growing number of cancer diagnoses, particularly among children. An Apollo Hospitals report calls India the "cancer capital of the world," with a sharp increase in non-communicable diseases. It notes that one in three Indians is pre-diabetic, two in three are pre-hypertensive, and one in ten suffers from depression. The report projects cancer cases to rise from 1.4 million in 2020 to 1.57 million by 2025.
The most common cancers in India are breast, cervix, and ovarian for women, and lung, mouth, and prostate for men. Contributing factors include aging, unhealthy diets, pollution, and climate change. The median age for lung cancer in India is 59, younger than in Western countries. There's a shortage of pediatric oncology facilities, especially in public hospitals, and financial and social barriers hinder treatment access.
Low health screening rates present a challenge, with less than 1% of Indians screened for common cancers, despite WHO recommendations. Experts call for prioritized action, including government incentives for screening and policies for financial protection and expanded services. Without intervention, cancer cases could double by 2040, with many preventable through individual, societal, and governmental efforts. The article concludes with a separate mention of a legal notice sent to a tea startup by Sony Pictures Networks India, unrelated to the main topic.

item.title: How Indians became Germany’s largest community of international students
item.description:
Indian students have become the largest international student group in Germany, surpassing Chinese students. The number of Indian students in German universities has doubled over the past five years to 43,000 and is projected to reach 45,000-50,000 by the end of 2024. The low cost of education, as higher education in Germany is mostly publicly funded, and the introduction of English-taught courses have contributed to this growth. Over 2,000 degree courses are now offered in English, particularly at the master's level.
Germany has become the third most popular destination for international students globally and the top non-English speaking country. In 2023, Germany issued 16,850 visas to Indian students. Engineering remains the most popular field of study for Indian students in Germany, followed by law, management, social sciences, and mathematics.
The article also notes that Indian students are the largest international student community in the US and are expected to reach one million by 2030. However, Canada has seen an 86% decline in study permits issued to Indian students due to diplomatic issues and a cap on international student permits.
Germany's new Skilled Immigration Act offers a smoother pathway for international students into the German labor market, allowing them to work up to 20 hours per week. This change is expected to further attract Indian students to Germany.

item.title: Why are Lakshadweep coral reefs undergoing severe bleaching?
item.description:
The article discusses the severe coral bleaching in the Lakshadweep Sea, identified by the ICAR-Central Marine Fisheries Research Institute (CMFRI). The phenomenon, caused by prolonged marine heatwaves since October 2023, poses a threat to the region's diverse marine ecosystems. Coral bleaching occurs when corals expel the algae living in their tissues due to warm water, leading to a transparent appearance and exposing their white skeleton. Although not immediately fatal, bleached corals risk starvation and disease.
The Lakshadweep Sea has experienced significant coral bleaching events before, but the current scale is unprecedented. Scientists measure the accumulated heat stress using the Degree Heating Week (DHW) indicator, and Lakshadweep has crossed the critical threshold, indicating severe bleaching. The increase in marine heatwaves is attributed to global warming and strong El Niño events, with a notable rise in the Indian Ocean region.
These heatwaves not only threaten coral reefs but also affect seagrass meadows and kelp forests, impacting photosynthesis, growth, and reproduction. The health of coral reefs is crucial for Lakshadweep's structure, and their death could prevent future coral formation. The article also briefly mentions a legal notice sent to Dorje Teas by Sony Pictures Networks India, unrelated to the main topic.

item.title: GOLDENE: A sheet of gold that is only one atom thick
item.description:
Researchers at Linköping University in Sweden have created a **one-atom-thick sheet of gold**, named 'goldene', marking the first time a freestanding 2D metal has been formulated. This breakthrough follows the discovery of graphene in 2004 and adds to the growing list of 2D materials. The challenge with metals is their tendency to form nanoparticles, but the team overcame this by replacing a monolayer of silicon with gold atoms, then etching away the surrounding titanium carbide.
The resulting goldene sheets are about **100 nanometres thick**, significantly thinner than the thinnest gold leaf available commercially. The material's potential applications are vast, particularly in the electronics industry, where it could serve as an economical catalyst and reduce the amount of gold needed for electrical conductivity. The technique may also apply to other metals, with efforts underway to create 2D sheets of iridium and platinum.
Goldene's unique structure, where each gold atom has only six neighbors instead of twelve, suggests it may have special properties. Future applications could include environmental and energy solutions like carbon dioxide conversion, hydrogen production, and water purification.

item.title: Covid virus is still here. Why aren’t more people falling ill?
item.description:
The article reflects on India's experience with the Covid-19 pandemic, highlighting that the worst phase was in May 2021 with a peak in cases and deaths. It notes that India did not experience further deadly waves after the Omicron surge in early 2022, which led to many infections but fewer severe cases and deaths. The WHO declared Covid-19 no longer a global public health emergency in May 2023, and India lifted all related restrictions shortly after the Omicron wave.
The virus, particularly the JN.1 variant, continues to circulate and cause infections, but not severe disease. Global data shows a decline in cases and deaths, with India reporting minimal cases and deaths despite low testing rates. The article suggests that the lack of severe outbreaks is due to natural immunity from previous infections and vaccinations, although neither provides permanent immunity. Continuous monitoring of the virus is necessary for timely interventions.
The article also mentions unrelated content regarding security operations in Jammu and Kashmir, which is not connected to the Covid-19 discussion.

item.title: This Quote Means: ‘Freedom of the press is a precious privilege that no country can forego’, by Gandhi
item.description:
World Press Freedom Day, celebrated on May 3, honors the essential principles of journalism, as established by the Declaration of Windhoek in 1992. The day emphasizes the responsibilities of journalists, the importance of a diverse media landscape, and press freedom. Mahatma Gandhi, known for his political leadership, also contributed significantly to journalism, advocating for the power of the press to unite people and reflect societal aspirations. He launched the newspaper Indian Opinion to address the needs of the Indian diaspora and highlight their issues.
Gandhi's perspective on journalism was that it should act as a bridge between different social groups and provide a platform for diverse voices. He also stressed the importance of a free press, free from political and corporate influences, as a means for societal self-reflection and critique. Despite potential biases, Gandhi believed in the press's role in advocating for the marginalized and the need for its freedom to allow for constructive criticism.
The article underscores the significance of press freedom as a privilege that is crucial for a healthy society, allowing for the critique of institutions and ideologies. It suggests that without press freedom, societies risk stagnation and decline due to a lack of feedback mechanisms. The article concludes by highlighting Gandhi's legacy in journalism and the enduring relevance of a free press.

item.title: How Xi Jinping’s Europe visit aims to seize a strategic opportunity
item.description:
Chinese President Xi Jinping's first European visit in five years is marked by a strategic effort to challenge U.S. influence and promote China as a counterweight. Targeting France, Serbia, and Hungary for their openness to China and economic ties, Xi aims to showcase China's growing clout and seek pragmatic relations amidst tensions over China's support for Russia and espionage concerns.
The visit tests Europe's balance between the U.S. and China, with Xi's presence in Serbia during the NATO bombing anniversary symbolizing a critique of U.S. international law adherence. The EU's complex stance on China as a partner, competitor, and rival reflects internal conflicts over economic benefits versus security risks.
Xi's focus on France aligns with President Macron's vision for European strategic autonomy, avoiding subservience to the U.S. and fostering a multipolar world. China's economic growth surpasses the EU's, highlighting the significance of their relationship amidst EU investigations into Chinese subsidies and potential trade tensions.
Xi's tour intends to strengthen China's partnerships in Europe, navigating the continent's divided perspectives and leveraging shared interests to reshape global dynamics. The unrelated content regarding the CISCE results has been omitted from this summary.

item.title: Who is Sadiq Khan, the Pakistani-origin Mayor of London now re-elected to the post?
item.description: Sadiq Khan has been re-elected as the Mayor of London, marking his third consecutive victory and making him the longest-serving mayor in the city's history. His journey from humble beginnings as the son of Pakistani immigrants to a human rights lawyer and then a politician resonated with voters. Khan's political career began with his election as an MP in 2005, and he later became the first Muslim to serve in the cabinet as Minister for Transport. Despite facing criticism over rising violent crime rates, Khan's policies, such as freezing transport fares and tackling air pollution, have maintained his popularity among London's diverse electorate. His recent win is seen as a significant boost for the Labour Party ahead of the UK's general elections set for no later than January 2025. Khan's stance on international issues, like calling for a ceasefire following the October 7, 2023, Hamas attack on Israel, has also contributed to his electoral success.

item.title: IndiGo’s wide-body aircraft order: What makes long-haul, low-cost air travel a tough nut to crack?
item.description:
IndiGo, India's largest airline, has placed an order for 30 Airbus A350-900 aircraft, with an option for 70 more, signaling its ambition to expand into non-stop, long-haul international flights. This move comes after its record order of 500 narrow-body jets last year. The long-haul, low-cost airline model is challenging and has seen many failures, but IndiGo aims to succeed where others have struggled.
The success of low-cost carriers (LCCs) hinges on minimizing costs to offer low fares while maintaining profitability. However, long-haul flights face higher fuel costs and operational complexities, such as the need for additional crew due to longer journey times, which can impact cost control. Wide-body aircraft, like the A350, offer better fuel efficiency but come with higher purchase and maintenance costs.
Effective network planning is crucial for the success of LCCs, with strategies including operating on less competitive routes, using multiple hubs, and serving secondary airports to reduce costs. IndiGo's approach to long-haul flights may include a dual-class cabin configuration and a focus on under-served routes with latent demand.
IndiGo's CEO, Pieter Elbers, has stated that the airline is considering various options for its wide-body fleet, including cabin configuration and amenities, with decisions to be made based on market needs. The airline is experimenting with a bring-your-own-device (BYOD) model for in-flight entertainment and may introduce seat-back screens and other amenities on its A350s.
IndiGo plans to offer direct international flights from multiple Indian cities, not just major hubs, aligning with successful LCC network designs. This strategy, along with potential innovations in service and pricing, could position IndiGo favorably in the long-haul market, leveraging its strong domestic and short-haul international network for connections.
The article also includes an unrelated announcement about the release of ICSE Class 10 and 12 results for 2024, which will be available on May 6 at 11 am on the official website. Last year, the pass percentage for Class 12 was 96.93%, with girls outperforming boys. This information is not related to the main content of the article.

item.title: Israel sanctions: Who has imposed curbs over its Gaza assault?
item.description:
The article discusses the international response to the humanitarian crisis in Gaza, focusing on the actions taken by various countries and movements against Israel. Turkey has suspended its $7 billion trade with Israel, demanding a cease-fire and aid for Gaza. This decision was influenced by Israel's stance and the situation in Gaza's Rafah region. Criticism came from Israel's Foreign Minister, while Hamas welcomed the move. Turkey's trade halt includes a wide range of exports and imports, and negotiations are underway to minimize the impact on Palestinians.
France is the only major Western power considering sanctions to compel Israel to withdraw troops and increase humanitarian aid in Gaza. The US, Canada, France, and the UK have already imposed targeted sanctions on Israeli settlers in the West Bank accused of violence. The Biden administration plans to label goods from West Bank settlements to indicate their origin.
Chile has banned Israeli companies from a major aerospace fair and ceased all military cooperation and purchases from Israel. It has also called for an ICC investigation into Israel's actions in Gaza and the occupied territories.
The conflict has stalled the India-Middle East-Europe Economic Corridor project, which aims to enhance integration and counter China's Belt and Road initiative. The project's delay affects the potential normalization of relations between Israel and Saudi Arabia.
The Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions (BDS) movement promotes nonviolent action against Israel, inspired by South Africa's anti-apartheid efforts. It faces accusations of antisemitism but continues to advocate for boycotts and sanctions. Consumer apps like Boycat support the boycott by identifying products linked to Israel.
Lastly, the article mentions the announcement of the ICSE Class 10 and 12 results for 2024 by CISCE, unrelated to the main topic. The results will be released on May 6, with a notable pass percentage from the previous year.

item.title: What is Artificial General Intelligence (AGI), and why are people worried about it?
item.description: Sam Altman, CEO of OpenAI, has pledged significant investment in the development of Artificial General Intelligence (AGI), which aims to create machines capable of performing any intellectual task a human can. AGI represents a leap from narrow AI, which is limited to specific tasks, to a more generalized intelligence. The concept, dating back to Alan Turing's 1950 paper, holds potential for transformative impacts across healthcare, finance, business, and education. However, it also raises concerns about environmental impact, job loss, socio-economic disparity, and the potential for AGI to become uncontrollable. Prominent figures like Stephen Hawking and AI pioneers have called for strict regulations to align AGI development with human values and safety.

item.title: Why has China sent a mission to the far side of the Moon?
item.description:
China's Chang'e-6 mission, launched on May 3, aims to be the first to retrieve samples from the Moon's far side, unseen from Earth. The mission began at the Wenchang Space Launch Center and will take five days to reach lunar orbit. The far side of the Moon, often called the dark side, is of interest due to its unique features such as a thicker crust and more craters compared to the near side. Scientists believe that analyzing far-side samples could reveal the Moon's origins and why its two sides are different.
The 53-day mission will see the orbiter circle the Moon while the lander targets the South Pole-Aitken basin, a large impact site that may contain material from the lunar mantle. After sample collection, an ascent vehicle will rendezvous with the orbiter to return the samples to Earth. This follows China's successful Chang'e-4 mission in 2019, which achieved a soft landing on the far side and explored with a rover. The Chang'e-6 mission continues China's exclusive achievements in far-side lunar exploration.

item.title: What a Blue Corner notice will mean for Prajwal Revanna
item.description: The article discusses the likelihood of the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) issuing a Blue Corner notice for Janata Dal (Secular) MP Prajwal Revanna, who is accused of sexual abuse and has fled to Germany. A Blue Corner notice is one of Interpol's color-coded alerts used to share information on crimes and criminals internationally. It is specifically aimed at gathering additional information about a person's identity, location, or activities in relation to a criminal investigation. The article explains that while Interpol notices are discretionary and cannot compel action, cooperation between countries can lead to effective responses. The article also mentions that India's good relations with Germany may aid in the cooperation between law enforcement agencies to address the case. In the past, Interpol issued a Blue Notice to locate fugitive Godman Nithyananda. The article concludes by mentioning the release of Sanjay Leela Bhansali's web-series "Heeramandi" on Netflix.

item.title: How international students can (legally) get around Canada’s fixed work hours
item.description:
Canada has recently updated its student work regulations, limiting off-campus work for international students to 20 hours per week, which has caused financial difficulties for many. This limit is expected to increase to 24 hours in September, but students are still struggling with high tuition and living costs. The Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) is considering increasing the limit to 30 hours, but concerns about academic performance have been raised.
International students, particularly from developing countries, are pushing for more work hours to achieve financial independence. With parents typically funding only the first year, students must work to afford their education. New study permit requirements mandate proof of at least $20,635 in savings, plus tuition and travel costs. The high cost of living, including rent and daily necessities, adds to the financial burden.
Students can legally work more than 20 hours by taking on-campus jobs, which offer unlimited work hours. These positions include teaching or research assistants and jobs with on-campus businesses. However, competition for these roles is fierce due to limited availability. Off-campus work restrictions are lifted during summer and winter breaks, allowing full-time employment. On-campus work provides a potential solution for students to support themselves financially while studying in Canada.

item.title: Swell waves likely to hit several coastal areas over the weekend, says INCOIS: What are these waves?
item.description:
The Indian National Centre for Ocean Information Services (INCOIS) has issued a warning for high sea waves, known as swell waves, expected to affect the coastal regions of Goa, Maharashtra, West Bengal, Odisha, Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Lakshadweep, Karnataka, Gujarat, and Andaman & Nicobar Islands from May 4 to May 5. Fishermen and coastal residents are advised to suspend beach and nearshore activities due to potential risks.
Swell waves, which are not caused by local winds but by distant storms, can lead to significant flooding, as seen in Kerala in March. These waves originate from strong winds in distant parts of the ocean and can travel great distances before reaching the shore. INCOIS's Swell Surge Forecast System, launched in 2020, provides advanced warnings of such events.
The article also differentiates between swell waves and tsunamis, noting that tsunamis are much faster and associated with underwater earthquakes, while swell waves are generated by atmospheric conditions like storms and can be forecasted in advance.

item.title: Emergency, first non-Congress Govt, and a promise belied
item.description: The article provides a detailed account of the political events in India surrounding the 1977 Lok Sabha elections. It highlights the rise of the Janata Party and the fall of Indira Gandhi's Congress post-Emergency. The Emergency period saw widespread arrests and censorship, with Indira Gandhi's election being invalidated due to electoral malpractice. The Janata Party, formed from a merger of four parties, won the election with Morarji Desai becoming the Prime Minister. The Congress suffered a major defeat but retained some strength in the southern states. Internal conflicts within the Janata Party led to instability, and by 1979, Charan Singh briefly became Prime Minister with Congress support, which was soon withdrawn, leading to another election. The article concludes with the notion that this period was a significant experiment in Indian democracy.

item.title: Explained: The Eta Aquariid meteor shower and how it can be spotted
item.description:
The **Eta Aquariid meteor shower**, associated with **Halley's Comet**, is expected to be visible on May 6 and 7. These showers, consisting of space debris entering Earth's atmosphere at high speeds, are an annual occurrence in May. While best viewed from the Southern Hemisphere, they can also be observed in the Northern Hemisphere.
Meteor showers originate from comets, which are icy bodies that release gas and dust when near the Sun, creating a visible tail. The Eta Aquariids are particularly fast, with about 30 to 40 meteors per hour visible from the Southern Hemisphere at their peak. This rate decreases in the Northern Hemisphere due to the position of the radiant in the Aquarius constellation.
For optimal viewing, a clear, dark sky with minimal light pollution is recommended. The Eta Aquariids are visible to the naked eye and can be traced back to their point of origin near the Aquarius constellation. Halley's Comet, the source of these meteors, orbits the Sun every 76 years and was last seen in 1986. It will next appear in 2061. The Orionids in October are another meteor shower caused by this comet.

item.title: What led to Latin America’s record dengue surge
item.description:
Dengue cases in Latin America and the Caribbean have surged to over 5.9 million from January to April 2024, surpassing the total for 2023. The spike is attributed to rising temperatures, fostering ideal conditions for mosquito proliferation. Brazil is the hardest hit, with 4.2 million cases and over 2,000 deaths, leading to states declaring emergencies and setting up field hospitals. Peru, Puerto Rico, and Argentina are also experiencing significant outbreaks, with Central American countries and Mexico reporting early rises in cases.
Climate change, particularly a 0.2°C average temperature increase per decade over 30 years, has expanded mosquito habitats and extended their active season. The 2023 El Niño event and extreme weather, such as untimely rainfall and droughts, have exacerbated the situation, creating more breeding grounds for mosquitoes. Urbanization, especially in shantytowns with standing water and inadequate refuse collection, has also contributed to the spread.
Efforts to develop a dengue vaccine face challenges due to the virus's four strains and the risk of increased susceptibility to other strains after vaccination against one. Current vaccines, like Qdenga and Dengvaxia, are either costly or have limitations. Partnerships and new clinical trials aim to produce more affordable and effective vaccines, but widespread availability is still years away. The Serum Institute of India is also testing a single-shot vaccine, with hopes for future success.

item.title: From Feroze to Rahul: Brief history of Rae Bareli, bastion of Gandhi-Nehru family
item.description: Rahul Gandhi has filed his nomination for the Rae Bareli Lok Sabha seat, continuing the Gandhi-Nehru family's long-standing association with the constituency. The family's connection began with Feroze Gandhi in 1952. Over the years, the seat has seen significant events, including Indira Gandhi's election and the controversy that led to the Emergency. Post-Emergency, the constituency witnessed a non-Congress victory but returned to Congress control in subsequent elections. Sonia Gandhi has maintained the seat since 1998, despite strong challenges from BJP candidates. The current contest is between Rahul Gandhi and Dinesh Singh, reflecting the ongoing political dynamics in Rae Bareli.

item.title: On World Press Freedom Day, the story of India’s first newspaper – ‘Hicky’s Bengal Gazette’
item.description:
World Press Freedom Day, celebrated on May 3, highlights the pivotal role of journalism. The first newspaper in India, Hicky's Bengal Gazette, was launched on January 29, 1780, by James Augustus Hicky. Initially catering to the British in Calcutta and filled with gossip, the Gazette also exposed government corruption and criticized the British East India Company, leading to its shutdown due to libel suits.
Andrew Otis, in his book "Hicky's Bengal Gazette: The Untold Story of India’s First Newspaper," delves into Hicky's life, from his arrival in India to his imprisonment, where he started his printing business. The Gazette, Asia's first newspaper, covered local issues, civic problems, and even Calcutta's frequent fires, influencing policy changes like the ban on thatch houses.
Despite avoiding political issues initially, Hicky's Gazette became a platform for social commentary and criticism, leading to legal troubles and Hicky's financial ruin. Otis credits Hicky with contributing to the growth of Indian journalism, which persisted despite British repression. The legacy of the Gazette and its influence on Indian-owned presses and the spread of anti-colonial sentiment is a testament to the enduring power of the press.

item.title: Can Yulia Navalnaya unite the Russian opposition?
item.description:
Following the death of her husband Alexei Navalny, Yulia Navalnaya has decided to take over his Anti-Corruption Foundation and continue his work. She has accused Russian President Vladimir Putin of being responsible for her husband's death and has stated that an investigation is in progress. Alexei Navalny, who died at 47, was known for his political activism against corruption in Russia, which led to severe repercussions from the authorities.
Yulia Navalnaya, who met Alexei in 1998 and married him in 2000, has been a supportive partner throughout his political journey, even though she never aspired to be a politician herself. Despite her own academic and professional background, she chose to assist her husband with his work. Her role became increasingly significant as Alexei Navalny's political influence grew.
The article recounts various challenges the couple faced, including Alexei's arrest and conviction on embezzlement charges, which was widely seen as politically motivated. Yulia's support was crucial during these times, and she earned the nickname "First Lady" of the opposition when Alexei ran for mayor of Moscow.
Observers now see Yulia Navalnaya as a potential unifying symbol for the Russian opposition, with some suggesting she could become a moral symbol of resistance. Her determination and involvement in her husband's political career have been highlighted as key factors in her rise as a prominent figure in the opposition movement. She has expressed a commitment to fight for a new Russia, one that aligns with the vision of dignity, justice, and love that Alexei Navalny had championed. Her message is one of resilience and encouragement to continue the struggle without fear.

item.title: Why is a Reliance Capital Ltd investor challenging its resolution plan?
item.description: An investor, Harsh Mehta, has filed a writ petition challenging SEBI's delisting regulations and the NCLT's approval of a resolution plan for Reliance Capital Ltd (RCL), which is undergoing insolvency proceedings. The challenged regulation exempts delisting as per an IBC-approved resolution plan from the standard delisting norms. Mehta, who holds a small percentage of RCL shares, argues that this exemption fails to protect investors' interests, as it allows for the delisting of shares without prior intimation or approval from public shareholders. The resolution plan approved by NCLT, submitted by IndusInd International Holdings Ltd (IIHL), proposes to cancel and extinguish the entire share capital of RCL for nil consideration, effectively reducing the liquidation value of equity shareholders to zero and impacting 98.49% of public shareholders. The petitioner contends that this process undermines the interests of equity shareholders and violates the SEBI Act, 1992. The trading of RCL shares is currently suspended following the NCLT order.

item.title: Why Congo’s latest Mpox outbreak is concerning
item.description:
The Democratic Republic of the Congo is facing a significant Mpox outbreak, with over 4,500 suspected cases and nearly 300 deaths reported since January. This marks a substantial increase from the previous year. The outbreak has been declared a health emergency, and cases have also been reported in the neighboring Republic of Congo.
A new form of Mpox, detected in the mining town of Kamituga in eastern Congo, is believed to be more transmissible among humans. This is attributed to genetic mutations resulting from sustained human transmission, in a population with limited contact with the wild animals that are natural carriers of the disease.
Dr. Placide Mbala-Kingebeni, who leads a lab at Congo's National Institute of Biomedical Research, notes that the new form of the disease presents milder lesions primarily on the genitals, making diagnosis more challenging. The disease's transmission through sexual contact has been confirmed, with a significant number of cases found in sex workers.
The World Health Organization (WHO) has indicated that the mutations may necessitate a revised testing strategy. There are concerns about silent transmission if patients do not seek medical attention. Two clades of Mpox exist, with Clade 1 being more severe. A new form of Clade 1 has been identified, potentially linked to over 240 cases and at least three deaths in Kamituga.
Despite the urgent situation, Congo has had limited access to Mpox vaccines and treatments. The health minister has authorized vaccine use in high-risk areas, and discussions are underway with countries like Japan to secure funding for vaccines. However, WHO's emergencies chief, Dr. Michael Ryan, highlighted the lack of financial investment from donors to address the Mpox spread in Africa and beyond.

item.title: The flight of Prajwal Revanna: How diplomatic passports, visa regimes work
item.description:
Janata Dal (Secular) MP Prajwal Revanna, after being accused of sexual abuse, fled to Germany using a diplomatic passport. The Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) clarified that Revanna did not require a visa note for Germany due to a visa exemption agreement between India and Germany. Diplomatic passports, which are maroon and have a shorter validity than normal passports, grant the holder certain international law privileges, including immunity from arrest and legal proceedings in the host country.
Diplomatic passports are issued to a range of individuals, including those with diplomatic status, government officials on official business, certain ranks of the Indian Foreign Service, and their families, as well as MPs and union ministers representing the government abroad. The validity of these passports is tied to the term of the MP. Despite the visa exemption, Prajwal was still required to seek political clearance for his travel, which he did not.
Karnataka Chief Minister Siddaramaiah has requested the cancellation of Prajwal's diplomatic passport and his return to India to face legal action. However, the government can only revoke the passport following a court order, as per the Passport Act 1967, which allows revocation for wrongful possession, suppression of material information, or if deemed necessary by the passport authority in the interest of India's sovereignty, integrity, or international relations. A diplomatic passport can also be revoked if the holder is convicted by a court in India or upon court orders during criminal proceedings.

item.title: Australian media reports Indian spies ‘kicked out’: In the world of spycraft, why national interest trumps all
item.description: The article discusses a series of allegations against India regarding espionage and covert operations abroad. Reports from Australia, the US, the UK, and Canada have accused Indian operatives of various acts, including attempting to steal sensitive information and being involved in assassination plots. India has denied these allegations, with varying responses that reflect its strategic positions. The incidents have raised concerns among the Five Eyes intelligence-sharing network countries, which include the accusers and have strategic ties with India. The article suggests that while espionage is a common practice among nations, the public outing of Indian operatives by these countries indicates a pushback against India's covert activities. The narrative also touches upon India's foreign policy, its reliance on ancient statecraft principles from the Arthashastra, and the importance of intelligence in national security. It concludes with the perspective that intelligence operations should remain consistent regardless of diplomatic relations, as per the insights of a former R&AW chief. The article also briefly mentions unrelated domestic political developments in India.

item.title: Article 361: Immunity shield until Governor in office
item.description: The article discusses the constitutional immunity provided to the President and Governors in India, which protects them from being named as accused or investigated for criminal proceedings while in office. This immunity is outlined in Article 361 of the Constitution. The article cites several instances where this immunity has been applied, such as the case of former UP Chief Minister Kalyan Singh, who was not tried for criminal conspiracy charges while serving as the Governor of Rajasthan. It also mentions cases where Governors resigned following allegations of misconduct, such as V Shanmuganathan of Meghalaya and N D Tiwari of Andhra Pradesh. The article references a Supreme Court ruling that affirms the complete immunity of Governors from legal action for acts performed in their official capacity. Additionally, the article briefly touches on the casting of Sanjay Dutt in the film Munna Bhai, despite his industry ban, and the subsequent success of the film and its sequels.

item.title: Why the first scientist to publish genome sequencing of Covid-19 recently protested in China
item.description: Dr. Zhang Yongzhen, the scientist who first published the Covid-19 genome sequencing, has regained access to his lab in China after a protest against its closure. His early work was pivotal for vaccine development and understanding the virus. Despite an eviction and a dispute with the Shanghai Public Health Clinical Center, authorities have allowed him to continue his research. Zhang's initial findings in January 2020 linked the virus to SARS and were shared globally, aiding in vaccine and testing kit development. However, his lab was shut down for "rectification" shortly after publishing the data. Recent tensions involve lab closures for renovation, with Zhang's collaborators expressing difficulties in continuing their work. Posts by Zhang on these events have been removed from Chinese social media, indicating a possible government clampdown on medical professionals and activists discussing Covid-19. The full nature of the lab dispute remains unclear.

item.title: How US Navy SEALs shot dead Osama bin Laden in a Pakistani military town
item.description: The article recounts the events leading up to and including the US Navy SEALs' operation, codenamed Neptune Spear, that resulted in the death of Osama bin Laden on May 2, 2011, in Abbottabad, Pakistan. It details bin Laden's early life, his initial cooperation with the US during the Soviet-Afghan War, and his eventual turn to anti-American activities, including the 1993 World Trade Centre bombing and the 1998 US Embassy bombings. The article describes the extensive manhunt for bin Laden post-9/11, the challenges faced by the US in locating him, and the final covert operation that led to his death. It also touches on the complex relationship between Pakistan and the US, as the operation took place deep within Pakistani territory without their knowledge. Bin Laden's body was buried at sea shortly after the operation. The article concludes with unrelated content about Indian filmmaker Vidhu Vinod Chopra's career and collaborations.

item.title: How to decide domestic violence damages: injury or ability to pay?
item.description:
The Supreme Court of India is considering whether compensation in domestic violence cases should be based on the severity of violence or the perpetrator's financial capacity. This follows a petition challenging a directive for a man to pay Rs 3 crore to his wife under the Domestic Violence Act. The Act aims to protect women's rights within the family, defining domestic violence broadly to include physical, sexual, verbal, emotional, and economic abuse.
The petitioner's counsel argues that compensation should reflect the harm suffered, not the standard of living or income of the parties involved. The Act allows for monetary relief consistent with the aggrieved person's standard of living, but the debate centers on whether this should apply to compensation for damages.
Legal precedents suggest maintenance should prevent destitution and align with the spouse's capacity to pay, with the Supreme Court previously ruling that alimony should fit the parties' status and the payer's financial ability. The current case raises questions about the legal framework for calculating damages in domestic violence cases, as there is a lack of clear precedents, leading to the application of maintenance case laws to domestic violence situations. The court's decision could clarify the legal approach to compensation in such cases.

item.title: Why Theodor Herzl wanted to establish a sovereign Jewish state
item.description:
Theodor Herzl, born on May 2, 1860, in Budapest, is recognized as the father of modern Zionism. Encountering anti-Semitism from a young age, Herzl initially believed Jews could assimilate to overcome prejudice. However, witnessing the Dreyfus Affair in France, where a Jewish officer was wrongfully convicted, changed his perspective. In 1896, Herzl published "Der Judenstaat," advocating for Jewish self-determination and a separate state as the solution to anti-Semitism.
Herzl proposed Argentina or Palestine for this state, favoring the latter due to its historical significance. He tirelessly lobbied influential figures for support and organized the first World Jewish Conference in 1897, which led to the establishment of a Zionist organization aiming to create a legally recognized Jewish homeland.
Despite opposition from some Jews and not being the first to advocate for a Jewish homeland, Herzl's vision and political efforts were pivotal. They contributed to the broader Jewish support for a nation-state and influenced the Balfour Declaration and the eventual creation of Israel in 1948. Herzl passed away in 1904, but his legacy endures, with his remains interred at Mount Herzl in Jerusalem. He is the only individual mentioned in Israel's declaration of independence, highlighting his foundational role in the state's creation.

item.title: Should Shariat law apply to former Muslims in succession matters? The question before SC
item.description:
The Supreme Court of India is set to examine if a person who has left the Muslim faith should be governed by Muslim personal law or secular laws in matters of succession. This follows a plea by Safiya PM, representing former Muslims in Kerala, who argues for the right to be governed by secular laws, particularly the Indian Succession Act of 1925, in both intestate and testamentary succession cases.
The case raises questions about the application of the Muslim Personal Law (Shariat) Application Act, 1937, which dictates inheritance rules based on Islamic teachings. Safiya's plea is backed by the Supreme Court's 2018 Sabarimala ruling, emphasizing the freedom of religion, including the right to not follow any religion, without facing discrimination in civil rights such as inheritance.
The current law stipulates specific shares for various relatives, with provisions that can disadvantage women and non-Muslims. The petitioner's advocate highlighted the adverse effects of these provisions on individuals like Safiya, who may be prejudiced under the current laws.
Safiya's petition seeks to challenge Sections 2 and 3 of the 1937 Act, which mandate the application of Shariat in certain matters for Muslims. The court's decision to hear the case acknowledges the potential legal vacuum for those who leave the Muslim faith and seek a secular framework for inheritance. The court has sought responses from the government and will revisit the case in July. The article also briefly mentions an unrelated IPL cricket match update.

item.title: Why has private wheat purchase surged in Punjab?
item.description:
In Punjab, during the current Rabi season, there has been a significant **47% increase** in the private purchase of wheat compared to last year. As of May 1, the state's grain markets have received **109.57 lakh metric tonnes (LMT)** of wheat, with **107.69 LMT** already purchased. Private entities, such as flour millers and processors, have bought **6.18 LMT**, which is a substantial increase from the **4.19 LMT** purchased last year.
There are approximately **70 roller flour mills** in Punjab, with an annual processing capacity of around **12 LMT**. These mills primarily supply atta, sooji, and maida within Punjab and to other states. However, most of their wheat is procured from outside the state, with only **25-30%** sourced locally. The rest comes from the Food Corporation of India’s e-auction or from states like Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan, where wheat is cheaper.
This year, Punjab millers have already purchased over **50%** of their annual wheat consumption. The increase in local purchases is attributed to higher prices in other states and changes in the quota under the Open Market Sale Scheme (OMSS). The Minimum Support Price (MSP) in Rajasthan, for instance, is **Rs 2,400 per quintal**, prompting millers to offer **Rs 5-10 more per quintal** than the MSP in Punjab.
The millers, represented by Naresh Ghai, seek a transparent government policy on the open market sale price of wheat to better manage price fluctuation risks. The current trend of increased private wheat purchases in Punjab reflects their efforts to optimize procurement strategies and minimize financial risks.

item.title: US Fed will keep rates steady amid high inflation: Why this matters for the global economy
item.description:
The US Federal Reserve has decided to keep its benchmark rate steady, despite an increase in inflation. This decision diverges from earlier predictions of multiple rate cuts in 2024, with the current consensus being a single cut. The consumer price index rose more than expected, and Fed Chair Jerome Powell emphasized that rate cuts would not be considered until there is greater confidence that inflation is moving towards the 2% target. The Fed's stance has affected market enthusiasm, with the S&P 500 and FTSE 100 experiencing declines after the announcement.
The Fed's monetary policy, particularly the federal funds rate, plays a crucial role in influencing employment and inflation by affecting credit availability and cost. Lower interest rates encourage borrowing and spending, which can stimulate economic growth. However, the policy's impact on inflation and employment is not immediate.
A potential rate cut by the Fed could positively affect emerging markets like India, as it may widen the interest rate differential, making such countries more attractive for currency carry trade. It could also boost US growth, which is beneficial for global growth, and influence emerging market equities and currency markets.
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has kept its repo rate unchanged, with expectations of a rate cut later in the year, likely after the Fed's rate cut. The RBI's last rate cut was in May 2020, and since then, it has increased the rate to combat inflation. The RBI aims to maintain inflation at 4%, with a 2% margin on either side.
Lastly, President Joe Biden highlighted the positive contributions of immigrants to the US economy and criticized xenophobia, contrasting his views with former President Donald Trump's anti-immigrant stance.

item.title: What is the role of hydropower in a world facing increasing drought?
item.description:
Hydropower, a clean energy source providing more electricity than all other renewables combined, faces challenges due to climate change. Droughts, particularly those driven by El Niño, have led to power shortages in Ecuador and Colombia, countries heavily reliant on hydropower. The vulnerability of hydropower to climate-induced weather patterns, such as droughts and floods, is an increasing concern. The first half of 2023 saw a historic drop in global hydropower output, with an 8.5% decrease attributed to droughts, likely worsened by climate change.
Countries with high dependence on hydropower, like those in Africa, are especially vulnerable to climate impacts due to limited alternative power generation and transmission infrastructure. Diversifying power sources and integrating renewable technologies like wind and solar are suggested solutions. Innovations like floating solar panels on reservoirs could complement hydropower generation.
Despite these risks, hydropower is still seen as crucial for decarbonizing the global economy. Medium-scale plants are recommended over mega dams to mitigate climate risks. The International Energy Agency predicts that while hydropower will be surpassed by wind and solar, it will remain the largest source of renewable electricity into the 2030s. However, a slowdown in industry growth could impact net-zero goals. Doubling hydropower capacity by 2050 is necessary to limit global temperature increases to 1.5°C, requiring significant investment.
Better water management and integration with other renewables can improve hydropower's resilience to drought. Hydropower also stabilizes electricity generation, acting as a large battery that can quickly adjust output. Pumped-storage schemes, which recycle water, offer additional resilience to drought compared to traditional hydropower.

item.title: Ex-envoy TCA Raghavan: ‘The military can no longer order Pakistan politics in the way it likes’
item.description: The article discusses the political dynamics in Pakistan following the elections, highlighting the surprising strength of Imran Khan's position despite the military's influence. It notes that the military can no longer dictate politics as before, and the traditional political parties, PPP and PML-N, are now in a coalition with the military, which is expected to be short-lived due to economic challenges. Nawaz Sharif is taking a backseat, grooming Maryam as his political heir, while Shehbaz Sharif focuses on infrastructure projects. The article also touches on the broader geopolitical context, including Pakistan's reduced leverage following the US's shift in focus to other global issues and the need for India to engage with Pakistan as part of its foreign policy, despite the current impasse in relations. It concludes with observations on the China-Pakistan relationship and the structural economic challenges Pakistan faces.

item.title: What marijuana reclassification means for the United States
item.description: The article discusses a proposal by the US Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) to reclassify marijuana from Schedule I to Schedule III, acknowledging its medical uses but not legalizing recreational use. The process involves reviews and public comments, and while it doesn't immediately change the legal status, it's seen as a significant shift. President Biden supports the move, which aligns with his stance on medical marijuana. The reclassification could impact research, as Schedule III drugs are easier to study, and reduce taxes for cannabis businesses. However, it doesn't address banking issues faced by the industry. Critics argue the change is either too political or not substantial enough, with some advocating for complete removal from the controlled substances list. The article also mentions President Biden's views on immigration and his criticism of xenophobia.

item.title: Why can accused persons in prison contest polls but not vote?
item.description:
The article discusses the legal nuances of the right to vote and the right to be elected in India, particularly in the context of imprisoned individuals. It highlights that while free and fair elections are considered a basic constitutional principle, the rights to elect and be elected are statutory rights and not fundamental rights. This distinction allows for certain restrictions, such as those outlined in the Representation of People Act, 1951 (RP Act).
**Key points include:** - **Amritpal Singh**, a jailed leader, intends to run for Lok Sabha elections, but cannot vote due to his imprisonment. - The Supreme Court has ruled that the rights to vote and be elected are statutory, not fundamental, which means they can be regulated by law. - **Section 8 of the RP Act** disqualifies individuals from contesting elections upon conviction of certain offenses, with a further six-year ban after release. - There have been legal challenges to this section, but the Supreme Court has maintained that only the legislature can amend the RP Act. - The **Election Commission of India** can reduce disqualification periods, as seen in the case of Sikkim Chief Minister Prem Singh Tamang. - Convicted MPs or MLAs can contest elections if their conviction is stayed on appeal. - **Section 62 of the RP Act** bars imprisoned individuals from voting, with the exception of those in preventive detention. - The Supreme Court has upheld this restriction, citing the statutory nature of the right to vote and other practical considerations.
The article concludes with an unrelated mention of President Joe Biden's views on immigration and xenophobia, contrasting his stance with that of former President Donald Trump. This part of the article does not relate to the main legal discussion.

item.title: Why is China more important for Tesla than India?
item.description:
Elon Musk's recent visit to Beijing, after postponing his trip to India, highlights China's pivotal role in Tesla's global supply chain. China leads in electric vehicle (EV) sales and battery production, with CATL, a key Tesla supplier, dominating two-thirds of the global market. Tesla's Shanghai Gigafactory, its largest and first outside the U.S., produces over a million Model 3 and Model Y vehicles annually for various markets.
India, while a potential player in the global EV market, currently depends on battery imports and has a disjointed supply chain. The country is promoting domestic battery production through incentives and aims to capture a significant market share by 2030. India's recently released EV policy reflects a shift in stance, easing duties on car imports to encourage foreign investment.
Despite China's strong position, its EV exports face scrutiny in Europe and the U.S. over subsidy concerns, which may create opportunities for India. The European Commission is investigating China's BEV subsidies, and the U.S. views Chinese EVs as a competitive threat, indicating a complex and evolving landscape for the global EV industry. President Biden's remarks on immigration further underscore the geopolitical dynamics affecting the sector.

item.title: May Day: Why May 1 is observed as Labour Day
item.description:
May Day, observed on May 1st, is known as International Workers' Day or Labour Day in various countries, honoring the labor movement's achievements. The day's significance dates back to the late 19th century, particularly the Haymarket Affair in Chicago on May 4, 1886. This event saw a violent confrontation between police and labor protesters after a bomb exploded during a rally, resulting in casualties on both sides. The aftermath led to the arrest of numerous protesters, with some receiving harsh sentences. Those who died were commemorated as "Haymarket Martyrs," and the incident profoundly impacted the labor movement, advancing the push for improved labor conditions globally.
The US recognized Labor Day as a federal holiday in 1894, celebrated on the first Monday of September, a practice later adopted by Canada. However, it wasn't until 22 years of protests that the US acknowledged the eight-hour workday. In contrast, The Second International chose May 1st to honor International Workers' Day in 1889, a date later reinforced by the International Socialist Congress for global demonstrations advocating for workers' rights.
Post the Russian Revolution in 1917, May Day gained prominence in the Soviet Union and Eastern Bloc, often marked by parades showcasing military strength. In India, May Day was first celebrated in 1923, initiated by the Labour Kisan Party and led by Comrade Singaravelar, who advocated for it to be a national holiday.
The article also mentions President Joe Biden's views on immigration and its positive impact on the US, contrasting it with the xenophobic attitudes from certain countries and former President Donald Trump's anti-immigrant rhetoric.

item.title: How the next government will push ‘balanced fertilisation’
item.description:
The article discusses the issue of balanced fertilisation in India and the government's policy goals post-Lok Sabha elections. It highlights the record consumption of urea at 35.8 million tonnes in the fiscal year ending March 2024, despite measures like neem coating to improve nitrogen use efficiency and reduce illegal diversion for non-agricultural uses. The article explains that balanced fertilisation involves supplying crops with primary, secondary, and micro-nutrients in the right proportions, which is crucial for plant growth and yield.
The Nutrient-Based Subsidy (NBS) system, introduced in April 2010, aimed to promote balanced fertilisation by linking subsidies to nutrient content, encouraging the use of complex fertilisers with balanced nutrient proportions. However, the exclusion of urea from NBS led to its increased consumption, undermining the system's objectives.
Recent price controls on non-urea fertilisers have led to nutrient imbalances, with DAP becoming the "new urea" due to its lower price compared to complex fertilisers, leading to over-application by farmers. The article suggests that a proper price hierarchy among non-urea fertilisers and bringing urea under NBS could help promote balanced plant nutrition.
The article also touches on India's heavy dependence on imported fertilisers and the impact of global prices on the country's subsidy burden. It mentions the Centre's approval of sulphur-coated urea and the potential for more balanced fertilisation policies in the future.
Lastly, the article includes unrelated content about President Joe Biden's views on immigration, contrasting his stance with former President Donald Trump's rhetoric, which is not related to the main topic of fertilisation policies.

item.title: Chocolate industry meltdown: What led to the rise in prices of cocoa beans
item.description:
The chocolate industry is facing a crisis due to a significant increase in cocoa bean prices, which have quadrupled from the previous year, reaching $12,000 per tonne. This surge is attributed to a combination of factors including El Niño, climate change, black pod disease, and the low income of cocoa farmers in West Africa, particularly Ghana and Ivory Coast, which produce 60% of the world's cocoa. The bad harvest caused by El Niño and exacerbated by climate change has led to a predicted global cocoa shortfall of 374,000 tonnes for the 2023-2024 season. Consequently, chocolate prices in the US have risen by 11.6%.
Climate change poses a long-term threat to cocoa production, with erratic rainfall and extreme weather events affecting the moisture-sensitive trees. The situation is worsened by the low wages paid to cocoa farmers, who earn less than $1.25 a day, pushing them below the United Nations' poverty line. The financial struggles of these farmers have led to a decrease in investments for increasing yield and combating climate change, and have resulted in the prevalence of slave and child labor on cocoa farms.
Despite the hardships faced by farmers, the four largest chocolate companies have reported substantial profits, yet they have done little to improve the farmers' income. Experts and researchers argue that these companies could redistribute wealth along the supply chain to alleviate the situation, but without such measures, the scarcity of cocoa beans and the exploitation of farmers are likely to continue, further driving up chocolate prices.

item.title: Why the Booker Prize’s links to slavery have come under criticism, again
item.description:
The Booker Prize, a prestigious literary award, has been scrutinized for its historical ties to slavery through its original sponsor, the Booker Group. The controversy arose when BBC Radio host Richie Brave highlighted the Booker brothers' role as enslavers in the early 1800s. The Booker Prize website has since updated its language to reflect this accurately.
Established in 1969, the Booker Prize was initially exclusive to Commonwealth writers but later expanded globally. It was sponsored by the Booker Group until 2001, followed by the Man Group until 2019, and is currently sponsored by the charity Crankstart.
The Booker brothers' wealth stemmed from their involvement in the slave-driven sugar and cotton industries in British Guyana. Post-slavery, they received compensation for emancipated slaves and continued exploitation by employing indentured laborers from India, significantly impacting Guyana's demographic.
Philosopher John Berger, who won the prize in 1972, protested its slavery links by donating part of his prize money to the British Black Panther movement. More recently, novelist Kiley Reid addressed the challenge of reconciling the prize's past with its present significance, noting the pervasive legacy of racism in institutions. The article also touches on broader historical and social contexts, including the division of South America by European powers and the subsequent exploitation of African and Indian populations.

item.title: Why Bombay High Court said banks can’t seek LOCs to stop debtors from going abroad
item.description:
The Bombay High Court has ruled that **public sector banks (PSBs) cannot request the issuance of Look Out Circulars (LOCs)** against loan defaulters. This decision invalidates the central government's Office Memoranda that previously allowed PSBs to do so. The court found that such LOCs, which prevent debtors from leaving the country, are violative of fundamental rights under Articles 14 and 21 of the Constitution.
The LOCs were challenged as they were seen as bypassing legal processes and were based on a clause that allowed PSB heads to request LOCs against defaulters, including guarantors and corporate officers. The petitioners argued that this infringed upon their fundamentalThe Bombay High Court has ruled that public sector banks cannot request Look Out Circulars (LOCs) against loan defaulters, overturning government provisions allowing this. The court found LOCs to be a violation of fundamental rights, emphasizing that banks shouldn't have unilateral power in such matters. It also criticized the distinction between public and private banks in issuing LOCs, calling it arbitrary. The judgment doesn't affect existing orders but suggests recourse through courts or the Fugitive Economic Offenders Act. The verdict can be challenged in the Supreme Court, and the government can frame laws consistent with constitutional rights.

item.title: SC rejects application of ‘eggshell skull’ rule in a case: What is this legal principle?
item.description: The Supreme Court of India reinstated a compensation of Rs 5 lakhs for medical negligence to Jyoti Devi, which was initially awarded by the district consumer forum but later reduced by the state and national consumer courts. The case highlighted the 'eggshell skull' legal principle, which holds an offender liable for all injuries caused, even if the victim has a pre-existing condition that exacerbates the injury. This principle was incorrectly applied in Jyoti's case, as she did not have a pre-existing condition that would have caused 'unusual damage'. The Supreme Court's decision was based on the prolonged suffering of Jyoti for over five years and the decade-long duration of the legal process. The 'eggshell skull' rule, also known as the 'thin skull rule', originates from an 1891 case in the US and is a common law principle in civil litigation for claiming enhanced compensation.

item.title: Covishield could cause blood clots in very rare cases, manufacturer AstraZeneca has said. What does this mean?
item.description:
AstraZeneca has acknowledged that its AZD1222 vaccine, known as Covishield in India, has a very rare risk of causing low platelet counts and blood clots, known as Thrombosis with Thrombocytopenia Syndrome (TTS). This admission came to light through court documents related to a lawsuit in the UK, where individuals affected by TTS after receiving the vaccine are seeking damages.
The Indian government had previously advised caution when administering Covishield to individuals with low platelet counts. Several European countries temporarily halted the use of the vaccine in 2021 due to blood clotting concerns. However, the World Health Organization (WHO) has stated that the risk of TTS is very low, with data suggesting a rate of four cases per million adults in the UK and one per 100,000 in the EU.
In India, the government reported 26 potential thromboembolic events following the administration of Covishield, equating to a very low incidence rate. A committee on Adverse Events Following Immunization (AEFI) confirmed 36 cases of TTS caused by Covishield, including 18 deaths, most of which occurred in 2021. Despite this, the Union Health Ministry maintains that the benefits of Covishield outweigh the risks, especially for preventing Covid-19 infections and reducing deaths. It also noted that the risk of blood clotting is significantly lower in South and Southeast Asian populations compared to European descent.
In 2023, the WHO updated its classification of TTS to include vaccine-induced immune thrombotic thrombocytopenia (VITT). The overall stance is that while there is a risk of TTS, it remains exceedingly rare, and the vaccines have a positive benefit-risk profile.

item.title: Elon Musk visits China: Why rolling out Full Self-Driving cars matters for Tesla
item.description:
Elon Musk has reportedly received tentative approval to introduce Tesla's Full Self-Driving (FSD) technology in China. This comes after a meeting with Chinese officials and could be a significant boost for Tesla, which faces slowing demand in the US and competition in China. Tesla may continue its partnership with Baidu for mapping and navigation services essential for FSD, but it's uncertain if this will restrict Tesla from exporting FSD data to the US.
FSD is an advanced driver assistance system (ADAS) that enhances safety and convenience, and Tesla aims to release it as a supervised autonomy system in markets where it can obtain regulatory approval. Tesla's vehicles come with an 'Autopilot' feature, which includes functions like 'Traffic-Aware Cruise Control' and 'Autosteer'. FSD adds capabilities like navigating on Autopilot, suggesting lane changes, and automatic parking, among others. These features are continuously improved through over-the-air updates.
The introduction of FSD in China could help Tesla compete better in the world's largest auto market. Despite annual promises since 2014, full self-driving technology remains a challenge for Tesla and other carmakers. Issues have included traffic violations and difficulties in recognizing pedestrians and cyclists. Tesla's approach to beta testing FSD with regular drivers has raised concerns, especially as it involves public road testing by drivers who paid for the feature.
The broader industry faces challenges in developing full self-driving cars, with debates over the best technology to use, such as cameras versus a combination of sensors. Tesla relies mainly on cameras, while others use a mix of technologies. The complexity of real-world AI and the need for extensive autonomous driving data are significant hurdles in achieving fully autonomous driving. Regulatory scrutiny over the safety of these systems continues, with investigations into Tesla's driver monitoring improvements and the adequacy of its vehicle recalls.

item.title: Why RBI has advised banks to refund borrowers for overcharging on interest
item.description:
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has identified unfair lending practices by banks and NBFCs, such as charging excess interest from the date of loan sanction or agreement, rather than from the actual disbursement date. In cases where loans were disbursed by cheque, interest was charged from the date of the cheque issuance, not when the cheque was given to the customer. Some banks charged interest for an entire month even if the loan was repaid within the month and collected advance installments while still charging interest on the full loan amount.
In response, the RBI issued a directive on April 29, instructing banks and NBFCs to review and correct their loan disbursal and interest charging practices to ensure fairness and transparency. The RBI's supervisory teams have advised banks to refund any excess interest and charges. The RBI emphasizes adherence to the Fair Practices Code, which promotes transparent interest charges and communication with borrowers regarding changes in interest rates and the option to switch to a fixed rate as per the bank's policy. However, these practices are reportedly not always followed by banks. The unrelated content about President Joe Biden's remarks on immigration has been omitted from this summary.

item.title: Heatwaves in several parts of India: Why has April been hotter than usual?
item.description: April 2024 in India has been marked by intense heatwaves, with the India Meteorological Department (IMD) reporting such conditions across various regions. The southern peninsular and southeastern coast have been particularly affected, while the northern plains have been spared so far. Heatwaves are officially declared when temperatures exceed normal by 4.5°C in the plains and 6°C in hilly regions. This year's severe heat is attributed to the El Niño weather pattern and persistent anticyclone systems, causing subsidence and preventing cooler sea breezes. The IMD's forecast had predicted these extreme conditions, which have predominantly impacted states like West Bengal, Odisha, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Karnataka, and Maharashtra. The situation reflects a broader trend of increasing temperatures and heatwaves in regions previously unaffected, signaling a shift in climate patterns.

item.title: Congress split and Garibi Hatao: last poll before Emergency
item.description: In 1970, facing political unrest, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi dissolved the Lok Sabha, calling for early elections to seek a mandate on her policies like bank nationalization and abolition of privy purses. The Congress party split, with Indira leading her faction to victory in the 1971 elections with the slogan "Garibi Hatao." The election saw unprecedented violence and electoral malpractices. Indira's government, however, faced challenges, including accusations of involvement in the Maharaja of Bastar's assassination and a no-confidence motion. Despite these, she secured a two-thirds majority. Her tenure saw significant events like the creation of Bangladesh post-1971 war, but her election was later invalidated, leading to the declaration of Emergency in 1975, altering Indian politics significantly.

item.title: What is Sierra Madre, an old ship fuelling China-Philippines tensions in South China Sea?
item.description: The South China Sea dispute has intensified with the Philippines and China clashing over territorial claims. Central to this is the Sierra Madre, a WWII ship stationed by the Philippines at Second Thomas Shoal to assert sovereignty. China's aggressive tactics, including swarming Filipino resupply vessels, have escalated tensions. The ship, now dilapidated, remains a symbol of the Philippines' claim, with its removal risking Chinese dominance. The region's rich resources have led to overlapping claims, notably on the Spratly and Paracel islands. An international tribunal supported the Philippines' claims in 2016, but China rejected the ruling. The US has reaffirmed its defense commitments to the Philippines, indicating support against Chinese coercion in the disputed waters.

item.title: What’s behind the demand for delaying polls in the Anantnag-Rajouri Lok Sabha constituency
item.description: In the run-up to the Anantnag-Rajouri Lok Sabha seat elections in Jammu & Kashmir, four parties have requested a postponement due to blocked roads from snowfall, hindering campaigning. Contrarily, other parties claim the roads are navigable. The controversy stems from the 2022 formation of the Anantnag-Rajouri constituency, which amalgamated regions from Jammu and Kashmir, altering the demographic balance and sparking accusations of electoral manipulation to favor the BJP. The BJP has not fielded a candidate, instead supporting allies, amidst speculation that a delayed election could benefit pro-BJP candidates. The constituency's demographic is a mix of non-ST Muslims in Kashmir and ST Gujjars, Bakerwals, and Paharis in Jammu, with recent government actions seen as BJP's bid to gain influence in the Valley.

item.title: Article 31C: Why the SC is deciding if a fundamental right still exists in a case about private property?
item.description: The Supreme Court of India is revisiting the constitutional validity of Article 31C, which protects laws aimed at distributing community resources equitably and preventing wealth concentration. Initially safeguarding specific directive principles from legal challenges, Article 31C's scope was expanded by the 42nd Amendment but later restricted by the Minerva Mills verdict. The current debate arises from a property acquisition case under the Maharashtra Housing and Area Development Act, questioning whether "material resources of the community" include private property. The court's decision could clarify the status of Article 31C post-Minerva Mills, addressing whether it was entirely struck down or partially revived, a significant issue with implications for property rights and socio-economic policies.

item.title: All you need to know about Pakistan’s Hangor class submarines, built by China
item.description: The first of eight Hangor-class submarines, built by China for Pakistan, was launched on April 26. These diesel-electric attack submarines, larger than India's Kalavari class, are set to join the Pakistan Navy by 2028. The Hangor-class features an air-independent propulsion (AIP) system, enhancing underwater endurance, and is armed with six torpedo tubes and missile capabilities, including the Babur-3 cruise missile. While the Kalavari class lacks AIP, India plans to upgrade with an indigenous system. The Hangor-class's size may limit maneuverability in shallow waters compared to the more compact Kalavari class. Both classes have advanced sensor suites, but the Hangor's specifics remain undisclosed.

item.title: AI in football: How new tech can help teams take more effective corner kicks
item.description: DeepMind's TacticAI is an innovative AI system designed to enhance football tactics, particularly for corner kicks.
