Developed in collaboration with Liverpool Football Club, it uses a geometric deep learning approach to model corner kick scenarios as graphs, capturing player interactions more effectively than traditional methods. TacticAI has been well-received, with experts preferring its tactical suggestions 90% of the time over existing practices. It represents a significant step in applying AI to dynamic team sports, offering predictive and generative insights that could revolutionize not just football, but potentially other domains like gaming and robotics. This advancement underscores the growing role of AI in strategic sports analysis and decision-making.

item.title: Behind cannibal stereotype: Why Joe Biden’s comments offended Papua New Guinea
item.description: Papua New Guinea's Prime Minister James Marape rebuked US President Joe Biden for suggesting cannibalism in New Guinea during WWII. Biden's anecdote about his uncle's disappearance after a plane crash invoked outdated stereotypes, which Marape dismissed, emphasizing his nation's dignity. The article highlights the Korowai and Fore tribes' historical practices of consuming human flesh, not out of savagery but as part of complex social customs, often misunderstood by Western perspectives. The Fore ceased the practice in the 1960s after linking it to the fatal kuru disease. The piece contextualizes Biden's remarks within the broader misuse of the cannibal stereotype, historically exploited to justify colonial atrocities, and examines cannibalism's diverse roles and rationales across cultures and species.

item.title: This Quote Means: ‘We do not have government by the majority… but by the majority who participate’
item.description: The second phase of India's 2024 Lok Sabha elections saw a slight decrease in voter turnout at 66.7%, a 3% drop from 2019. This decline is notable given India's history of high participation rates, which are indicative of a robust democracy. The article emphasizes the importance of voting as a fundamental democratic exercise and a reflection of public trust in the political process. It highlights the struggles of marginalized groups to secure voting rights and how voting empowers individuals as stakeholders in society. The piece also discusses voter apathy, its potential dangers to democracy, and the need for greater accountability in the political system. It references the Indian Supreme Court's introduction of the 'None of the Above' option as a means to express dissatisfaction, underscoring its role in a vibrant democracy. The article concludes by examining the impact of voter disillusionment, particularly among the youth, on election participation.

item.title: Uttarakhand forest fire: How are forest fires caused and how frequent are they in India?
item.description: In Uttarakhand's Nainital district, forest fires prompted the Indian Air Force to conduct firefighting operations using Bambi buckets. The fires affected Nainital, Haldwani, and Ramnagar forest divisions. Forest fires in India, which occur from November to June, are influenced by temperature, dry vegetation, and moisture levels. The Forest Survey of India notes that 36% of India's forests are fire-prone, with severe fires in dry deciduous forests. Northeastern states, parts of Maharashtra, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, and regions in Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, and Karnataka are highly susceptible. Most fires are man-made, linked to agriculture and land-use changes. In Uttarakhand, causes include deliberate acts, carelessness, and natural factors. Prevention methods include watch towers, fire watchers, community involvement, and fire lines. Satellite technology aids in fire management. Separately, India's T20 World Cup team selection is underway, with focus on Samson and Gill, and uncertainty over KL Rahul's inclusion.

item.title: How a new report links fashion giants Zara and H&M to deforestation in Brazil
item.description: An Earthsight investigation has revealed that cotton used by major brands like Zara and H&M is linked to deforestation and human rights abuses in Brazil. Despite sustainability labels, the UK-based NGO found that cotton production in Brazil's Cerrado region, a biodiversity hotspot, is causing environmental damage. The report tracked 816,000 tons of cotton linked to European brands, produced for eight Asian manufacturers. It highlighted the role of SLC Agricola, responsible for 11% of Brazil's cotton exports, in deforestation. Better Cotton, a certification scheme, failed to prevent the implicated cotton from reaching the market. The findings have prompted calls for stricter supply chain regulations and accountability from European markets to mitigate negative impacts on the environment and human rights.

item.title: Why fentanyl, reportedly the biggest killer of Americans aged 18-49, figured in Antony Blinken’s China visit
item.description: US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken's visit to China highlighted the fentanyl crisis, a synthetic opioid causing widespread addiction and death in the US. Blinken discussed with Chinese officials the need to control the production and export of fentanyl precursors. The US blames China and Mexico for trafficking fentanyl, which is often mixed into other drugs unbeknownst to users. The US has seen a dramatic increase in opioid-related deaths, with fentanyl being a significant factor. Cooperation between the US and China is crucial, as evidenced by the recent bilateral Counternarcotics Working Group. However, tensions over various geopolitical issues have hindered progress. The US seeks to address the crisis domestically and internationally, with the FEND Off Fentanyl Bill targeting illicit traffickers and precursor chemical producers. The issue is a major concern for US voters ahead of the presidential elections.

item.title: Expert Explains: What Election Commission can do if normal polling process is disrupted
item.description: The Election Commission of India (EC) has annulled polls in certain stations in Manipur and Arunachal Pradesh due to irregularities, with repolls scheduled subsequently. Additionally, the death of a candidate has postponed elections in Madhya Pradesh's Betul constituency. India's election laws cater to disruptions in polling, ensuring a fair and uninterrupted democratic process. Provisions include voiding polls for EVM tampering or damage, booth-capturing, and natural disasters. Repolls involve fresh voting, with specific measures to prevent repeat voting. The EC has the authority to countermand elections if booth-capturing is widespread, affecting the election's integrity. In cases of candidate death, the poll is adjourned, allowing the concerned party to nominate a new candidate. These laws maintain the sanctity and transparency of elections in India.

item.title: What is a Bambi Bucket, being used by an IAF helicopter to fight Nainital forest fires?
item.description: To combat the forest fires in Uttarakhand's Nainital district, the Indian Air Force deployed an MI 17 V5 helicopter equipped with a "Bambi Bucket" to douse the flames. The Bambi Bucket, a collapsible container for aerial firefighting, was filled with water from Bhimtal Lake and released over the fires. Invented in 1982 by Canadian Don Arney, the Bambi Bucket has been a game-changer in firefighting due to its ease of filling and effectiveness in water delivery. It releases a solid column of water, ensuring a more impactful and less evaporative drop. Available in sizes up to 9,840 liters, it's now used globally by over 1,000 operators. Arney's innovation earned him a place in the Inventors Hall of Fame in 2017.

item.title: Why Canada is top preference for Indians wishing to study abroad, despite obstacles
item.description: Despite recent policy changes, Canada remains a top destination for Indian students, particularly from Punjab. The country's welcoming environment and excellent public universities continue to attract students, offering them a clearer path to post-study settlement. Canada's work permit and Permanent Residency (PR) policies are more favorable than those of the US, UK, and Australia, with higher visa success rates and lower refusal rates. Experts highlight Canada's transparent process and the high presence of Indian communities as confidence boosters for students. Even with a cap on international students, opportunities for Indian students in Canada are still abundant, with a high percentage already studying there. The support from local Indian communities also helps mitigate homesickness for students abroad.

item.title: When Supreme Court junked the Election Commision’s first EVM experiment in Kerala
item.description: In 1982, the Supreme Court of India disapproved the use of electronic voting machines (EVMs) in elections, citing the lack of legislative backing and the need for voter training. This verdict came after EVMs were first used in Kerala's Parur Assembly constituency, leading to a contested election result. Despite the Election Commission of India's (ECI) assertion of its constitutional powers, the court ruled that only Parliament had the legislative authority to sanction EVMs. However, the concept persisted, and by 2004, EVMs had fully replaced ballot papers in the Lok Sabha elections, following legal amendments and gradual adoption across various states. This marked a significant evolution in India's electoral process from paper ballots to electronic systems.

item.title: How ISRO used satellite remote-sensing to analyse glacial lakes in Himalayas
item.description: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) has reported a significant expansion of glacial lakes in the Indian Himalayan river basins, analyzing satellite data from the past four decades. The study found that out of 2,431 lakes larger than 10 hectares, 676 have expanded since 1984, with 601 lakes more than doubling in size. This expansion is attributed to the accelerated retreat of glaciers due to global warming, leading to the formation of lakes in depressions caused by glacial movement. ISRO categorized these lakes into moraine-dammed, ice-dammed, erosion-based, and others. Glacial lakes are vital freshwater sources but also pose risks of glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs), which can devastate downstream communities. Satellite remote-sensing technology aids in monitoring these lakes, providing insights for environmental impact assessments and risk management strategies. Fieldwork, including early warning systems, is essential for critical sites to mitigate GLOF risks.

item.title: Explained: Symbol Loading Unit (SLU), the ‘matchbox’ that feeds EVM candidate information
item.description: The Supreme Court of India has directed the Election Commission to secure Symbol Loading Units (SLUs) for 45 days post-election results, marking a change from only storing EVM components. SLUs, crucial for loading candidate symbols onto VVPATs, will now be available for scrutiny if election results are contested. This decision prevents the reuse of SLUs across different phases of multi-phase elections, necessitating the procurement of additional units by the EC. Furthermore, the court has permitted candidates to request verification of EVM software for tampering, with a focus on second and third-place finishers. This move requires candidates to bear the cost, with a refund only if tampering is detected. The verification process involves inspecting the memory/microcontrollers of EVMs, with engineers certifying their authenticity. These changes do not affect voters but significantly alter the EC's polling organization, potentially impacting the Representation of the People Act regarding election petitions.

item.title: Full cross-checking, mismatches, return to paper: 5 arguments Supreme Court rejected on VVPATs
item.description: The Supreme Court of India dismissed petitions for 100% VVPAT slip verification with EVM counts, emphasizing the importance of trust in the electoral process. Justices Khanna and Datta expressed confidence in EVM security and dismissed concerns of tampering as unfounded. The court maintained that voter rights are safeguarded by existing measures like the seven-second VVPAT slip display. Justice Khanna directed additional security checks for EVM microcontrollers and sealing of Symbol Loading Units post-election. Instances of EVM-VVPAT discrepancies were deemed isolated, with the court rejecting the idea of returning to paper ballots or providing physical VVPAT slips to voters, citing potential misuse and malpractices.

item.title: Looking back at the Chernobyl disaster, 38 years later: Who was responsible?
item.description: The Chernobyl disaster of April 26, 1986, stands as a catastrophic nuclear event. Reactor 4's explosion released immense amounts of radiation, initially killing two workers, with subsequent deaths from acute radiation sickness. Predictions estimate up to 9,000 cancer-related deaths in affected areas. The disaster rendered 2,600 sq km uninhabitable and sparked debate over culpability. Faulty safety tests led to the meltdown, with some blaming operator error, while others cite design flaws and poor human-machine interaction. The Soviet Union initially concealed the incident, which released more radiation than the Hiroshima bomb. Decades later, responsibility remains contested, highlighting the complex interplay between human actions and technological systems.

item.title: Is Japan moving closer to a future female empress?
item.description: Japan's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) is considering legal reforms to prevent a succession crisis in the imperial family, potentially allowing female members to retain royal status post-marriage and reinstating previously removed branches. This shift, influenced by public support for an empress, marks a departure from traditionalist views. However, critics argue these proposals are conservative ploys to preserve male-only succession. The debate reflects broader societal discussions on gender equality, with many Japanese favoring a more inclusive approach to imperial succession. Despite this, the likelihood of these reforms passing is uncertain due to the need for unanimous legislative agreement and opposition from conservative factions.

item.title: The planet’s plastic problem: why we need a global plastics treaty
item.description: Negotiators from 175 countries are in Ottawa to draft a global treaty to address plastic pollution, aiming to finalize it by the end of 2024. This treaty is considered the most significant environmental agreement since the 2015 Paris climate accord. Plastic production has surged since the 1950s, leading to a crisis with billions of tonnes polluting the planet and contributing to climate change. The treaty may set production caps, recycling targets, and ban certain plastics and chemicals. However, oil-producing nations and industry lobbyists oppose these measures, favoring a focus on waste management over production reduction. The "High-Ambition Coalition" of 65 nations seeks to end plastic pollution by 2040, but faces challenges from major fossil fuel producers and the US's preference for voluntary action.

item.title: Harvey Weinstein’s rape conviction overturned: What the court argued, its implications
item.description: New York's highest court has overturned Harvey Weinstein's 2020 rape conviction and ordered a new trial, citing judicial errors in the landmark #MeToo case. The Court of Appeals found that the trial judge allowed testimony from witnesses whose allegations were not part of the charges, thus prejudicing the case. Weinstein was originally convicted for assaults in 2006 and 2013 and sentenced to 23 years. The reversal is based on the misuse of "Molineux witnesses," who testified about uncharged acts, violating Weinstein's rights to be tried solely for the charged crimes. Despite this, Weinstein remains imprisoned due to a separate 16-year sentence from a 2022 LA conviction for rape, which his lawyers plan to challenge. The decision marks a significant blow to the #MeToo movement, following a similar overturning of Bill Cosby's conviction. Appeals may now be directed to the Supreme Court.

item.title: Supreme Court VVPAT judgment: What has changed — and not changed?
item.description: The Supreme Court of India has dismissed requests for 100% verification of VVPAT slips with EVM counts, maintaining the current electoral process. The court has, however, mandated new post-election procedures for the Election Commission (EC). These include the storage of Symbol Loading Units (SLUs) for 45 days post-results for potential election petitions and allowing candidates to request verification of EVMs in 5% of machines per Assembly segment. Verification requests must be made within seven days of result declaration, with costs borne by the candidates, refundable if tampering is detected. Additionally, the court suggested the EC consider machine counting of VVPAT slips with barcodes for efficiency, though it refrained from a definitive stance on this technical suggestion.

item.title: Supreme Court rejects demand for 100% verification of VVPAT slips: What was the case about?
item.description: The Supreme Court of India, on April 26, upheld the current process of vote verification using Voter Verified Paper Audit Trails (VVPATs), rejecting demands for complete cross-verification with Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) and dismissing calls to revert to ballot papers. The verdict, delivered by Justices Sanjiv Khanna and Dipankar Datta, came after the Association for Democratic Reforms petitioned for enhanced transparency in elections through barcode-enabled VVPAT slips for faster tallying. The court suggested the Election Commission explore electronic counting of VVPAT slips. VVPATs, which provide a physical vote verification system, were fully adopted by June 2017. Currently, VVPAT slips from five randomly selected polling stations per assembly constituency are counted, a practice established by a 2019 Supreme Court judgment. Despite opposition parties advocating for increased verification to ensure election integrity, the Election Commission has cited logistical challenges and potential result delays as reasons for maintaining the status quo.

item.title: 50 yrs of portugal’s Carnation Revolution: How Europe’s longest dictatorship was overthrown
item.description: Portugal marked the 50th anniversary of the Carnation Revolution, which ended Europe's longest fascist rule and brought democracy. Antonio Oliveira Salazar's regime, which began in 1932, fell in 1974. Salazar, once Finance Minister, balanced Portugal's budget and stabilized its currency. As Prime Minister, he established the Estado Novo, a regime maintaining the Portuguese empire. The 1974 revolution, led by junior army officers, sought democracy and an end to colonial wars in Africa, leading to rapid decolonization. Today, the rise of the populist Chega party, which reveres Salazar's ideals, challenges this legacy. Chega, advocating "God, patriotism, family, and work," has grown significantly, reflecting on Portugal's current socio-economic issues.

item.title: Expert Explains: How a ‘new’ Japan promises to transform Asian geopolitics
item.description: Japan is undergoing a significant shift from its post-WWII pacifism to becoming a major military power. This change is driven by external pressures such as China's rise, North Korea's military capabilities, and uncertainties in US security commitments. Internally, conservatives in Tokyo advocate for Japan to assume more responsibility for its own security and contribute to regional order. Japan has increased its defense spending, acquired counter-strike capabilities, eased its weapons export ban, and is revising its defense command structure with the US. These moves signify Japan's transition from a US protectorate to an active partner in Indo-Pacific security, reshaping the regional security landscape and aligning with India's vision of a multipolar Asia.

item.title: How sending notice to party, not candidate, for poll code violations marks a shift in EC response
item.description: In a notable departure from past practices, the Election Commission (EC) has issued notices to political parties, specifically the BJP and Congress, for alleged Model Code of Conduct (MCC) violations by their star campaigners, including Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Rahul Gandhi. This shift emphasizes individual accountability and suggests that parties may be held responsible for their campaigners' actions. The move raises questions about the extent of action against individual leaders and the consequences for parties with unsatisfactory responses. The EC's approach aligns with a "calibrated approach" announced by Chief Election Commissioner Rajiv Kumar, targeting "repeat offenders" and legally linking campaigners' conduct to their parties, reminding them of their constitutional commitments. This change is underscored by the fact that no sitting Prime Minister has previously received an MCC violation notice.

item.title: Why a US court overturned Harvey Weinstein’s 2020 rape conviction
item.description: A New York appeals court has overturned Harvey Weinstein's 2020 sex crime conviction and ordered a new trial, citing serious errors in the previous trial, including the admission of invalid testimony. The Court of Appeals found that uncharged allegations had been erroneously admitted, which did not pertain to the complainants of the underlying crimes. Weinstein's lawyers argued that the trial was swayed by allowing testimonies from three women not involved in the case. While dissenting opinions criticized the decision for perpetuating outdated views on sexual violence, the majority ruled for a retrial. Weinstein, currently serving a 23-year sentence for separate convictions, will remain in prison despite the overturned New York ruling. The decision's impact on Weinstein is yet to be determined. The case has been a significant part of the #MeToo movement, following numerous allegations against Weinstein in 2017.

item.title: What is the Army Tactical Missile System, which the US has sent to Ukraine?
item.description: The U.S. has confirmed the provision of long-range ATACMS missiles to Ukraine, following President Zelenskyy's request and a $61 billion funding bill passed by Congress. These missiles, with a range of 300km, are an upgrade from previous systems with shorter ranges. They are launched from HIMARS and MLRS platforms, previously supplied by the U.S. and U.K. National Security Adviser Sullivan cited Russia's intensified attacks on civilian infrastructure as the reason for the timing of this delivery. The move comes amid concerns of escalation and reports of North Korea providing ballistic missiles to Russia. The ongoing Ukraine-Russia war has seen continued demands for aid from Ukraine, with U.S. President Biden supporting aid despite opposition from some Republican leaders. The article also briefly mentions AstraZeneca's admission of rare side effects from its Covid vaccine.

item.title: How American universities have long been hotbeds of protest
item.description: Protests have erupted across US college campuses in response to Israel's actions in Gaza, with significant police arrests at UT Austin and USC, and potential police action at Harvard and Brown. The movement, involving at least 30 universities, was sparked by NYPD's arrest of 108 Columbia University students demanding divestment from Israel-linked entities. This echoes the 1968 Columbia protests against Vietnam War policies and the influential 1960 Greensboro sit-ins, which contributed to the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Student activism has a long history in the US, from pre-Revolution protests to anti-apartheid and Black Lives Matter movements, often leading to significant institutional changes and reflecting broader societal issues.

item.title: Maratha quota case update: hearing paused till June, here’s what has happened so far
item.description: The Bombay High Court is set to resume hearings on June 13 regarding the 10% reservation for Marathas under Maharashtra's SEBC Act, 2024. This follows political upheaval and the significance of Maharashtra's 48 Lok Sabha seats in the upcoming elections. The court's decision will impact applications for education and government jobs under the Act. The Maratha community, constituting nearly a third of the state's population, has seen previous reservation laws fail. The current challenge argues the Act's unconstitutionality for exceeding the 50% reservation ceiling without constitutional amendment. The Shukre Commission's extensive survey supports the Marathas' backward status, but its findings and the Act's validity face scrutiny in court.

item.title: Microsoft unveils Phi-3-mini, its smallest AI model yet: How it compares to bigger models
item.description: Microsoft has introduced Phi-3-Mini, a new small language model (SLM), as part of its Phi-3 series. This model is designed to be more capable and cost-effective than larger language models (LLMs), performing well on benchmarks in language, reasoning, coding, and math. Phi-3-Mini, with a 3.8 billion parameter count, is available on platforms like Azure AI Studio and HuggingFace. It supports a context window of up to 128K tokens, enabling it to process large text content efficiently. The model is also instruction-tuned for immediate use. Microsoft plans to release more models in the Phi-3 family, including Phi-3-small and Phi-3-Medium. SLMs like Phi-3-Mini are ideal for resource-constrained environments and quick response scenarios, such as chatbots. They require less computing power and energy, making them suitable for smaller devices and organizations. Microsoft's Phi-3-Mini is said to outperform its predecessors and other models of similar or larger size.

item.title: Case before Supreme Court: Can Govt redistribute privately owned property?
item.description: The Supreme Court of India is revisiting the interpretation of Article 39(b) of the Constitution, which addresses the distribution of material resources to serve the common good. Historically, the apex court ruled that private property does not fall under "material resources of the community," but Justice Krishna Iyer's minority opinion, later supported by a five-judge bench, argued otherwise. This view was influential in nationalizing coal mines in 1983. Currently, the court is hearing a case on the Maharashtra Housing and Area Development Act's amendment, which allows the state to acquire 'cessed' properties in Mumbai for redistribution. The case challenges the constitutionality of this amendment, questioning if privately owned resources are included in "material resources of the community." A nine-judge bench is now deliberating on this matter.

item.title: Sam Pitroda controversy: How inheritance tax works
item.description: The article discusses the debate around inheritance tax in India, sparked by comments from Sam Pitroda and political reactions from the BJP and Congress. It outlines the history of wealth-related taxes in India, including the now-abolished estate duty, wealth tax, and gift tax. The piece also touches on global discussions about taxing the wealthy to address income inequality, with proposals like a global minimum corporate tax rate and a 'Billionaire Minimum Income Tax' in the US. It highlights the challenges of implementing such taxes, including capital flight and administrative costs, and notes the IMF's observation of declining wealth tax rates worldwide. The article concludes with the effectiveness of wealth taxes and the potential revenue from a global minimum tax on billionaires.

item.title: Census to kranti: How Rahul Gandhi framed quotas as wealth re-distribution tool
item.description: Rahul Gandhi's rhetoric on a caste census has evolved from a tool for social justice to a central goal, intertwining it with issues of inequality and wealth concentration. Despite internal dissent and BJP's criticism of threatening middle-class wealth, Gandhi remains unapologetic, advocating for an "X-ray" financial survey to inform revolutionary policies. Sam Pitroda's inheritance tax suggestion, contrasting with the Congress manifesto's tax stance, has sparked debate and confusion within the party. Gandhi insists on a caste census upon forming government, aiming for comprehensive socio-economic clarity. This stance marks a significant shift for Congress, aligning with socialist parties and challenging the Supreme Court's reservation cap, reflecting a broader strategy beyond electoral promises.

item.title: What is Art 244(A), the constitutional promise of autonomy driving the election narrative at a tribal seat in Assam?
item.description: In Assam's Diphu constituency, a long-standing election promise is the implementation of Article 244(A), which allows for an autonomous state within Assam. This provision, added in 1969, would enable the tribal-majority areas of Karbi Anglong, West Karbi Anglong, and Dima Hasao, currently under the Sixth Schedule, to have greater autonomy with their own legislature or council. Despite past peace accords and settlements promising enhanced autonomy and development packages, the actual implementation of Article 244(A) remains a central issue. Political parties continue to pledge its enactment, but progress post-elections is criticized as stagnant. The current focus is on the upcoming vote, with candidates reiterating commitments to autonomy, reflecting the region's complex history of autonomy demands and political negotiations.

item.title: Why has RBI barred Kotak Mahindra Bank from onboarding new customers via online, mobile channels?
item.description: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has imposed restrictions on Kotak Mahindra Bank, instructing it to halt the onboarding of new customers via online and mobile banking channels and to cease issuing new credit cards. This directive follows the RBI's IT examination for 2022 and 2023, which revealed significant deficiencies in the bank's IT management and compliance. The bank experienced frequent outages, highlighting a lack of operational resilience and inadequate IT infrastructure. Despite ongoing discussions with the RBI, the bank's rapid growth in digital transactions has further strained its systems. The RBI's decision aims to protect customer interests and ensure the stability of digital banking services. Kotak Mahindra Bank will continue serving existing customers and is taking steps to address the IT issues.

item.title: Why Centre filed an application to modify 2G spectrum scam judgement
item.description: The Indian government has sought to modify a 2012 Supreme Court ruling on the 2G spectrum allocation process. The original case involved the allocation of 2G licenses on a first-come-first-serve basis in 2008, which led to allegations of a massive scam and subsequent investigations. The Supreme Court canceled 122 licenses and mandated auctions for allocation to prevent misuse. The government now argues that auctions may not always be optimal, citing needs for spectrum in public interest functions and situations where auctions are not technically or economically viable. It seeks clarification on whether administrative allocation could be allowed in certain cases, referencing a 2012 court clarification that auctions are not a constitutional principle for all natural resources.

item.title: Road ahead for Tesla: Why EV sector is struggling, how Elon Musk hopes to negotiate potholes and speed bumps
item.description: Tesla Inc's shares rose over 10% after-hours despite a significant miss in revenue and earnings, marking the first decline in over four years with a 9% drop from the previous year. The company's operating profit and adjusted net income fell by more than 50% year-on-year, and future delivery volumes are projected to be notably lower. Tesla's inventory reached an all-time high of 28 days, and layoffs at its Texas factory numbered 2,600 due to low demand. Additionally, 4,000 Cybertrucks were recalled due to a faulty accelerator pedal. Surprisingly, the stock's rise post-earnings call was attributed to plans for more affordable vehicles, a potential Tesla robotaxi service, and a surge in software revenue from its full self-driving feature. Despite challenges, including competition from Chinese EV makers and the need to open its charging network, Tesla is pushing forward with new models, including a low-cost "Model 2" expected to launch by early 2025.

item.title: Lok Sabha elections 2024: What the BJP and Congress manifestos say on climate change
item.description: India's general elections are unfolding amidst a severe heatwave, with climate change being a critical but underrepresented issue in campaigns. Despite experiencing climate-induced disasters, political parties have not prioritized it in their electioneering. However, both the BJP and Congress have included climate agendas in their manifestos. The BJP aims to continue its current policies, expand renewable energy to 500 GW by 2030, and promote a green credit system. It also plans to launch river health programs and a National Atmospheric Mission. Conversely, Congress proposes an independent authority to enforce environmental standards and a National Climate Resilience Development Mission, alongside funds for green transitions and infrastructure. Both parties commit to expanding forest cover, protecting ecosystems, and reducing pollution.

item.title: US Senate passes Bill that may ban TikTok: What can be the implications?
item.description: The U.S. Senate has passed a bill that could mandate the sale of TikTok by its Chinese owner, Bytedance, or lead to its outright ban, reflecting ongoing U.S.-China tensions. The bill, which addresses national security concerns over TikTok's Chinese connections, suggests that Bytedance must divest TikTok within nine months for it to continue operating in the U.S. President Biden is expected to sign the bill into law, potentially triggering legal challenges and retaliatory actions from Beijing. Critics argue the bill infringes on free speech, with TikTok claiming it would harm American users and businesses. Previously, the Trump administration attempted to force TikTok's sale to a U.S. company, with Microsoft notably entering negotiations. The broader context includes tech bans as foreign policy tools, with countries targeting Chinese tech firms like Huawei in response to strained relations, leading to reciprocal actions and the development of independent tech capabilities.

item.title: Reservation for Muslims: Andhra Pradesh case and issues before the court
item.description: In a speech, Prime Minister Narendra Modi accused Congress of attempting to provide a 5% reservation for Muslims in Andhra Pradesh, which he claimed was part of a larger plan to implement across India. The article discusses the legal challenges and changes to Muslim reservation in various states. In Andhra Pradesh, attempts to include all Muslims in the OBC category were struck down by the High Court for not excluding the "creamy layer" and lacking objective criteria. Despite the High Court's affirmation that Muslim reservations do not conflict with secularism, subsequent attempts to establish a 5% Muslim quota were invalidated. The Supreme Court is yet to hear the final appeal, following its decision on the Economically Weaker Section quota. The article also briefly mentions AstraZeneca's admission of rare side effects from its Covid vaccine.

item.title: After wars, deaths, political turmoil, how the 1967 Lok Sabha elections saw the Indira Gandhi era begin
item.description: The period between India's third and fourth Lok Sabha elections (1962-1967) was marked by significant political upheaval. The nation faced a defeat by China and the deaths of Prime Ministers Nehru and Shastri. Indira Gandhi succeeded as Prime Minister, leading Congress to victory in the 1967 elections, which saw the end of simultaneous Lok Sabha and state Assembly elections. The elections expanded to 520 Lok Sabha seats and over 3,500 state Assembly seats, reflecting changes like new states and Union Territories. Despite internal challenges and the rise of opposition parties, Congress maintained a vote share above 40%, although it faced setbacks with non-Congress governments forming in several states. The era post-1967 ushered in a political dominance by Indira Gandhi, reshaping India's political landscape.

item.title: How much wealth do Indian Muslims have? Here’s what a study says
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi's allegation that the Congress plans to redistribute gold to Muslims has been refuted as "lies" and "hate speech" by the Congress. A 2020 study by the Indian Institute of Dalit Studies reveals disparities in wealth ownership among different social groups in India. Hindu high castes hold about 41% of the nation's wealth, with Hindu OBCs at 31%, and Muslims, SCs, and STs owning smaller percentages. The wealth distribution is disproportionate to the population share of these groups. The study also highlights the variations in average household wealth, with Hindu high castes at the top. Additionally, Hindu OBCs possess the largest share of gold among social groups.

item.title: How US colleges are witnessing protests over the Israel-Palestine conflict
item.description: U.S. colleges are embroiled in debates over student protests linked to the Israel-Hamas conflict. Arrests have been made at Columbia, NYU, and Yale, with students facing charges for their involvement. The protests were sparked by a Hamas attack on Israel and subsequent Israeli military action, which resulted in significant casualties. Tensions on campuses stem from differing views on the Middle East, with some student groups blaming Israel for the violence and others decrying perceived antisemitism in anti-Israel protests. Universities face a dilemma in balancing free speech with maintaining support from benefactors. High-profile resignations and cancelled speeches have occurred amidst congressional testimonies on antisemitism in colleges. The situation reflects the historical role of U.S. campuses as sites of political activism and debate.

item.title: The story of Doordarshan’s iconic logo, now in controversy over its colour
item.description: Doordarshan (DD), India's public broadcaster, recently changed its logo color from ruby red to saffron, sparking criticism from opposition parties amid elections. They linked the new color to the ruling party, BJP. DD defended the change as a visual update, noting that saffron was part of its logo when it transitioned to color broadcasting in the 1980s. The article traces DD's history from its black and white transmission days in 1959, highlighting the iconic 'DD Eye' logo and the signature tune composed by Pandit Ravi Shankar and Ustad Ali Ahmed Hussain Khan. The 'Eye' logo, designed by Devashis Bhattacharyya, symbolized yin and yang and evolved over the decades, with students from the National Institute of Design (NID) contributing to its revamp. The article also briefly mentions the journalist's background and unrelated content about HPBOSE class 12 results.

item.title: New World Meteorological Organisation report released: 5 charts that tell the status of climate crisis in Asia
item.description: The World Meteorological Organisation's 2023 report highlights Asia's accelerated warming, with the region experiencing more extreme weather and water-related events than any other. In 2023, 79 hydrometeorological events impacted over nine million people and caused over 2,000 deaths. The majority were floods and storms, exacerbated by Asia's surface temperature rising 1.87°C above the 1961–1990 average. Glaciers in High Mountain Asia are losing mass due to high temperatures and dry conditions, with significant losses over the past 40 years. Precipitation patterns have shifted, with areas like Turkmenistan, Pakistan, and Myanmar experiencing below-normal rainfall, while others received excess. Sea surface temperatures in Asia have also reached record highs, particularly in the North-west Pacific Ocean, with warming rates in some areas more than triple the global average.

item.title: What is the UK govt’s recent Bill, which could lead to some migrants being deported to Rwanda?
item.description: The UK's upper house passed the Safety of Rwanda Bill, affirming Rwanda as a safe country for deporting undocumented immigrants, despite the Supreme Court's previous ruling against such policies due to human rights concerns. This move follows a treaty signed with Rwanda to enhance migrant protections. The contentious plan, initiated by former PM Boris Johnson, involves flying migrants 6,400 km to Rwanda for resettlement assessments. The UK has already paid Rwanda £290 million, with an additional £50 million pending the Bill's passage. The UNHCR criticizes the policy, and the ECHR halted initial deportations. With upcoming elections, immigration remains a hot-button issue, and PM Rishi Sunak asserts that flights to Rwanda will commence within 10-12 weeks, notwithstanding potential legal challenges.

item.title: Dawoodi Bohra leader wins legal battle: Who challenged Syedna Mufaddal Saifuddin’s position as 53rd Dai, and why?
item.description: The Bombay High Court dismissed a decade-long challenge to the leadership of Syedna Mufaddal Saifuddin, head of the Dawoodi Bohra community. The dispute arose after the 52nd al-Dai al-Mutlaq, Syedna Mohammad Burhanuddin, passed away in 2014, and his son, Saifuddin, succeeded him. This succession was contested by Burhanuddin's half-brother, Khuzaima Qutbuddin, who claimed he had been secretly appointed as the successor in 1965. Qutbuddin's son, Taher Fakhruddin, continued the legal battle after his father's death in 2016. The court ruled on evidence, not faith, noting that the nass (succession) could be changed and revoked, supporting Saifuddin's claim, which was backed by witnesses and documents from 1969 and reaffirmed in 2011. The case's length was attributed to extensive evidence and disruptions caused by the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: How the rupee has ‘strengthened’ under Modi government
item.description: The Indian rupee has depreciated by 27.6% against the US dollar from 2014 to 2024, a slightly higher rate than during the previous decade. The article explains that the rupee's value is not only determined by its exchange rate with the dollar but also by its Effective Exchange Rate (EER) with a basket of currencies from major trading partners. The Nominal EER (NEER) shows the rupee depreciated 32.2-40.2% against this basket over the last 20 years, less than its 45.7% fall against the dollar. The Real EER (REER), adjusted for inflation, indicates the rupee has strengthened in real terms, suggesting an overvaluation that could affect India's trade competitiveness. The article highlights the complexity of currency valuation and its impact on the economy.

item.title: Explained: What do countries and companies want in global plastic treaty talks?
item.description: Global leaders are convening in Ottawa to draft a landmark treaty aimed at curbing plastic pollution, potentially rivaling the 2015 Paris Agreement in environmental significance. The treaty seeks to manage plastics' entire lifecycle, addressing the industry's contribution to carbon emissions—currently 5% and potentially rising to 20% by 2050. Divisions exist among nations and interest groups on the treaty's scope, with some advocating for production limits and others opposing such measures. The "High-Ambition Coalition," including the EU and Japan, aims to eliminate plastic pollution by 2040, proposing legally binding reductions in plastic production. In contrast, the U.S. favors individual national plans. Industry groups argue against production caps, fearing consumer cost impacts, and prefer focusing on recycling and reuse. Consumer brands support the treaty, including production limits and comprehensive waste management strategies. Final negotiations are scheduled for December in Busan, South Korea.

item.title: Why High Court upheld Karnataka’s ban on hookah
item.description: The Karnataka High Court has affirmed the state's ban on hookah bars, ruling them as an illegal service under anti-tobacco laws. The decision is based on Article 47 of the Constitution, which mandates the state to improve public health and allows for the prohibition of harmful substances. The court found that hookah smoking involves services similar to serving food or alcohol, which distinguishes it from cigarette smoking in designated zones. Consequently, the ban extends to all forms of hookah, including herbal varieties, as they require an instrument and thus constitute a service. This ruling aligns with the directive principles of state policy aimed at protecting citizens' health under Article 21.

item.title: No age restriction for health insurance now: All you need to know
item.description: In a significant move, the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India (IRDAI) has mandated insurance companies to offer health insurance to all individuals, including senior citizens, irrespective of their age or pre-existing medical conditions. This directive aligns with the government's commitment to include those over 70 in the Ayushman Bharat scheme. Insurers are now encouraged to design inclusive products that provide comprehensive coverage for various groups, particularly the elderly. The change aims to improve healthcare access and affordability for seniors, addressing the challenges they face with high premiums and limited coverage due to age-related risks. The IRDAI's guidelines also emphasize the importance of continuous coverage, prohibiting insurers from refusing renewal based on previous claims and advocating for fair premium adjustments. This reform is expected to foster innovation in the insurance market, benefiting the aging population and contributing to the broader goal of universal healthcare by 2030.

item.title: Why the US may sanction Netzah Yehuda, an Israeli Defence Forces battalion
item.description: The U.S. is considering sanctions against an IDF battalion over alleged human rights abuses, a first in U.S.-Israel relations. The Axios report suggests the sanctions would prevent U.S. military aid to the battalion, with Secretary Blinken indicating a decision is imminent. Israeli President Netanyahu has publicly opposed such sanctions, especially as IDF soldiers combat terrorism. The allegations stem from incidents in the West Bank, including the death of Omar Assad, a U.S.-Palestinian citizen, after IDF detention. The IDF admitted to moral failure but denied violence, despite claims of mistreatment. The Netzah Yehuda battalion, accommodating ultra-Orthodox Jewish soldiers, has faced past indictments for abuse. The potential sanctions, under the Leahy Laws, coincide with Israel's Gaza offensive and U.S. political tensions, as Biden balances support for Israel with domestic and international criticism. Congress recently voted to support Israel with $26 billion, reflecting this delicate balance.

item.title: Do Muslims have more children than others? Here’s what available data show
item.description: At an election rally, Prime Minister Narendra Modi criticized the Congress party for allegedly favoring "infiltrators" and those with larger families, hinting at the Muslim community. The article highlights the lack of recent census data on religious demographics in India. It notes that the Muslim population grew by 24.69% from 2001 to 2011, marking the slowest growth in the community's history. Additionally, it points out that Muslims have the lowest labor force and worker population ratios among all religious groups, although their unemployment rate is below the national average. The article concludes with a mention of the Indian cricket team's selection process for the T20 World Cup, focusing on the inclusion of players Sanju Samson and Shubman Gill, and the potential exclusion of KL Rahul.

item.title: Warming up to climate change: Why does sea level rise matter?
item.description: A study published in Science warns that a quarter of China's coastal land could be underwater within a century due to land subsidence and climate change, threatening millions. This issue extends globally, potentially impacting up to half a billion people. Sea levels have risen 21-24 centimeters since 1880, with the rate doubling since 1993. The acceleration could add another 20 centimeters by 2050, increasing flood risks worldwide. Global warming, causing glacier melt and thermal expansion of seawater, is the primary cause. Coastal cities in India and island nations like Indonesia face significant threats, with Indonesia relocating its capital due to flood risks. Rising sea levels also intensify storm surges and contaminate freshwater sources.

item.title: SC allows abortion of 30-week foetus: What is the law on abortions, and what does the court consider?
item.description: The Supreme Court of India has permitted a 14-year-old sexual assault victim to terminate her nearly 30-week pregnancy, emphasizing the need to protect her physical and mental well-being. The Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 1971, generally allows abortions up to 20 weeks, with exceptions up to 24 weeks under specific conditions. Beyond this, a medical board's approval is required. The court has occasionally allowed terminations past this period, considering the woman's rights and foetal viability. Recent cases highlight the liberal interpretation of the MTP Act and the evolving legal stance on reproductive rights, prioritizing women's autonomy over the rights of the unborn, marking a shift from traditional benchmarks and pointing to legislative gaps in India's abortion laws. This summary reflects the article's focus on the legal aspects of abortion in India without including unrelated content.

item.title: New shoe sizing system proposed for Indians: What is ‘Bha’ and the need for it?
item.description: A comprehensive survey across India has led to the development of 'Bha', a new Indian footwear sizing system, set to replace UK/European and US sizes. The study, covering over 100,000 participants, revealed that Indians generally have wider feet, necessitating a size larger than ideal in existing systems. This mismatch has caused discomfort and health issues, particularly among women and diabetics. The proposed Bha system, based on extensive 3D foot scanning, suggests eight size categories, simplifying manufacturing and potentially fitting 85% of the population correctly. The Council of Scientific and Industrial Research–Central Leather Research Institute (CSIR–CLRI) has recommended Bha to the Bureau of Indian Standards for approval, with implementation expected by 2025. This change aims to enhance comfort and reduce returns, especially from online sales, benefiting both consumers and manufacturers in one of the world's largest footwear markets.

item.title: What is the significance of Earth Day?
item.description: Celebrated globally on April 22, Earth Day 2024 marks its 54th anniversary, emphasizing environmental protection. UN Secretary-General António Guterres urged unity and action for climate change on this day. Originating in 1970 with 20 million protesters, Earth Day catalyzed environmental activism, leading to significant milestones like the Paris Agreement. The day underscores our collective duty to balance economic, social, and environmental needs for current and future generations. The 2024 theme, 'Planet vs. Plastics,' addresses the plastic crisis, advocating for a 60% reduction in plastic production by 2040 to mitigate its toxic impact on human health and the environment. Earth Day continues to be a pivotal platform for raising awareness and driving substantial environmental change.

item.title: This Quote Means: ‘If you want to test a man’s character, give him power’
item.description: The article explores the concept of power, its ethical implications, and its portrayal in popular culture. It references quotes like "With great power comes great responsibility" and delves into the true test of character when one is endowed with power. Originally attributed to Abraham Lincoln, the quote under scrutiny is likely from Robert G. Ingersoll, emphasizing that power reveals true character, especially in prosperity. The article discusses power's various interpretations, from a tool for social change to a means of coercion. It highlights Hannah Arendt's view of power as legitimate collective action and contrasts it with Marxist perspectives on power as class dominance. The piece concludes by questioning whether power is the ultimate measure of character, suggesting that adversity can also reveal a person's true nature.

item.title: Whether copyright can be claimed over maths and science textbooks: What Andhra Pradesh HC held
item.description: The Andhra Pradesh High Court ruled that textbooks on mathematical equations and science are not subject to copyright as they are non-literary. This decision came after Deepthi Publications, a Guntur-based publisher, challenged a 2010 government order preventing private schools and colleges from self-publishing to combat piracy. The court quashed a criminal case against the publisher, stating that their books, which are based on CBSE and ICSE syllabi and aid in competitive exam preparation, fall under the fair use doctrine. The court emphasized that educational materials used for instruction are exempt from copyright infringement, and originality is required for copyright to exist. However, the court did not quash the government order, acknowledging its intent to protect against piracy and safeguard students' futures.

item.title: Why some student visa hopefuls are attempting to go to Canada on visitor visas
item.description: In response to Canada's cap on international students, many Indian students are considering entering Canada on visitor visas and then applying for study permits. This trend follows the introduction of stringent requirements for study visas, including mandatory attestation letters from the student's intended province or territory, which has led to delays and increased competition for study permits. Some educational consultants are misleading students by suggesting this indirect route, despite it being legal. However, experts advise applying directly for study visas, as the process is becoming more streamlined. They warn that the visitor visa route is complex, costly, and subject to the same cap on international students. It's recommended that students apply for study visas to avoid complications and potential legal issues.

item.title: Explained: The legislations that BJP, Congress, DMK and others have promised in manifestos
item.description: The Lok Sabha elections have prompted various political parties to outline their legislative and judicial reform agendas in their manifestos. The BJP focuses on significant new laws, building on policies from the past decade. The Congress proposes the broadest range of new laws, targeting diverse areas. The CPI(M) aims to repeal laws it deems oppressive, enhance legal protections for minorities, and legislate for socio-economic equality. The DMK, with a history of pre-election manifestos, promises specific legislative and judicial changes. The TMC, led by Mamata Banerjee, pledges to serve "Maa, Mati, Manush" and bring transformative change to West Bengal and the nation. These manifestos reflect each party's vision for India's future legislative and judicial landscape.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war: Have tanks become obsolete in modern warfare?
item.description: The Russia-Ukraine conflict has highlighted the vulnerability of tanks in modern warfare. Despite Russia destroying five and damaging three of the 31 M1 Abrams tanks sent by the US to Ukraine, and Ukraine losing 796 tanks since 2022, both countries continue to use and produce them. Drones, particularly FPV drones, have become a cost-effective method to target tanks' weak points. Ukraine's failure to fully protect its tanks from such attacks is one reason for its heavy losses. Tanks, however, still offer significant firepower, mobility, and psychological impact. History has shown their value in warfare, and with adequate infantry support and armor upgrades, tanks can be indispensable in urban combat. The narrative underscores the enduring relevance of tanks despite advancements in anti-tank weaponry.

item.title: Attack and retaliation, anger and restraint: Connecting the dots in the Iran-Israel hostility
item.description: On April 19, coinciding with Ayatollah Khamenei's 85th birthday, Israel launched a strike on Iran, targeting a military base near Isfahan. This action was in retaliation for Iran's April 13 drone and missile attack, which was a response to an earlier Israeli strike in Syria. The IAEA confirmed no nuclear facilities were damaged. Both nations have since maintained a silence, signaling a mutual desire to avoid escalation. The US was informed prior to the strike, suggesting coordination. Iran remains on alert, with President Raisi warning of a harsh response to any further invasions. Meanwhile, India has urged restraint from both sides, emphasizing diplomacy without issuing a formal reaction to the strike. The situation remains tense, with global implications hinging on the next moves by Israel and Iran.

item.title: Influencing Severus Snape to SRK, why Lord Byron still captures our imagination
item.description: The article reflects on the enduring influence of Lord Byron, 200 years after his death, highlighting the cultural impact of the Byronic hero archetype. This character type, known for its rebellious charm and brooding intensity, often exhibits heroic qualities alongside self-destructive tendencies. The Byronic hero has permeated pop culture, with examples ranging from Erik in "The Phantom of the Opera" to Severus Snape in the "Harry Potter" series. The archetype has also been prominent in Bollywood, influencing roles played by Amitabh Bachchan and Shah Rukh Khan. The article discusses the public's fascination with these complex characters, suggesting they offer an escape from societal constraints and allow for self-exploration. It also touches on the emergence of Byronic heroines, challenging traditional female characterizations and reflecting a shift towards more nuanced portrayals of women. The piece concludes by asserting the lasting appeal of Byronic characters, who captivate audiences with their depth and complexity.

item.title: What is Llama 3, Meta’s most sophisticated and capable large language model yet?
item.description: Meta has unveiled its latest AI, Llama 3, and an image generator, aiming to integrate these into its virtual assistant across platforms like Facebook and WhatsApp. Llama 3, an advanced Large Language Model (LLM), comes in two sizes with up to 70 billion parameters, outperforming its predecessor and rivals like Google's models in benchmarks. It supports longer interactions with 8,000 token contexts and includes safety tools like Llama Guard 2. Meta plans to enhance Llama 3's multilingual and multimodal capabilities, and it's already available for developers through various platforms. The AI is currently accessible in English in the US and will expand globally. Meta's move positions it as a leader in sophisticated AI technology.

item.title: Punjabiyat: How Punjab can be bridge for national reconciliation between India and Pakistan
item.description: Maryam Nawaz Sharif, Chief Minister of Pakistan's Punjab, emphasized her Punjabi roots while advocating for improved Indo-Pak relations at Gurdwara Kartarpur Sahib. She echoed her father's sentiment to foster friendship, not conflict, with neighbors. The concept of 'Punjabiyat'—a shared Punjabi identity—has been a recurring theme to bridge bilateral ties. Despite the division of Punjab in 1947 and subsequent wars, cultural bonds persist, marked by a common culture, empathy, and efforts to heal Partition's wounds. Cultural exchanges in films and music, and political initiatives like paradiplomacy, have sought to strengthen these ties. The Attari-Wagah land route, once a symbol of potential trade growth, remains a point of contention and hope for future reconciliation and mutual prosperity.

item.title: How Jawaharlal Nehru won a third term in the 1962 elections, despite growing challenges
item.description: The 1962 Indian general elections marked a significant evolution in the country's electoral process, with the Election Commission refining its procedures and recording the highest voter turnout to date. Despite Prime Minister Nehru's successful liberation of Goa and other territories from Portuguese rule, the Congress party faced its first substantial political criticism. The elections introduced key changes, including the abolition of two-member constituencies and the realignment of administrative boundaries due to the creation of new states and union territories. The Congress party emerged victorious, winning 361 Lok Sabha seats, while the opposition parties, despite their efforts, could not make a significant impact. The election also continued the practice of marking voters with indelible ink, although the experiment with photo identity cards was discontinued. Amidst the political shifts, Nehru began his third term as Prime Minister, confronting challenges such as linguistic nationalism, social unrest, and the aftermath of the Chinese invasion. His tenure, however, ended with his death in 1964, marking the longest prime ministerial term in India's history.

item.title: Elon Musk set to arrive: potential win-win for Tesla and India, some challenges too
item.description: Elon Musk's visit to India signals a potential $2 billion investment in a Tesla car manufacturing facility, aligning with the government's EV policy to import 8,000 electric cars at reduced duties. This move could mark a significant moment for India's auto sector, similar to Apple's impact on cell phone assembly. Musk will also discuss Starlink and his social media platform, avoiding controversies during the election period. The visit focuses on Tesla's influence on India's EV ecosystem and its potential as an export hub. Despite challenges like a small luxury car market and infrastructure needs, the new policy aims to attract global EV manufacturers and provide Indian consumers with advanced technology, supporting the 'Make in India' initiative. However, Tesla faces competition from local players and must navigate India's unique market conditions.

item.title: Indian BrahMos missiles delivered to the Philippines: The missile’s significance
item.description: India delivered BrahMos supersonic cruise missiles to the Philippines, marking a significant step in becoming an arms exporter. The $375 million deal, signed in 2022, was highlighted by Prime Minister Narendra Modi as part of India's growing defense exports, totaling Rs 21,000 crore this year. The BrahMos missile, developed by BrahMos Aerospace—a joint venture between India's DRDO and Russia's NPOM—stands out for its speed, range, and precision. It's a two-stage missile capable of reaching supersonic speeds and performing complex maneuvers. The missile's versatility and stealth capabilities make it a strategic asset in defense and a symbol of India's advanced military technology. Ongoing upgrades aim to enhance its range and maneuverability, with tests being conducted across all Indian Armed Forces branches. The BrahMos has also been integrated into various platforms, including land-based systems, warships, fighter jets, and submarines, demonstrating India's commitment to advancing its missile technology and defense capabilities.

item.title: Is the EU’s image failing in Southeast Asia?
item.description: A survey by the ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute indicates a decline in Southeast Asia's trust in the EU's commitment to free trade and the rules-based order. Trust in the EU as a global free trade leader fell to less than 14%, and its role in upholding international law dropped to third place. Confidence in the EU's contribution to global peace and governance also decreased, with only 41% of respondents believing the EU would "do the right thing," partly due to perceptions of the EU being preoccupied with internal affairs. The EU's stance on the Israel-Hamas conflict and deforestation legislation has affected its popularity, particularly with Malaysia and Indonesia. Despite these challenges, the EU maintains a strong partnership with ASEAN, being its fourth most important dialogue partner. The survey's findings suggest the EU needs to enhance cooperation and engagement to improve its image and partnership in Southeast Asia.

item.title: The story of indelible ink, a lasting symbol of Indian elections, and who makes it
item.description: The indelible ink, a symbol of Indian elections, is being produced by Mysore Paints & Varnish Ltd. for the 2024 Lok Sabha elections, with around 26.5 lakh phials prepared. This ink, containing silver nitrate, has been used for decades to prevent multiple voting and is applied on voters' fingers at polling booths. Initially marked with a glass rod, the ink's application has evolved, but its purpose remains integral to the electoral process. The ink's formula, a closely guarded secret, ensures its resistance to various cleaning agents for up to 72 hours. Manufactured since 1962, the ink is now exported to over 25 countries, with diverse application methods tailored to different electoral systems.

item.title: Fourth global mass coral bleaching triggered: What are corals and why are they important?
item.description: The fourth global mass coral bleaching event, driven by record ocean temperatures, has been announced by NOAA. This event poses a threat to marine life and the livelihoods of millions dependent on reefs. The rise in sea surface temperature to 21.07°C in March 2023 is attributed to increased greenhouse gas emissions, with oceans absorbing 90% of this excess heat. Coral reefs, vital for marine ecosystems and human economies, are suffering as a result. Corals, particularly hard corals that build reefs, are experiencing bleaching due to stress from environmental changes. While not immediately fatal, bleaching impacts coral reproduction and increases disease vulnerability. The current bleaching event, exacerbated by El Niño, has affected over 54% of global coral areas. Scientists warn that such events may become more frequent and severe, threatening the majority of coral reefs with even a 1.5°C rise in global temperatures. Efforts to limit warming to 1.5°C by reducing greenhouse gas emissions are critical but remain challenging.

item.title: Maldives ex-President Yameen acquitted
item.description: The Maldives High Court has overturned the 11-year sentence of former president Abdulla Yameen on graft and money laundering charges, ordering a retrial due to an unfair trial. Yameen's involvement in the MMPRC scandal, where over USD 90 million was embezzled, led to his initial conviction. Despite his release after a Supreme Court appeal, he was re-sentenced in 2022. His convictions barred him from the 2023 presidential race, which his party won with an anti-India campaign. Upcoming parliamentary elections will test the new government's policies amidst geopolitical tensions and domestic challenges.

item.title: Canadian visa delays: How students can improve chances of approval in September
item.description: Canadian student visa processing has been delayed since January due to policy changes, including a cap on international students and the new requirement of attestation letters from provinces/territories. Students unable to secure visas for the May intake are now aiming for September. To improve visa chances, students must ensure their program isn't banned and may use the Web Form or CAIPS for application updates. Reapplication is a last resort due to additional costs. Experts advise careful application review for an enhanced success rate, and colleges are expected to streamline attestation issuance soon. Unrelated content regarding AstraZeneca's vaccine side effects was omitted from this summary.

item.title: As Aamir Khan’s fake video on Congress goes viral, how to spot disinformation amid elections
item.description: As India approaches the Lok Sabha elections, manipulated media and deepfake videos have surged online. Two viral videos of Aamir Khan, altered to show him endorsing political views, and a deepfake of Ranveer Singh criticizing the Prime Minister, highlight the issue. These deepfakes often use 'voice swap' technology, which can alter voice characteristics to create realistic fakes. Despite the challenge of detecting sophisticated deepfakes, the public is advised to verify sources, listen for audio anomalies, scrutinize visual inconsistencies, stay informed, and use AI detection tools like Optic's 'AI or Not' to assess content authenticity. Awareness and vigilance are crucial, especially during sensitive times like elections.

item.title: Nestlé’s baby food sold in Asian, African countries had added sugars: Why is sugar harmful?
item.description: A report by Public Eye and IBFAN found that Nestlé's baby food products in Asia, Africa, and Latin America contain added sugars, unlike their European counterparts. Cerelac, a leading brand, has nearly 3 grams of added sugar per serving in India. Nestlé India claims to have reduced added sugars by up to 30% in the past five years. The report criticizes Nestlé for inconsistent nutritional standards and unclear sugar content labeling. It highlights the risks of added sugars, which can lead to health issues like diabetes and obesity. The WHO recommends limiting free sugar intake, and experts warn against adding sugars to baby foods due to its addictive nature and the risk of nutrition-based disorders. The study underscores the growing exposure to added sugars in low- and middle-income countries, driven by global food brands. WHO advises against added sugars before age 2, and a UNICEF-supported study found high sugar levels in many baby foods in Southeast Asia.

item.title: Cost and benefit: Israel’s very expensive defence against aerial threats
item.description: Israel's recent interception of Iranian missiles and drones, which saw 99% of over 300 projectiles neutralized, was a strategic success but came at a steep economic cost. The defense involved costly systems like the Iron Dome and Arrow interceptors, with each interception missile costing up to $100,000. The financial toll for Israel exceeded $550 million in one night, while Iran's expenses were significantly lower, at $100-$200 million for the attack. The disparity in costs highlights a strategic challenge for Israel, as Iran possesses a large arsenal capable of multiple attacks. This economic strain is prompting a shift towards more cost-effective defense technologies, such as microwave and laser beams, which promise cheaper and potentially unlimited defense capabilities.

item.title: ED attaches properties of Shilpa Shetty’s husband: What is the alleged Rs 6,606 cr Bitcoin fraud?
item.description: The Enforcement Directorate (ED) has attached properties worth Rs 97.79 crore of businessman Raj Kundra under the PMLA, linked to a Bitcoin investment fraud case. The properties include a flat in Mumbai, a bungalow in Pune, and shares, all connected to Kundra and his wife, actor Shilpa Shetty. The case involves a Ponzi scheme started by Amit Bhardwaj and others in 2017, deceiving investors with promises of high returns from Bitcoin mining. Multiple FIRs led to the ED's money laundering probe. Kundra allegedly received 285 Bitcoins from Bhardwaj, which he retained after a failed deal to set up a mining farm in Ukraine. These Bitcoins are now valued at over Rs 150 crore. Kundra, previously arrested in a pornography case, was first questioned by the ED in 2018 and made a biopic about his jail experience in 2023.

item.title: Did the comments of India’s envoy to Ireland breach IFS service rules?
item.description: The Indian Ambassador to Ireland, Akhilesh Mishra, is under scrutiny for potentially breaching service rules after his public rebuttal to an Irish Times editorial. The editorial criticized India's democratic integrity under PM Narendra Modi, to which Mishra responded, calling the views "biased and prejudiced" and indirectly attacking the previous Congress regime. His comments have sparked demands from the opposition for his dismissal, citing a breach of the expected political neutrality enshrined in the Central Civil Services (Conduct) Rules. While some officials view his remarks as distasteful, they may not constitute an actionable breach. The incident has reignited discussions on the apolitical conduct expected from civil servants, referencing past controversies and reforms aimed at maintaining civil service integrity and discipline.

item.title: Where India’s trade with Israel and Iran stands, and whether regional tensions could impact it
item.description: Tensions rise in the Middle East after Iran's attack on Israel, raising concerns for India due to its friendly ties with both nations. India's trade with Israel has flourished since 1992, reaching $10.7 billion in 2022-23. Meanwhile, trade with Iran, despite fluctuations, stood at $2.33 billion in the same period. India's exports to Israel include diesel and diamonds, while it imports space equipment and potassium chloride. Investment ties with Israel and Iran show Indian firms investing more in Israel than vice versa. Though the conflict's impact on petroleum prices is uncertain, shipping disruptions in the Red Sea could affect global trade routes.

item.title: How Uttar Pradesh’s anti-conversion law governs religious conversion
item.description: The Allahabad High Court upheld an FIR against a Muslim man in an interfaith live-in relationship, citing Uttar Pradesh’s anti-conversion law. The law prohibits conversions through coercion or fraudulent means, including conversion through relationships like marriage. Punishments range from 1-5 years imprisonment to 3-10 years for mass conversions. It also declares marriages for unlawful conversion void and requires a stringent process for valid conversion, including declarations to the District Magistrate. Challenges to the law's constitutionality are pending before the Supreme Court. Meanwhile, cases against the law have been filed in Allahabad HC. AstraZeneca's admission of rare side effects from its COVID vaccine may lead to legal payouts.

item.title: Experts Explain: Last 72 hours most crucial during elections, here’s what happens behind the scenes
item.description: The article outlines the meticulous preparations and activities involved in the Lok Sabha election process, focusing on key phases like campaigning, election silence, and polling. It highlights logistical arrangements, enforcement of election laws, and measures to ensure fair conduct. Various teams like Flying Squads and Static Surveillance Teams are deployed to prevent malpractices. The importance of adherence to the Model Code of Conduct is emphasized, along with efforts to educate voters and ensure polling station facilities. Strict regulations govern the silent period before polling, with restrictions on campaigning and public gatherings. The article also covers polling day procedures, including the role of polling officials and post-polling security measures for EVMs.

item.title: ‘Voluntary Code of Ethics’ for social media platforms: What EC told X on taking down elections-related posts
item.description: X (formerly Twitter) has complied with the Election Commission of India's request to withhold four posts during the Lok Sabha elections, despite disagreeing with the orders. The EC cited violations of the Model Code of Conduct (MCC) and the Voluntary Code of Ethics for social media platforms. The MCC, in effect since March 16, prohibits unverified allegations and criticism of private lives of political parties and candidates. Established after the 2019 Lok Sabha elections, the Voluntary Code of Ethics mandates social media platforms to facilitate grievance redressal and promptly act on EC's orders. X, while complying, advocates for freedom of expression and urges the EC to publicize future takedown orders.

item.title: Why has Sonam Wangchuk suspended Ladakh’s Pashmina March again?
item.description: Climate activist Sonam Wangchuk has suspended Ladakh's "Pashmina March" after initially planning it to raise awareness about grazing pasture loss. Wangchuk, known for his environmental activism, recently undertook a 21-day protest fast demanding Ladakh's inclusion in the Sixth Schedule of the Constitution. He highlights the loss of land to corporations and Chinese activities along the Line of Actual Control as reasons for the pasture loss. Wangchuk's activism reflects broader concerns in Ladakh, including dissatisfaction with the region's new administrative setup following its separation from Jammu and Kashmir. Despite attempts to engage with authorities, negotiations have been inconclusive, leading to Wangchuk's continued activism and protests.

item.title: How a beam of sunlight was directed on Lord Ram’s forehead in Ayodhya temple
item.description: A Surya Tilak ceremony was performed at the newly-built Ram temple in Ayodhya on Ram Navami, projecting sunlight onto Lord Ram’s idol's forehead. Astronomers from the Indian Institute of Astrophysics designed a mirror-lens system to achieve this. They calculated the Sun’s position annually, directing beams through mirrors and lenses to focus on the idol. A 19-gear system adjusts the setup yearly based on the Metonic cycle. Due to temple construction, a modified version was used initially. Precision is crucial, with concern for cleanliness to prevent soot and dust accumulation. The final installation awaits temple completion.

item.title: What is the dress code for advocates and when can it be relaxed?
item.description: The Karnataka High Court has exempted advocates at District and Trial courts from wearing black coats during the scorching summer months, providing relief from the heat and rapid courtroom transitions. While strict dress codes persist in higher courts, recent relaxations hint at possible changes. The Bar Council of India, empowered by the Advocates Act, regulates attire to ensure a dignified appearance. Notices often coincide with summer onset, permitting relaxation. High Courts, including Kerala, Punjab & Haryana, and Delhi, have exempted gowns during summers. The Supreme Court briefly considered amending rules but dismissed the plea in 2022. Meanwhile, AstraZeneca's acknowledgment of rare vaccine side effects may lead to legal compensation.

item.title: Why ‘application of mind’ (by the DM) is crucial for preventive detention under the J&K Public Safety Act
item.description: Lashkar-e-Taiba and Hizbul Mujahideen, two terrorist groups, were the focus of a recent ruling by the Jammu and Kashmir High Court. Jaffar Ahmad Parray, detained under the Public Safety Act, was ordered released due to illegal preventive detention. Justice Rahul Bharti found flaws in the detention process, noting the police's reliance on a vague dossier and the District Magistrate's failure to consider Parray's representation. This decision echoes past cases highlighting the importance of proper procedure in preventive detention orders. In a related development, AstraZeneca acknowledged rare side effects of its COVID vaccine, potentially leading to significant legal compensations.

item.title: What’s behind heavy rainfall in Dubai
