It highlights a petition in the Supreme Court that points out the lack of clarity in voter registration forms regarding the voluntary nature of this linkage. The Election Commission of India (EC) proposed amendments to the Representation of the People Act, 1950, and voter enrolment forms to make it clear that providing Aadhaar details is not mandatory. However, the Union Law Ministry reportedly rejected these amendments.
The EC had initiated a drive in 2015 to link Aadhaar with the electoral rolls to eliminate fraudulent entries, which was halted after a Supreme Court ruling limited Aadhaar's use. In 2019, the EC proposed the linkage again, leading to the passing of the Election Laws (Amendment) Bill, 2021, which allowed voluntary Aadhaar linking starting July 2022.
A recent Supreme Court petition by a Congress leader from Telangana called for amendments to give electors the option not to link their Aadhaar with their voter ID. The EC suggested changes to the enrolment forms to reflect that Aadhaar submission is optional, but the government deemed further amendments unnecessary, stating that clarifications from the EC would suffice.
Additionally, the article mentions the transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan, the wife of a BJD leader, from a public-facing department due to allegations of misuse of her position to influence voters. The BJP has accused her of using the Mission Shakti scheme for electoral gains. The article's author, Damini Nath, is an Assistant Editor with The Indian Express, covering housing, urban affairs, and the Election Commission.

item.title: Why do we celebrate Women’s Day on March 8?
item.description:
International Women's Day, celebrated on March 8, was officially recognized by the United Nations in 1975. Its origins trace back to the first National Woman's Day in the U.S. on February 28, 1909, honoring the 1908 garment workers' strike in New York. This event was part of the broader First Wave of Feminism, which began in the mid-19th century and included significant campaigns for women's rights, such as the 1848 women's rights convention by Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Lucretia Mott.
Clara Zetkin, a leader in the German Social Democratic Party, proposed the idea of an International Women's Day in 1910, leading to the first rallies in 1911 with over one million participants across Europe. The date of March 8 became globally recognized due to its association with Russian women's protests on February 23, 1913 (Julian calendar), corresponding to March 8 on the Gregorian calendar. These protests were a critical part of the Russian Revolution, which led to the establishment of a communist state and women gaining the right to vote in Russia.
In 2011, the Obama administration proclaimed March as 'Women's History Month,' commemorating the 100th anniversary of International Women's Day and acknowledging the ongoing struggle for women's equality. The article concludes with a contemporary event unrelated to Women's Day, detailing the transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan from the Mission Shakti department in India due to allegations of misuse of public office.

item.title: El Niño and the summer, monsoon: What is in store this year
item.description:
The article discusses the implications of the 2023-24 El Niño event for India, particularly concerning the summer temperatures and the southwest monsoon. The **India Meteorological Department (IMD)** has predicted a hotter summer with above-normal temperatures and more heatwave days from March to May. The **World Meteorological Organisation (WMO)** stated that the current El Niño, one of the strongest on record, has peaked and is now weakening, but it will continue to influence global climate patterns.
El Niño is characterized by abnormal warming of the equatorial Pacific Ocean waters and affects global weather, leading to higher temperatures, dryness, and altered rainfall patterns. The 2023-24 El Niño has been linked to record-breaking global temperatures and is expected to contribute to higher-than-normal temperatures across India during the summer months. Heatwaves are anticipated to be longer and more severe, particularly in Central and Northern Peninsular India.
The southwest monsoon, which accounts for nearly 70% of India's annual rainfall, may be affected by El Niño, as past episodes have been associated with below-average rainfall. However, current global climate models suggest that ENSO neutral conditions will emerge by May, potentially leading to favorable conditions for the monsoon. If these predictions hold, the monsoon may not be adversely affected by El Niño, and there could be normal rainfall, assuming other ocean-atmosphere parameters remain conducive. The IMD is expected to release the Long Range Forecast for the monsoon by mid-April. The article also mentions unrelated content and advertisements which have been omitted from this summary.

item.title: The ‘Architecture Nobel’: Why Pritzker laureate Riken Yamamoto’s work stands out
item.description:
Riken Yamamoto, a Japanese architect, has been honored with the 2024 Pritzker Architecture Prize, often dubbed the "Architecture Nobel." He is the ninth Japanese recipient since the prize's inception in 1979. The Pritzker Prize recognizes living architects for their talent, vision, and contributions to humanity and architecture. It includes a $100,000 award, a citation, and a bronze medallion.
The selection process involves a jury evaluating over 500 nominees, including visits to project sites, with the ceremony held in May. Japanese architects have claimed the most Pritzker Prizes, with Yamamoto joining a list of previous laureates who have significantly influenced global architectural discourse.
Yamamoto, 79, is known for his emphasis on community and visibility in his designs, which range from private residences to public institutions. His work often features transparent elements that connect the community, such as the Hiroshima Nishi Fire Station's glass walls. He advocates for architecture that fosters societal relationships and harmonizes individual freedom with communal living.
The article also touches on the challenges Japanese architects face, such as high inheritance taxes and limited space, which drive innovative design solutions. Yamamoto's approach is described as a remedy for societal isolation, creating spaces that encourage interaction and visibility, exemplified by his projects like the Koyasu Elementary School and Hotakubo Housing.
In his statement, Yamamoto criticizes the current architectural focus on privacy, suggesting that architecture should instead promote societal connections and cultural harmony. His philosophy and designs aim to address the isolation malaise of society by creating spaces that are not only functional but also foster community engagement.

item.title: Kerala declares man-animal conflict a state-specific disaster: what changes with this
item.description: Kerala has become the first state in India to declare man-animal conflict a state-specific disaster. This shift in responsibility from the forest department to the state disaster management authority allows for quicker, more decisive action under the Disaster Management Act. The Chief Minister leads the state-level authority, with district collectors heading the district authorities. This change enables the disaster management authority to override other norms, including the Wildlife Protection Act, to address the conflict more effectively. The decision follows increasing incidents of animal attacks and subsequent public outcry. Previously, only the chief wildlife warden could decide on actions against wild animals causing human fatalities, often leading to legal challenges. The new measure prevents lower courts from intervening in actions taken under this declaration. Kerala has previously declared other issues like snakebites, Covid-19, heatwaves, soil piping, and coastal erosion as state-specific disasters.

item.title: Why scientists voted down proposal to declare start of the Anthropocene — and what it means
item.description:
The article discusses the debate over the Anthropocene, a proposed geological epoch that would mark the significant impact humans have had on Earth. Despite evidence of human influence from the peak of Mount Everest to the Mariana Trench, a committee of 18 scientists voted against declaring the Anthropocene as a new epoch in the geologic time scale (GTS). The GTS, which measures Earth's history, is divided into aeons, eras, periods, epochs, and ages, with transitions marked by significant events.
We currently live in the Holocene epoch, which began 11,700 years ago after the Last Glacial Period. The term Anthropocene was coined in 2000, suggesting that human activity has profoundly changed the planet. The Anthropocene Working Group (AWG) proposed 1952 as the starting point for this epoch, reflecting the "Great Acceleration" of human population growth and environmental impact post-World War II.
However, the proposal was rejected by the Subcommission on Quaternary Stratigraphy (SQS) of the International Union of Geological Sciences (IUGS), as it did not meet the chronostratigraphic standards for defining epochs. Critics argue that the proposal's recent starting point could confuse the long history of human transformation of the Earth. Others believe that the Anthropocene should be considered an "event" rather than an epoch, as it does not require a formal start date on the GTS.
The rejection of the Anthropocene proposal does not negate the undeniable and lasting human impact on the planet, which will be evident in future geological records. The concept of the Anthropocene remains relevant as a transformative time for Earth due to human activity. The article concludes by noting that the SQS vote was against the specific definition proposed by the AWG, not against the idea of human impact itself. Scientists continue to debate whether the Anthropocene should be officially recognized and how to define it.

item.title: Bengaluru’s first driverless metro train, aided by AI: All you need to know
item.description:
The Bengaluru Metro Rail Corporation Limited (BMRCL) has introduced the first set of six train coaches for the yellow line, which will feature a Communication-based Train Control (CBTC) system. This line, spanning 18.8 km and connecting RV Road to Bommasandra, is notable for being the first in Bengaluru to offer a driverless train service. It aims to ease traffic congestion on Hosur Road and includes 16 elevated stations, integrating with the Green and Pink Lines of the existing metro network.
The CBTC system, described as "one train talking to another," enables Unattended Train Operations (UTO) and is managed by the Operations Control Centre (OCC). The trains, equipped with AI, will perform daily self-checks, automated cleaning, and enter a sleep mode at night. Manufactured by CRRC Nanjing Puzhen Co Ltd and Titagarh Rail Systems Ltd, these trains are part of the Make In India initiative.
Special features include a hot axle detection system, real-time location updates, front and rear-view cameras, and an Emergency Egress Device (EED) for passenger safety. Before commencing operations, the trains will undergo extensive safety tests, including static and dynamic testing, system integration tests, and statutory safety trials by relevant authorities.
Initially, the driverless trains will operate with a train operator for six months and start with a 15-minute frequency. The yellow line was expected to be operational by 2022 but has been delayed to December 2024 due to setbacks in train deliveries and manufacturing challenges. The trains are undergoing a series of at least 37 mainline tests over four months and signalling tests for 45 days before they can start service.

item.title: What is Haiper, the text-to-video model created by Google DeepMind, TikTok alumni?
item.description: Haiper, a new player in the AI field, has launched a text-to-video model that aims to pave the way towards artificial general intelligence. Founded by former members of Google DeepMind and TikTok, Haiper's model allows users to generate short high-definition videos from text prompts. The model, which is still in its early stages, currently produces videos up to four seconds long but plans to extend this. Despite some imperfections in the video output, Haiper is free to use and is seeking to build a community around its product. The company is also working on a series of large trained models for future release. While it faces stiff competition from established entities like OpenAI and Google, Haiper has made its tool available for public use, unlike OpenAI's Sora, which remains inaccessible to the public. The article also briefly mentions the professional background of the technology journalist, Bijin Jose, who reported on Haiper.

item.title: How RBI’s new directions on credit cards could benefit customers
item.description: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has mandated that credit card issuers must offer customers a choice of card networks and prohibited exclusive agreements with any single network. This decision aims to enhance customer choice and competition among card networks. Issuers have six months to comply with these new regulations. The RBI's review revealed that current issuer-network agreements limit customer options, prompting these changes. The norms apply to issuers with over 10 lakh active cards and exclude companies like American Express that operate their own networks. As of January 31, 2024, India had 9.95 crore active credit cards, with leading issuers being HDFC Bank, SBI Cards, ICICI Bank, and Axis Bank. The new rules are expected to benefit customers by providing more options and fostering better card features due to increased competition.

item.title: SC sets up panel to look into tiger safaris, ecological damage at Jim Corbett: What was the case
item.description:
The Supreme Court of India has mandated the formation of a committee to propose methods for rectifying ecological harm in Jim Corbett National Park due to unauthorized construction and deforestation. This committee will also address tiger safari concerns in national park buffer zones. The court's decision follows a Central Empowered Committee (CEC) report that highlighted over 6,053 trees were illegally cut down for the Pakhrau Tiger Safari in Uttarakhand.
The case originated from a public interest litigation regarding illegal tree felling and construction within the Corbett Tiger Reserve's Tiger Breeding Habitat. The Supreme Court's ruling cited numerous violations in the Pakhrau safari's development, including unauthorized road and building construction, excessive tree felling, and overspending of approved funds.
The CEC report implicated the District Forest Officer of Kalagarh and other officials for these irregularities, leading to arrests and investigations by the CBI. The then Forest Minister, Harak Singh Rawat, was identified as the main orchestrator.
The Supreme Court's committee, comprising representatives from various environmental and wildlife authorities, is tasked with evaluating the damage, identifying responsible officers, and recommending restoration measures. It will also consider the feasibility of tiger safaris in buffer zones and establish guidelines if deemed permissible. The committee's approach emphasizes ecocentrism, the precautionary principle, and the use of only injured, conflicted, or orphaned tigers in safaris.
Separately, the Election Commission of India transferred Sujata R Karthikeyan, wife of BJD leader V K Pandian, due to allegations of misusing public office for election-related activities. The BJP accused her of using the Mission Shakti scheme to sway voters. This unrelated matter was also mentioned in the article.

item.title: India to restart Penicillin G manufacture: why was it stopped, what changed now
item.description:
India is set to resume the domestic production of Penicillin G, an essential antibiotic, after a hiatus of three decades. This move is a result of the government's Production Linked Incentive (PLI) scheme, which was initiated during the pandemic to boost local manufacturing and reduce dependency on imports. The scheme incentivizes companies based on incremental sales.
The decision comes in the wake of realizing the importance of self-reliance, especially after the supply chain disruptions experienced during the pandemic. The industry had previously seen a decline in API production due to the influx of cheaper Chinese products, leading to the closure of Indian manufacturing plants. The last such plant belonged to Torrent Pharma in Ahmedabad.
The revival of Penicillin G production is scheduled for mid-2024 by Aurobindo Pharma, based in Hyderabad. The delay in restarting production is attributed to the lack of perceived need, high initial costs, and the dominance of China as a major API supplier. The PLI scheme aims to address these challenges by providing financial support to fermentation-based bulk drug manufacturers, including antibiotics, enzymes, and hormones like insulin.
The impact of the PLI scheme has been significant, with a noticeable decrease in API imports. However, experts note that India still imports a substantial percentage of its APIs, indicating that it will take time for domestic manufacturing to fully recover. The scheme offers a tiered support system, with higher incentives in the initial years to encourage investment in this critical sector.

item.title: Explained: Ladakh, Article 371, and the Sixth Schedule of the Constitution
item.description: Union Home Minister Amit Shah has proposed extending Article 371-like protections to Ladakh, addressing concerns about jobs, land, and culture raised by local organizations. However, he ruled out including Ladakh in the Sixth Schedule of the Constitution, which would grant autonomy to administrate tribal areas. Ladakh, now a Union Territory without a legislature, has seen demands for such inclusion since its separation from Jammu and Kashmir in 2019. Article 371 provides special provisions for certain states, allowing for autonomy and representation without interference from state and central governments. Shah assured the Ladakh delegation of local representation and participation through hill councils and up to 80% reservation in public employment. This move, if enacted, would mark the first time special provisions are introduced for a Union Territory rather than a state. The article also mentions the Election Commission's transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan due to allegations of misuse of public office.

item.title: Explained: The rise and fall of Byju’s
item.description: Byju Raveendran, the CEO of Byju's, informed employees that a legal issue with investors has led to blocked funds, affecting salary payments. The company is also involved in a legal case in the US regarding $533 million, which it claims is not misappropriated but transferred to a subsidiary. Once valued at $22 billion, Byju's now faces financial distress, legal challenges, and a potential leadership shake-up, with its valuation dropping below $1 billion. The company's rapid growth, fueled by aggressive marketing and global investments, has been marred by financial missteps, leading to significant losses and defaults on loans. Byju's is banking on a successful rights issue to stabilize its operations, while the outcomes of court proceedings will determine the future of the company and its leadership.

item.title: Who was Ayya Vaikundar, and why TN Governor calling him ‘Sanatan Dharma saviour’ sparked a row
item.description:
The article discusses the controversy surrounding Tamil Nadu Governor R N Ravi's remarks on Ayya Vaikundar, a 19th-century social reformer. Ravi's statement that Vaikundar was an incarnation of Lord Vishnu meant to protect Sanatan Dharma has sparked criticism from politicians and followers of Vaikundar. Ayya Vaikundar is celebrated for his efforts to eradicate caste-based discrimination and promote equality through various social reforms, such as community eateries and common wells for all castes, and inclusive worship practices that challenged the prevailing caste system.
Prime Minister Narendra Modi paid homage to Vaikundar, praising his work towards creating a compassionate society. However, Ravi's interpretation of Vaikundar's teachings as aligned with Sanatan Dharma has been disputed by leaders of the Ayyavazhi sect and others, who argue that Vaikundar's mission was to eliminate ignorance and caste division, not to save Sanatan Dharma. The article also mentions historians' views that political appropriation of such figures should be logical and respectful of their unique historical context, which they believe Ravi's comments lacked.
Additionally, the article briefly touches on an unrelated issue regarding the Election Commission of India's transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan due to allegations of misuse of public office. The BJP accuses her of using the Mission Shakti scheme to influence voters on behalf of the BJD. This part of the article seems to be separate from the main topic of Ayya Vaikundar.

item.title: Why is ISRO building a second rocket launchport?
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi inaugurated ISRO's second launchport at Kulasekarapattinam, Tamil Nadu, which will focus on commercial and small satellite launches. This new facility, costing Rs 986 crore, is expected to alleviate the load on the Satish Dhawan Space Centre (SDSC) SHAR, which will continue to handle larger missions. The Kulasekarapattinam launchport offers geographical advantages for Small Satellite Launch Vehicle (SSLV) missions, allowing for more efficient fuel use and enhanced payload capacities due to its direct southward launch trajectory. The Tamil Nadu government has provided over 2,000 acres for this project, and ISRO Chairman S Somanath estimates a two-year construction period. The SSLV, designed for low-cost, quick-turnaround launches of small satellites, has seen both failure and success in its initial missions. The new launchport is strategically placed near the equator, which is beneficial for geostationary satellite launches, and is expected to support 20 to 30 SSLV launches annually once operational.

item.title: Why the US Supreme Court restored Donald Trump’s candidacy in Colorado
item.description: The Supreme Court of the United States ruled unanimously in favor of former President Donald Trump, allowing him to contest the 2024 presidential elections. This decision came despite arguments that he was ineligible under the Fourteenth Amendment's Section 3, which bars individuals who engaged in insurrection from holding office. The Colorado Supreme Court had previously ruled that Trump could not be listed on the primary ballot, but the SCOTUS overturned this decision, stating that states have no power to enforce Section 3 concerning federal offices. The ruling ends challenges to Trump's candidacy in at least 36 states and has significant implications for the upcoming election where Trump is leading opinion polls. The unrelated content regarding the Election Commission of India has been omitted from this summary.

item.title: What is Cuttack’s famed silver filigree work, which recently received GI tag
item.description:
The article discusses the awarding of the Geographical Indication (GI) tag to the Rupa Tarakasi, the renowned silver filigree work from Cuttack, Odisha. The GI tag, applied for by the Odisha State Cooperative Handicrafts Corporation Limited (Utkalika), recognizes products with unique qualities originating from a specific region. Cuttack's silver filigree is celebrated for its intricate designs and fine craftsmanship, where silver is crafted into delicate wires or foils to create jewelry and showpieces.
The origins of Cuttack's filigree art are traced back to the 12th century, with significant influence from various cultures and rulers over time. Historically, it shares characteristics with filigree work from regions like Arabia, Malta, and ancient Greece, suggesting a widespread cultural exchange.
Today, Cuttack's filigree artisans produce a range of products, including jewelry, decorative items, and religious artifacts. Despite the evolution of the craft, the fundamental process has remained consistent, with changes primarily in design and product offerings. The article also mentions the use of various metals in the crafting process, such as copper, zinc, cadmium, and tin.
The unrelated content regarding the Election Commission's order and political accusations has been omitted from this summary.

item.title: GI tag for Majuli masks of Assam: History, cultural significance of the centuries-old art form
item.description:
The traditional Majuli masks and manuscript paintings of Assam have been awarded the Geographical Indication (GI) tag, recognizing their unique cultural significance and origin. The Majuli masks, part of the neo-Vaishnavite tradition since the 16th century, are used in bhaonas (theatrical performances) to depict various characters, including gods, goddesses, and demons. These masks are crafted from local materials like bamboo, clay, and cotton, and their creation can take from five days to one and a half months, depending on the size.
The art of mask-making is deeply rooted in the monastic institutions known as sattras, which are centers for religious and cultural activities. Currently, the mask-making tradition is primarily concentrated in four sattras on Majuli, the world's largest river island. Efforts are being made to modernize the art form and make it economically viable, with initiatives like selling masks to tourists and displaying them in exhibitions, including the British Museum.
Hemchandra Goswami, the head of Samaguri Sattra, has been instrumental in promoting mask-making beyond its traditional use in bhaonas. Workshops are held to train new artists, and there are plans to adapt the masks for contemporary uses to appeal to younger generations.
Majuli manuscript painting, also dating back to the 16th century, is performed on manuscripts made from the bark of the sanchi or agar tree. This art form, which has been patronized by the Ahom kings, continues to be practiced in Majuli's sattras and is an integral part of the island's cultural heritage. The GI tags aim to preserve and promote these traditional arts, ensuring their longevity and appreciation in the modern world.

item.title: Why Bombay High Court acquitted Saibaba, again
item.description: The Nagpur Bench of the Bombay High Court acquitted former Delhi University professor G N Saibaba, reversing a trial court's life sentence verdict for alleged Maoist links under the UAPA. The High Court highlighted the prosecution's failure to adhere to procedural requirements, such as obtaining valid sanctions for the charges. The absence of these sanctions was deemed a fundamental error, leading to the conclusion that the trial court lacked jurisdiction to take cognizance of the offences. The High Court also dismissed the state's argument for presuming terror charges based on the recovery of electronic evidence and pamphlets, stating that such items do not fall under the hazardous category as per the UAPA. This ruling underscores the importance of procedural safeguards in the judicial process, especially when serious charges are involved.

item.title: Why INS Jatayu, India’s new naval base in Lakshadweep, matters
item.description: The article discusses the commissioning of **INS Jatayu**, an upgraded naval base at Minicoy in the Lakshadweep Islands, which marks a significant enhancement of India's security infrastructure in this strategically important region. INS Jatayu will be the second naval base in Lakshadweep after INS Dweeprakshak and is part of India's efforts to strengthen its presence in the Indian Ocean, especially in light of the strategic importance of the Lakshadweep Islands and their proximity to major maritime routes. The base will support a range of military and possibly civil aircraft, enhancing India's operational capabilities, including anti-piracy and anti-narcotics operations, and its role as a first responder in the region. This move comes at a time of growing Chinese influence in the Indian Ocean and strained relations with the Maldives. The commissioning of INS Jatayu is aligned with the government's focus on the comprehensive development of the islands, despite potential challenges posed by the fragile ecology of the region.

item.title: Meet MethaneSAT, a satellite which will ‘name and shame’ methane emitters
item.description: MethaneSAT, a satellite designed to track and measure global methane emissions, was launched on a SpaceX Falcon9 rocket. It aims to provide detailed data with a wider field of view than previous satellites. Methane, a potent greenhouse gas, contributes significantly to global warming and ground-level ozone formation. The Environmental Defense Fund (EDF), in collaboration with various institutions, developed MethaneSAT to monitor the oil and gas sector, offering near real-time public data to aid in reducing methane emissions. The satellite's advanced technology can detect small methane sources and "super emitters," addressing the underreporting of emissions by national governments. The launch aligns with global efforts to manage methane emissions, such as the Global Methane Pledge. MethaneSAT's data promotes transparency but does not guarantee changes in polluters' behavior.

item.title: A new report card, where students, their friends, parents get a say: What has NCERT changed, why
item.description: The article discusses the introduction of a new 'holistic progress card' (HPC) by the National Council for Educational and Research Training (NCERT), which aims to provide a more comprehensive assessment of students' abilities beyond academic performance. The HPC, developed by PARAKH, will evaluate students on interpersonal relationships, self-reflection, creativity, and emotional application, and will be implemented for classes 1 through 8 as per the National Education Policy (NEP) 2020. This card will replace traditional marks or grades with a 360-degree evaluation that includes self and peer assessments, as well as parental input on various aspects of a child's development. The HPC is designed to foster higher-order thinking skills and holistic growth, and it has already been adopted by several states and Union Territories. The change reflects the NEP 2020's emphasis on building self-awareness and self-esteem in students, moving away from rote memorization towards a competency-based evaluation system. The HPC is expected to provide valuable insights for teachers and parents to support individual learning paths.

item.title: Kerala man killed on Israel farm: What are Indians doing there?
item.description: An Indian national was killed and two others were injured when an anti-tank missile, allegedly fired by Hezbollah from Lebanon, hit an orchard in northern Israel. The Israeli Embassy in India condemned the attack. Tensions have escalated along Israel's northern border with Lebanon since October 2023, leading to casualties and displacements. Hezbollah, opposed to Israel and Western influence, has been active since the Lebanese Civil War. Israel's labor shortage, exacerbated by security concerns, has led to the recruitment of Indian workers, particularly in agriculture. The recent attack highlights the risks faced by these workers, who are often employed near conflict zones. The article also discusses the broader context of Indian labor in Israel, including caregivers, and the impact of the conflict on their employment and safety.

item.title: Why Anthropic calls the new Claude 3 its ‘most intelligent’ AI model yet
item.description: Anthropic, an AI start-up, has launched a new family of AI models named Claude 3, which includes Claude 3 Haiku, Claude 3 Sonnet, and Claude 3 Opus, each designed for different levels of performance and use cases. The models are said to be more accurate in answering questions and have been developed by former OpenAI members. Claude 3 Opus is highlighted as the most powerful, capable of near-human comprehension and fluency in complex tasks, surpassing GPT-4 in several benchmarks. However, experts advise caution in interpreting these benchmarks. The models also feature enhanced vision capabilities and improved performance in various cognitive tasks but have shown biases and struggle with complex reasoning at times. Anthropic emphasizes the safety and ethical aspects of Claude 3, aiming to release more affordable versions in the future. The article suggests that Claude 3 represents a significant advancement in large language models.

item.title: Govt clarifies its AI advisory on elections: How to understand the concerns and criticism around the issue
item.description: The article discusses the Indian government's advisory on generative AI services in the context of elections. The advisory, initially causing concern among startups, was clarified to target significant platforms, not startups. It mandates large platforms to seek permission before deploying AI services, especially with Lok Sabha elections approaching. The advisory aims to prevent illegal content and protect the electoral process's integrity. Criticism arose over potential regulatory overreach and the legal basis of the advisory, as current laws don't explicitly cover large language models (LLMs). The government views the advisory as a due diligence measure under the Information Technology Rules, 2021, and a precaution against misinformation and deepfakes affecting elections. The article suggests that a balanced approach between regulation and innovation is necessary, considering the potential misuse of AI in sensitive areas like elections. The legal framework for the advisory is debated, but it's presented as an effort to ensure the safety of citizens and democracy. The article concludes with a brief mention of an upcoming IPL match, unrelated to the main content.

item.title: Former DU professor GN Saibaba acquitted over alleged Maoist links: What was the case against him?
item.description: The Bombay High Court acquitted former Delhi University professor G N Saibaba and others, previously convicted for alleged Maoist links. The division bench found the prosecution's case unproven due to an invalid sanction under the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act (UAPA), rendering the trial null and void. The court highlighted the failure to establish legal seizure of evidence and the absence of incriminating material against the accused. Consequently, the bench overturned the trial court's judgment and acquitted all accused, emphasizing the importance of due process and legal safeguards. Previously, the Supreme Court had set aside a similar High Court verdict and remanded the case for a fresh hearing, which led to this acquittal.

item.title: Tata Motors demerger: What does it signal, what’s in it for shareholders?
item.description: Tata Motors' shares saw a significant surge following the announcement of a demerger into two separate listed entities. The demerger will divide the company into one entity handling the commercial vehicles business and another incorporating the passenger vehicles business, including electric vehicles and the Jaguar-Land Rover division. This strategic move is expected to unlock value and enhance growth opportunities, with the passenger vehicles segment showing potential for self-sustainability. The demerger process will be carried out through an NCLT Scheme of Arrangement, ensuring that shareholders retain identical stakes in both entities. Analysts have mixed views on the potential value creation from the demerger, with some seeing it as a positive step towards competing with market leaders and capitalizing on growth opportunities, especially in electric and autonomous vehicles. The formalities and approvals for the demerger are anticipated to take 12-15 months, with no adverse impact on employees, customers, or business partners. Tata Motors' stock has risen significantly over the past year, reflecting investor optimism.

item.title: SC upholds Rajasthan rule barring those with more than 2 kids from police force: What is the case
item.description:
The Supreme Court upheld the Rajasthan government's rule barring individuals with more than two children from applying for police constable positions, stating it is constitutional and non-discriminatory. The rule in question is Rule 24(4) of the Rajasthan Police Subordinate Service Rules, 1989, which disqualifies candidates with more than two children after June 1, 2002, from appointment to the service. Exceptions are made if the number of children does not increase after that date or in the case of multiple births from a single subsequent delivery.
The case arose from an ex-serviceman's plea after his application for a constable post was rejected due to having more than two children post the specified date. His appeal was dismissed by the Rajasthan High Court, leading him to approach the Supreme Court, which also dismissed his challenge.
The ruling referenced a similar provision for panchayat elections upheld by the Supreme Court in 2003. The article also notes that several states have implemented policies linking family size to eligibility for various positions, including public employment, to promote family planning. The article ends with a mention of the Election Commission of India ordering the transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan due to a complaint of alleged misuse of public office.

item.title: What is India’s disability law; how accessible are govt buildings to PwD?
item.description:
The article discusses the efforts of the Central Public Works Department (CPWD) in India to ensure public buildings are accessible to people with disabilities (PwD), in line with the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016. This act aligns with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which India ratified in 2007. The CPWD has mandated that lifts should have audio and visual announcements, and emergency evacuation routes for PwD should be clearly marked, including Braille signage.
The CPWD's directive is part of a broader initiative to enforce compliance with accessibility laws and guidelines that were established years ago but have seen delayed implementation. The Harmonised Guidelines and Space Standards for Barrier Free Built Environment for Persons With Disability and Elderly Persons, first published in 2016, were updated in 2021 to include comprehensive standards for ramps, grab rails, lifts, toilets, and other features to enhance accessibility.
Despite these efforts, there is criticism from PwDs and activists regarding the lack of implementation of these guidelines. Experts point out the absence of awareness and accountability among engineers and public works departments responsible for executing these standards. The article also mentions the Accessible India Campaign, which aims to make public buildings, transportation, and websites accessible for PwD, and the progress made in retrofitting buildings to meet accessibility standards.
The article concludes with concerns about the inconsistent application of accessibility standards and the need for more stringent measures to ensure compliance. It highlights the challenges faced by PwDs due to the haphazard implementation of accessibility features and the lack of sensitivity among those responsible for their implementation.

item.title: JMM bribes for votes ruling: How Supreme Court interpreted privilege for lawmakers
item.description:
The Supreme Court of India, led by Chief Justice DY Chandrachud, has ruled that **lawmakers cannot claim immunity** from criminal prosecution for bribery related to their speech and votes in the House. The Court emphasized that parliamentary privilege claims are subject to judicial review and are not absolute.
The case involved the interpretation of **Article 105(2)** and **Article 194(2)** of the Constitution, which protect members of Parliament and state Assemblies from legal proceedings related to their official actions. However, the Court clarified that privileges must pass the "necessity test," meaning they must be essential for lawmakers to perform their duties. Accepting bribes does not meet this criterion.
The Court also addressed whether a lawmaker could claim immunity if they accepted a bribe but voted according to their conscience or party line. Analyzing the Prevention of Corruption Act, the Court concluded that merely accepting a bribe constitutes an offense, regardless of the subsequent action taken by the public servant.
Furthermore, the Court held that creating a class of public servants with extraordinary protection would violate the right to equality under **Article 14** and be considered arbitrary.
Lastly, the Court stated that both Parliament and the judiciary have roles in addressing the actions of lawmakers, as the purposes of punishment by the House and criminal prosecution are distinct. This ruling ensures that lawmakers are held accountable and reinforces the integrity of the parliamentary system.

item.title: Bribes for votes: Supreme Court draws a red line, pushes the envelope on House privileges
item.description: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that parliamentary privileges are not absolute and can be subject to judicial review. This decision extends the court's ability to scrutinize the actions of Parliament members, particularly concerning immunity from prosecution for bribery under Article 105(2) of the Constitution. The ruling emphasizes the separation of powers and the judiciary's independence as part of the Constitution's basic structure. It asserts that lawmakers can be prosecuted for corruption even for actions within the House, as such behavior undermines the Constitution's ideals and democratic principles. The court has gradually limited the scope of immunity from graft charges, as seen in the 2021 Kerala assembly ruckus case where the Supreme Court ruled that criminal acts, such as property damage, are not protected by parliamentary immunity. Additionally, the court is considering cases related to the Governor's powers in lawmaking and the balance between citizens' fundamental rights and parliamentary privileges. In a related development, the Election Commission has transferred Sujata R Karthikeyan, linked to a political leader, due to allegations of misusing her public office for electoral gains.

item.title: All you need to know about ‘Super Tuesday’, a key day in the US Presidential elections
item.description:
Super Tuesday, set for March 5, 2024, is a pivotal day in the US Presidential election cycle, with voters from 15 states casting their ballots for Democratic and Republican candidates. This day is often seen as a strong indicator of the eventual party nominees.
The US election process begins with primaries and caucuses, where voters express their preferences for candidates. Victories in these events are crucial as they secure delegates who will later vote at the National Conventions to officially nominate the Presidential candidates.
Criticism exists over the delegate system, as it does not allow direct voter selection of candidates. Additionally, "superdelegates" have the power to vote independently of primary results, potentially influencing the party's final decision.
This year's primaries and caucuses run from January to June, with Super Tuesday being a significant event due to the large number of states involved. The Democratic Party sees President Joe Biden seeking re-election without significant opposition, while the Republican field has narrowed to Donald Trump and Nikki Haley, with Haley achieving a historic win in the Washington primary.
The article also touches on the anticipation surrounding the candidacy for the Nehru-Gandhi seats in India, highlighting the global nature of political campaigns and elections.

item.title: What is the Punjab-Himachal dispute over the Shanan hydropower project
item.description: The article discusses the dispute between Punjab and Himachal Pradesh over the Shanan hydropower project. The project, which dates back to the British era, was leased to Punjab in 1925 and the lease expired on March 2, 2024. Himachal Pradesh claims the project should revert to it post-lease, while Punjab has taken the matter to the Supreme Court, asserting ownership and control through the Punjab State Power Corporation Ltd. The Centre has intervened by ordering a status quo to be maintained until a final decision is made, ensuring the project's uninterrupted operation. This order is an interim measure and not a basis for any claim or interest, with parties expected to resolve the dispute legally. The unrelated content regarding President Joe Biden's comments on immigration has been omitted from this summary.

item.title: Warming up to climate change: What is carbon capture and can it help save the planet?
item.description:
Germany has recently decided to permit carbon capture and offshore storage for industries like cement production to achieve carbon neutrality by 2045. This move is part of a broader adoption of carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies by various countries, such as the UAE's project to convert atmospheric CO2 into rock.
CCS technologies capture CO2 emissions from sources like refineries and power plants and store them underground. There are three main CCS techniques: post-combustion, pre-combustion, and oxyfuel combustion. Post-combustion captures CO2 after fossil fuels are burned, pre-combustion does so before burning, and oxyfuel combustion burns fuel with pure oxygen to produce CO2 and water vapor, which are then separated.
While CCS is touted for its potential to combat climate change, its effectiveness and cost-efficiency are debated. Studies have shown that some operational CCS projects do not perform as claimed, and the technology is expensive compared to renewable energy sources. The International Energy Agency (IEA) has cautioned against overreliance on CCS, stating that the electricity required for extensive carbon capture by 2050 could exceed global electricity usage in 2022.
Critics argue that CCS provides a "social licence to operate" for fossil fuel companies, allowing them to continue extraction under the guise of climate solutions. The article suggests that while CCS has a role, it should not be the sole strategy for addressing climate change.

item.title: As SC overturns Narasimha Rao decision, remembering its 1998 ruling in JMM cash-for-votes case
item.description:
The Supreme Court of India has recently overturned a 1998 judgment that granted legislators immunity from criminal prosecution for bribery related to their speech and votes in Parliament and Legislative Assemblies. This landmark decision reverses the court's previous stance from the case P V Narasimha Rao v State (CBI/Spe), where it was ruled that legislators were protected under Article 105(2) of the Constitution, which safeguards parliamentary freedom of speech and voting from legal proceedings.
The case stems from a 1993 no-confidence motion against then Prime Minister P V Narasimha Rao, where it was later discovered that Jharkhand Mukti Morcha (JMM) MPs were allegedly bribed to vote against the motion. The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) filed cases against six JMM MPs and Janata Dal’s Ajit Singh for accepting bribes.
The Supreme Court's recent ruling emphasizes that the intended purpose of Article 105(2) is not to shield legislators from the rule of law or allow them to engage in corrupt practices. The court's decision now holds that legislators can be prosecuted for bribery, marking a significant shift towards accountability and the integrity of parliamentary proceedings. This ruling is expected to have far-reaching implications for the conduct of legislators and the legal framework surrounding parliamentary immunity.

item.title: Why Odisha wants to introduce Similipal’s black tigers to female big cats from central India
item.description: The Odisha government is seeking approval from the National Tiger Conservation Authority to introduce female tigers from the Central Indian landscape to the Similipal Tiger Reserve. This initiative aims to enhance the gene pool and balance the sex ratio within the reserve, which is home to the unique pseudo-melanistic royal Bengal tigers. Genetic studies indicate that these tigers, which have distinctive black-and-yellow stripes due to high melanin levels, are inbred and isolated. The recent Odisha Tiger Estimation revealed a total of 24 adult tigers in Similipal, with 13 being pseudo-melanistic. The introduction of more females, particularly from areas like Maharashtra and Madhya Pradesh where tiger reserves are overcrowded, is expected to increase genetic diversity. The NTCA's approval is required for such relocations, and a technical committee will assess the reserve's suitability for the new tigers. Previous relocation efforts in Odisha's Satkosia Tiger Reserve were unsuccessful, resulting in the death of a male tiger and the return of a female tiger to her original habitat after she allegedly killed two people.

item.title: National leopard survey shows count up, but fewer animals outside tiger reserves: What this means
item.description:
The article discusses the findings of the 2022 national survey on India's leopard population. The survey reports a significant increase in the leopard count to **13,874**, marking a **75%** rise from the 2014 estimate. However, a more accurate comparison with the 2018 figures, which accounted for a larger number of camera traps, shows an **8%** increase in the population. Notably, **33%** of leopards are found within protected areas, which only make up **11%** of their range in India.
The study highlights the contrasting situations of leopards in protected areas versus those outside. In tiger reserves, leopard numbers have risen by **21%** since 2018, while those outside these areas have seen a **1%** decline. The article underscores the threats leopards face due to conflict and poaching, particularly in unprotected areas. It also points out the challenges of habitat fragmentation and the need for policies to protect leopards from development and poaching pressures.
The leopard's adaptability has allowed it to survive in close proximity to humans, but this has also made it vulnerable. The article cites studies and data on leopard poaching and conflict, including the alarming rate of leopard deaths and captures. It concludes by emphasizing the leopard's resilience and the critical role of human perception and policy in ensuring the future of this species outside protected forests.
The author, Jay Mazoomdaar, is noted for his investigative reporting on various environmental and conservation issues. The article also briefly mentions an upcoming IPL 2024 cricket match between Sunrisers Hyderabad and Rajasthan Royals, but this is unrelated to the main content.

item.title: Venice Biennale, ‘the Olympics of the art world’, set to open on April 20: Everything you need to know
item.description: The 60th Venice Biennale, set to open on April 20, will feature 333 artists under the theme "Stranieri Ovunque" or "Foreigners Everywhere," curated by Adriano Pedrosa. The event, attracting over 600,000 visitors annually, is a significant art fair showcasing contemporary art linked by a common theme to explore global social, economic, and political ideas. The Biennale, which began in 1895, includes a central pavilion, national pavilions, and collateral events. India, without a permanent pavilion, has participated officially in 1954, 2011, and 2019, with notable exhibitions and sales of works by prominent Indian artists. This year's Biennale will also include works by Indian artists and a public collective, highlighting the experiences of marginalized groups. Additionally, an exhibition dedicated to MF Husain, titled "The Rooted Nomad," will coincide with the Biennale in Venice.

item.title: How to bring about White Revolution 2.0
item.description:
The article discusses the findings of the **Household Consumption Expenditure Survey (HCES) for 2022-23**, which indicates that milk has become the top food expenditure item in India, surpassing spending on vegetables, cereals, and other food products in both rural and urban areas. The increase in milk expenditure is a positive sign for the dairy industry and farmers, but it faces challenges due to rising milk prices and the cost of feed and fodder.
To address these challenges, the article highlights the potential of **genetic improvement and breeding technologies** to increase milk yield and reduce production costs. It details the use of sex-sorted semen to ensure a higher probability of female calves, which are future milk producers. The article also describes advanced breeding techniques like **embryo transfer (ET)** and **in vitro fertilization (IVF)**, which can significantly increase the number of calves produced from high genetic merit cows.
The **Kaira District Co-operative Milk Producers’ Union (Amul)** is mentioned as a key player in implementing these technologies, aiming to increase the use of sex-sorted semen and has established a Bovine Breeding Centre for breeding high genetic merit bulls and cows.
Furthermore, the article touches on the need to reduce feeding costs through the cultivation of high-yielding fodder grasses and the establishment of a Total Mixed Ration (TMR) plant by Amul, which would provide a balanced diet for cattle at a lower cost.
The overarching theme is the focus on reducing the cost of milk production at the farm level, termed as **White Revolution 2.0**, to maintain farmer incomes and the competitiveness of the Indian dairy industry without increasing consumer prices. The article concludes with a brief mention of unrelated topics and a statement by President Joe Biden on the role of immigrants in the US economy.

item.title: Pakistan National Day to be celebrated in Delhi: What was the Lahore Resolution, which it marks
item.description: Pakistan is attempting discreet diplomatic outreach to India after a period of estrangement. To facilitate this, Pakistan will host its National Day celebrations in New Delhi, honoring the 1940 Lahore Resolution that called for an independent Muslim state in India. The resolution outlined the creation of two separate autonomous units for Muslim-majority regions, which later became the basis for Pakistan's independence. National Day is observed at the Pakistani embassy in New Delhi with speeches, music, and the presence of Indian dignitaries.

item.title: Why Thailand’s now-replaced WTO Ambassador questioned India’s agriculture subsidies, what India argued
item.description:
Thailand replaced its Ambassador to the World Trade Organization (WTO) after India protested her comments regarding India's Public Stockholding (PSH) program.
Thailand, as part of the Cairns Group, criticized India's PSH program, claiming it is subsidized and distorts global food prices. India, with rice exports exceeding the WTO's de minimis limit of 10% for developing countries, has argued for a change in the subsidy calculation method.
The Cairns Group, supported by the EU and US, seeks to reduce India's farm support, while India demands a permanent solution for public stockholding.
During the 13th WTO Ministerial Conference, tensions escalated between India and Thailand, leading to Indian negotiators boycotting discussions where the Thai representative was present.
Indian farmers have expressed concerns about WTO restrictions on farm support and have requested its removal from the WTO agreement.

item.title: This Quote Means: ‘Jai Jawan, Jai Kisan’, said by former Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri
item.description:
Lal Bahadur Shastri, India's former Prime Minister, coined the iconic slogan "Jai Jawan, Jai Kisan" ("hail the soldier, hail the farmer") in 1965 amidst numerous challenges, including the Indo-Pak conflict and agricultural crisis. The slogan emphasizes the vital role of both soldiers and farmers in India's well-being and security.
Shastri's tenure as Prime Minister was marked by his swift actions during the conflict, which resulted in a ceasefire on Pakistan's terms. He also prioritized agriculture, allocating funds and reforms to lay the foundation for the Green Revolution and empowered key figures in the sector.
Over the years, the slogan has evolved, with subsequent leaders adding "Jai Vigyan" (hail science) and "Jai Anusandhan" (hail research) to highlight the importance of scientific advancement and research.

item.title: What is grey zone warfare, mentioned by India’s Chief of Defence Staff recently?
item.description:
In the 2024 Raisina Dialogue, General Anil Chauhan introduced "grey zone warfare" as the latest form of informal warfare, citing examples from the South China Sea and China's actions around Taiwan. Grey zone warfare involves actions that fall between direct conflict and peace, such as economic operations, influence campaigns, and cyberattacks.
Experts believe grey zone warfare has emerged due to factors like nuclear weapons and technological advancements, making direct conflicts too costly. It allows countries to pursue objectives covertly or with obfuscated attribution.
Grey zone warfare methods include economic sanctions, disinformation campaigns, and proxy wars. Russia and China have been associated with such tactics. For instance, China's presence in the South China Sea and Taiwan's complaints about increased Chinese military activity are examples of grey zone warfare.
While grey zone warfare poses challenges different from open conflicts, experts warn that it can escalate in multiple dimensions and become difficult to manage. It can also be used to bait adversaries into escalation, normalize disputed claims, and project strength.

item.title: Bribes for votes: Why SC will decide if MLAs and MPs immune from criminal prosecution
item.description: The Supreme Court is considering overturning a 1998 ruling that granted legislators immunity from bribery charges in Parliament and Legislative Assemblies. Articles 105(2) and 194(2) of the Constitution provide this protection, which was interpreted literally in the P.V. Narasimha Rao case. However, a seven-judge bench led by Chief Justice D.Y. Chandrachud is examining the issue, focusing on whether the purpose of these articles was to protect legislators from criminal prosecution, the definition of "in respect of," and when the offense of bribery is complete. Senior advocates Raju Ramachandran and P.S. Patwalia argue for a narrow interpretation of the immunity, while Attorney General R. Vankataramani and Solicitor General Tushar Mehta advocate for reconsideration. The court will ultimately decide whether to maintain or overrule the P.V. Narasimha judgement.

item.title: What is the military significance of the airstrip that India has developed for Mauritius?
item.description: Prime Minister Modi and Mauritian Prime Minister Jugnauth inaugurated an airstrip and jetty built by India on Agaléga Islands. Despite denials, reports suggest the airstrip could be developed into a military base. The project aims to enhance India's reach in the Indian Ocean, especially amidst China's growing influence. The initiative is part of India's 'Neighbourhood First Policy' with Mauritius and involves Indian Navy detachments and the supply of defense equipment. India is also strengthening ties with neighboring countries such as Seychelles, Madagascar, and certain African nations, while its relationship with the Maldives has been affected by political changes.

item.title: Why did stock exchanges conduct special trading sessions today?
item.description:
The Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) and National Stock Exchange (NSE) conducted live trading sessions on Saturday as part of the SEBI's plan for disaster recovery sites (DRS).
These sessions tested the stock exchanges' ability to switch their trading systems to DRS locations in case of disruptions. The exchanges conducted the sessions in two phases, ensuring a smooth transition of trading activities and preserving data integrity.
The DRS framework aims to ensure that trading continues without interruptions in the event of an outage. Stock exchanges conducted the special trading sessions based on discussions with SEBI to ensure the effectiveness of these DRS sites.

item.title: What India’s latest leopard population estimates suggest
item.description: According to the 'Status of Leopards in India, 2022' report, India's leopard population has increased to 13,874 from 12,852 in 2018. Central India and Eastern Ghats have the highest population of leopards. Madhya Pradesh has the largest population, followed by Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Tamil Nadu. While tiger populations have positively impacted leopard populations in some areas, they have also negatively impacted them in others. Poaching, habitat loss, and road accidents remain significant threats to leopards. Leopard-human conflict is also a growing issue due to leopards' adaptability and presence outside protected areas. States like Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Kerala have reported numerous fatal attacks and human-leopard encounters.

item.title: Is the President immune from prosecution? US Supreme Court to decide on Trump case
item.description:
The Supreme Court (SCOTUS) is considering whether former President Donald Trump has immunity from criminal charges for attempting to overturn the 2020 election. Trump faces conspiracy charges related to the January 6th Capitol attack.
The Constitution does not specify presidential immunity, but SCOTUS ruled in United States v Nixon (1974) that the President can be required to testify and produce evidence in criminal cases. However, the question of whether a President can be prosecuted while in office remains unanswered.
Trump argues that the "absolute immunity" granted to former President Nixon in Nixon v Fitzgerald (1982) should extend to criminal liability for actions taken during office.
In contrast to the US, India's President and Governors have absolute immunity from criminal prosecution during their terms. However, the Prime Minister and Chief Ministers have no such protection and can be treated like ordinary citizens in court.

item.title: Obesity on the rise, high levels of undernutrition persist in India: What a new study says
item.description:
India faces a double burden of obesity and undernutrition. Over the past 32 years, obesity has surged, particularly in women with a 9.8% prevalence in 2022. Childhood obesity has also increased significantly. Despite declining, undernutrition remains high, with India having the highest prevalence of thinness in girls and the second highest in boys globally.
Socioeconomic factors play a role, with junk food being more accessible and affordable than nutritious options. Obesity is more prevalent in urban areas and among the better-off, while undernutrition persists in remote and poor regions.
Obesity contributes to non-communicable diseases, while undernutrition increases susceptibility to these conditions later in life. The study recommends addressing both issues through programs that promote healthy nutrition and weight loss support.

item.title: Decoding China: National People’s Congress meets at bad time
item.description: Chinese Prime Minister Li Qiang, despite economic headwinds, remains optimistic, using weather metaphors to predict a brighter future. Despite a global downturn, reduced demand, and a struggling real estate industry, Li aims to revitalize China's economy. The key challenge is reaching the 5% growth threshold in 2024. Li's upcoming report to Parliament will outline his plan to boost internal consumption and attract foreign investment. Germany plays a significant role in this growth strategy, with record levels of FDI. Visa liberalization measures have been implemented to encourage investment from Germany and other EU nations, demonstrating China's eagerness for international business collaboration.

item.title: Why have GDP and GVA growth rates diverged in Q3?
item.description:
India's GDP grew by an unexpected 8.4% in Q3 of 2023-24, surpassing RBI estimates of 6.5%. This helped raise the full-year estimate to 7.6%. Growth was driven by manufacturing, mining, construction, and services, while agriculture contracted.
However, there is a discrepancy between GDP and GVA growth, with GDP growing at 8.4% and GVA at 6.5%. This is due to lower-than-expected annual GDP deflator and a sharp rise in net taxes.
Investment growth supported GDP, while private consumption growth remained subdued. The government attributed the GVA-GDP divergence to a fall in subsidies.
Economists believe GDP deflator growth could lead to lower real GDP growth in the future. They emphasize monitoring consumption growth and private investments for sustained growth.

item.title: Expert Explains: How the development of Agaléga figures in India’s vision for its maritime neighbourhood
item.description: Prime Minister Modi and Prime Minister Jugnauth inaugurated an airstrip and jetty on Agaléga Island, which belongs to Mauritius. The development aims to enhance socio-economic security for Mauritius and aligns with India's maritime vision. These facilities will improve the well-being of the island's inhabitants and create employment opportunities. They will also strengthen Mauritius' government presence and enable better monitoring of their Exclusive Economic Zone. India and Mauritius have close historical and cultural ties, with 70% of Mauritians having Indian origin. India's commitment to the SAGAR vision and willingness to assist maritime nations are underscored by this joint development. India respects sovereignty and has a track record of providing material support, information exchange, and joint exercises with Mauritius, but only upon request and in accordance with established mechanisms. India's development aid is not intended to create debt traps or violate sovereignty.

item.title: Bengaluru bomb blast: What are improvised explosive devices, or IEDs?
item.description: An explosion at Rameshwaram Cafe in Bengaluru, which injured nine people, was caused by an improvised explosive device (IED), not a gas leak. Karnataka's Chief Minister confirmed the incident after reviewing CCTV footage. The article explains that IEDs are homemade bombs that can vary greatly in form and have been used for over a century. They consist of an initiator, switch, main charge, power source, and container, and may include shrapnel or hazardous materials to increase damage. Common materials for IEDs include fertilizers, gunpowder, and hydrogen peroxide. IEDs have been used historically in various attacks in India and are also used as distractions in war zones. The extent of damage depends on the IED's size, construction, and placement. The article also mentions the transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan by the Election Commission of India due to allegations of misuse of public office.

item.title: Can you be sued for defamation if you retweet defamatory content?
item.description:
The Supreme Court has stayed a trial against Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal for retweeting an allegedly defamatory YouTube video. Retweeting may not always imply endorsement, according to the court. Kejriwal's counsel admitted the post was a mistake.
In Indian law, defamation can be civil (libel/slander) or criminal (IPC Section 499). Criminal defamation requires proof beyond reasonable doubt and carries up to two years' imprisonment. The Supreme Court has upheld the constitutionality of criminal defamation laws, but reasonable restrictions can be imposed under Article 19(2).
The Delhi High Court had ruled that retweeting defamatory content prima facie attracts liability. However, the Supreme Court has observed that retweeting may simply be sharing information and not an endorsement. The case will proceed with further hearings.

item.title: How climate change has fuelled farmers’ protests in Europe
item.description: European farmers are protesting due to rising costs, cheap imports, and the impact of climate change on agriculture. The EU's environmental regulations, aimed at reducing GHG emissions, have further exacerbated the situation. Farmers argue that these regulations are too strict, unfair, and economically unviable, especially with the added burden of energy costs and competition from Ukraine's neighbors. The backlash has led to a rollback of some regulations, but the EU still needs to curtail emissions from the sector to meet its Green Deal targets without further igniting farmer unrest.

item.title: Sensex, Nifty jump above 1 per cent: What has led to this gain?
item.description:
Benchmark indices Sensex and Nifty surged over 1% following the release of better-than-expected GDP growth of 8.4% for Q3 FY24. Key contributors include strong growth in manufacturing, construction, and capital formation.
Experts attribute the market rally to the solid GDP numbers and highlight the potential for large caps like Reliance Industries, Bharti Airtel, and ICICI Bank to lead the surge. However, tepid private consumption might impact consumer staples stocks.
While fixed investment remains a key driver of growth, consumption lags behind. The services sector shows resilience, but agriculture underperforms.
Despite the positive GDP data, Nomura projects a more moderate growth of 6.1% in 2024 and 6.2% in FY25 due to factors such as the impact of elections on public spending and weak consumption.

item.title: Why the Supreme Court overturned its 2018 decision, which set a time limit on courts’ stay orders
item.description:
In 2018, the Supreme Court (SC) aimed to address delayed trials by automatically vacating stay orders by High Courts after six months. However, in 2023, a five-judge SC bench has overturned this ruling, citing concerns about "doing injustice" by nullifying lawful stay orders.
The bench held that constitutional courts should avoid setting precise timelines for case decisions, leaving discretion to lower courts familiar with local issues. They emphasized that High Courts should prioritize applications to vacate stay orders to ensure faster disposal of cases.
The ruling was based on arguments that automatic vacation of stay orders without due process violates principles of judicial fairness and that setting timelines is within Parliament's legislative powers, not the court's.

item.title: India-built airstrip inaugurated in Agaléga, Mauritius: Its strategic significance vis-a-vis Maldives and China
item.description:
Indian technical personnel have replaced Indian military personnel on one of three aviation platforms in the Maldives. India also inaugurated an airstrip and jetty on Mauritius' Agaléga Island, strategically located in the Indian Ocean.
Mauritius and the Maldives are crucial outposts for India due to their maritime and strategic significance. China's increasing presence in the region has heightened India's concerns. India's withdrawal of military personnel from the Maldives follows pro-China President Mohamed Muizzu's request.
After an MoU signed in 2015, India upgraded the airstrip on Agaléga Island to enhance Mauritius' capabilities in safeguarding its interests and monitoring its Exclusive Economic Zone. Despite domestic criticism, Mauritius has managed the situation better than the Maldives, where former Foreign Minister Abdulla Shahid disputes claims of foreign military presence.
India's presence in the Indian Ocean supports its maritime security interests and strengthens its relationships with island nations. However, domestic politics in these nations can influence their policies and India must navigate its diplomatic efforts carefully.

item.title: First semiconductor fabrication plant can help plug in to global value chain
item.description:
The Union Cabinet has approved semiconductor projects worth ₹1.26 lakh crore, with the key highlight being Tata Group's partnership with TSMC to establish a semiconductor fabrication plant in India. This plant will produce semiconductor wafers for various industries, including high-performance computing and microcontrollers. The plant's construction is expected to begin in three months.
The plant is significant for India's semiconductor ambitions, as domestic manufacturing of these wafers is crucial for meeting national needs. The plant is part of a government-funded initiative to boost the domestic semiconductor industry, including a ₹76,000 crore chip incentive scheme.
Semiconductors are complex products requiring specialized facilities (fabs) for manufacturing. India aims to develop its semiconductor ecosystem by attracting foreign companies and promoting domestic research. Challenges include attracting highly skilled talent and fostering original semiconductor design research, but the government is investing in R&D to address these issues.

item.title: Explained: Red Bull team principal Christian Horner cleared in mysterious probe, but fate in F1 uncertain
item.description:
Formula One has been embroiled in controversy before the start of its 2024 season. Rumors abound about Lewis Hamilton's possible move to Ferrari, while Christian Horner, Red Bull team principal, has been cleared by an internal investigation into allegations of inappropriate behavior.
Despite the clearance, Horner's future in F1 remains uncertain as details of the allegations against him remain undisclosed. This lack of transparency has led to speculation and placed Red Bull, F1, and stakeholders like sponsors and drivers in a precarious position.
Mercedes team principal Toto Wolff and driver Lewis Hamilton have called for greater clarity, while Verstappen has expressed trust in the process. Red Bull's dominance in recent years is at stake, with Horner's departure potentially leaving the team in uncharted territory.

item.title: PM Modi launches hydrogen-powered ferry: features, significance
item.description: India has launched its first domestically built hydrogen fuel cell ferry, named "Harit Nauka." Built by Cochin Shipyard Limited, the ferry has a 24-meter catamaran design and can accommodate 50 passengers. It is eco-friendly, with zero emissions, noise, and energy efficiency due to its hydrogen fuel cell technology, which generates electricity using hydrogen and releases only water. The ferry uses a 50-kW PEM fuel cell with Lithium-Ion Phosphate batteries, developed by KPIT Technologies and the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research Labs. India has now indigenously developed hydrogen fuel cell systems, giving it an advantage in the marine sector. The "Harit Nauka" initiative aims to transition inland vessels to green fuels, with the ferry as a pilot project.

item.title: How does a chatbot remember the prompts you gave it? Understanding context windows
item.description:
ChatGPT is a chatbot powered by GPT 3.5 or GPT-4, a large language model (LLM). The chatbot interacts with users through a chat interface, similar to messengers.
Context windows are crucial for AI models to recall information during a conversation. The size of the context window determines the amount of information the model can consider at once to generate responses. Larger context windows provide more information but require more computational power and can lead to irrelevant information being included.
GPT-4 Turbo has a massive context window of 128K tokens, while Google Gemini 1.5 Pro has a context window of up to 1 million tokens. While larger windows can enhance accuracy, they come with challenges such as increased computational power, memory bandwidth, and storage requirements. Additionally, large context windows can result in repetitive or contradictory responses and a higher carbon footprint.

item.title: Why homesexuality is ‘natural’ in the animal kingdom
item.description: Researchers observed male humpback whales engaging in sexual activity for the first time in 2022. Homosexuality is prevalent in many animal species, attributed to both biological and environmental factors. Despite reproductive implications, homosexuality persists due to hypotheses such as "indiscriminate mating," where individuals indiscriminately mate without recognizing sex. Other hypotheses suggest adaptive functions, such as fostering social bonds and reducing intrasexual aggression. Studies have found a correlation between same-sex sexual behavior and sociality, and evidence indicates it may mitigate adulticide in males. Same-sex sexual behavior is considered a convergent adaptation in mammals, providing survival benefits.

item.title: Who is Abdul Karim ‘Tunda’, linked to 40 terrorist bombings, and now acquitted in one case?
item.description:
Abdul Karim "Tunda," an alleged bomb expert and Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT) operative, has been acquitted in a 1993 train blasts case. The acquittal comes despite being linked to numerous terrorist attacks over the years.
Tunda, born in 1943, joined the neo-fundamentalist sect after witnessing communal violence during the Ram Janmabhoomi movement. He later traveled to Pakistan and received training in explosives from the ISI.
After the Babri Masjid demolition in 1992, Tunda is suspected of being involved in several bombings, including the December 6, 1993, train blasts. He was also accused of raising funds and scouting recruits for LeT.
Apprehended in 2013, Tunda faced multiple cases, but was acquitted in most. Despite being convicted in a 1996 blast case, the Punjab and Haryana High Court later commuted his sentence.

item.title: Why Apple has shelved its car project: Vehicles are now more about software than hardware
item.description:
Apple has ended its 10-year electric self-driving car project, Project Titan, to focus on generative AI and mixed-reality headsets. The shift from mechanical to software-driven vehicles has made car manufacturing more software-centric, giving Apple an advantage due to its expertise in this area.
Apple's CarPlay smartphone integration platform, supported by most new US cars, has allowed it to dominate the car software experience. CarPlay has fostered customer loyalty and given Apple control over driver data, which is expected to become increasingly valuable in the future.
The growing demand for connectivity and digital offerings in cars is driving a shift towards software integration, creating opportunities for companies like Apple. Legacy automakers are facing software challenges and are actively hiring software engineers to address this gap.

item.title: Did Morarji Desai really drink his own urine?
item.description:
The article discusses two notable aspects of former Indian Prime Minister Morarji Desai's life. Firstly, he was born on February 29, 1896, and celebrated fewer than 25 birthdays due to the rarity of leap days. Secondly, he was known for consuming his urine, a practice that has become a subject of both humor and serious discussion.
In 1978, during Desai's tenure as Prime Minister, he sought to realign India's foreign policy, moving away from its pro-Soviet stance and improving relations with the United States. This included a state visit to the U.S. and hosting President Jimmy Carter in India.
The article highlights an interview with journalist Dan Rather where Desai, then over 80 years old, attributed his good health to a diet of natural foods and the daily consumption of urine, which he defended as a natural treatment with historical and cultural significance in India. Desai claimed that urine therapy could purify the body and cure diseases at no cost.
