item.description: Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced the expansion of Nano DAP application across all agro-climatic zones in India. Nano DAP, a more efficient and cost-effective alternative to conventional di-ammonium phosphate (DAP), is expected to aid in achieving self-sufficiency in fertilizer production and benefit farmers. The product, launched by Home Minister Amit Shah and produced domestically in Gujarat, is in liquid form and boasts a smaller particle size for better assimilation in plants, leading to increased crop yields. It is also cheaper and more convenient for farmers to use. The expansion aligns with the government's goal to reduce fertilizer imports and enhance food grain production.

item.title: Why two Bombay HC judges have differed on Centre’s ‘fake news’ fact check rule
item.description: The Bombay High Court delivered a split verdict on the IT Rules amendment, which allows the government to flag "fake news" on social media. Justice Patel struck down the amendment, citing it as censorship and an overreach of government power, while Justice Gokhale upheld it, dismissing claims of bias and stating that the rules do not penalize content unless it's patently false with malicious intent. The matter will now be referred to a third judge for a final decision, as the two judges' opinions differed. The Centre has agreed not to notify the Fact Check Unit for another 10 days. The article also mentions the transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan by the Election Commission due to alleged misuse of public office.

item.title: Interim Budget 2024: What Sitharaman said about withdrawing old tax demands, who will benefit
item.description:
The Interim Budget 2024 has introduced a proposal to alleviate the burden of old tax disputes for taxpayers. **Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman** announced the government's plan to withdraw outstanding direct tax demands up to **Rs 25,000** for the period up to FY09-10 and up to **Rs 10,000** for FY10-11 to FY14-15. This move is expected to benefit about **one crore taxpayers**, particularly those who have been consistent with their recent tax filings but have not received refunds due to these pending demands.
The Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT) has implemented a demand management facilitation system to address issues where refunds are held up, resolving over **1.4 lakh cases** in the past year. The filing of Income-tax Returns (ITRs) has seen a significant increase, with **8.18 crore ITRs** filed for the assessment year 2023-2024, marking a **9% increase** from the previous year.
Income tax revenues are projected to constitute **19%** of the government's financial resources in FY25, with corporate tax at **17%**, GST at **18%**, and borrowings at **28%**. Additionally, the Election Commission of India has transferred Sujata R Karthikeyan from the Mission Shakti department following allegations of misuse of public office for electoral influence.

item.title: Interim Budget 2024: Concerns over GDP, spending cuts; fiscal deficit is bright spot
item.description:
Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman presented the interim Union Budget for 2024-25, focusing on the past achievements of the Modi government rather than new initiatives. The budget highlighted a nominal GDP growth of 10.5% for the coming year, with a real GDP growth rate adjusted for inflation projected between 6% to 6.5%. The fiscal deficit target is ambitiously set at 5.1% of GDP for FY25 and 4.5% for FY26, aiming to reduce borrowing costs for the private sector.
The government's expenditure is categorized into revenue and capital, with capital expenditure (capex) being more beneficial for economic growth. Despite setting a high capex target of Rs 10 lakh crore, the actual expenditure was Rs 9.5 lakh crore. Concerns were raised about reduced spending in key areas like health and education, as well as cuts in schemes for disadvantaged groups.
Income tax revenues are expected to be the largest contributor to government resources at 19%, followed by corporate tax and GST. The budget reflects a trend of fiscal consolidation and a focus on capital expenditure to stimulate economic growth. President Joe Biden's remarks on immigration and xenophobia were also noted, emphasizing the positive impact of immigrants on the US economy.

item.title: Budget 2024 Speech Highlights, Explained: On Fiscal Deficit, no changes to indirect or direct taxes
item.description:
The Interim Budget for 2024 presented by Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman focused on the government's vision for a 'Viksit Bharat' (Developed India) by 2047, emphasizing harmony with nature, modern infrastructure, and opportunities for all. Key highlights include:
- **No changes** to taxation, maintaining direct and indirect tax rates, and import duties. - **Fiscal deficit target** set at 5.1% of GDP for FY25, with a goal to reduce it below 4% by 2025-26. - **Capital investment outlay** increased by 11.1% to ₹11.11 lakh crore, representing 3.4% of GDP. - **MGNREGS allocation** of ₹86,000 crore, equal to the current year's revised estimate. - **Pradhan Mantri Awaas Yojana-Gramin (PMAY-G)**: 2 crore more houses to be built in the next five years. - **HPV vaccine** to be included in the immunization program for girls aged 9 to 14 to prevent cervical cancer. - **Financial corpus of ₹1 lakh crore** established for interest-free loans to incentivize private sector research and development. - **Digital Public Infrastructure** highlighted as a key factor in the economy's formalization. - **25 crore people** lifted out of poverty in the past decade, with significant savings from direct benefit transfers. - **Rooftop solar systems** to be installed on 1 crore houses, with a new Suryoday Yojana to enable savings and support electric vehicle adoption.
The budget refrained from populist announcements, aligning with the themes of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's campaign for re-election. It also included measures for agricultural self-sufficiency, blue economy initiatives, and expansion of the Ayushman Bharat insurance scheme. The government's approach is encapsulated in the principles of "Reform, Perform, and Transform," aiming for robust economic growth and comprehensive development.

item.title: India Budget 2024 Live Updates, explained: Making sense of the numbers, new announcements
item.description:
The Interim Budget for 2024, presented by Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman, focused on the government's vision for a 'Viksit Bharat' (Developed India) by 2047, emphasizing harmony with nature, modern infrastructure, and opportunities for all citizens. Key highlights include:
- **No changes to taxation**: Direct and indirect tax rates, as well as import duties, remain unchanged. - **Fiscal deficit target**: Set at 5.1% of GDP for FY25, with a goal to reduce it to below 4% by 2025-26. - **Capital investment outlay**: Increased by 11.1% to ₹11.11 lakh crore, representing 3.4% of GDP. - **MGNREGS allocation**: ₹86,000 crore, equal to the current year's revised estimate and 43% higher than the budget estimate. - **PMAY-G**: 2 crore more houses to be built in the next five years, aiming to achieve the target of 3 crore houses. - **Health initiatives**: Inclusion of the HPV vaccine in the immunisation program and expansion of the Ayushman Bharat insurance scheme. - **R&D incentives**: Establishment of a ₹1 lakh crore corpus for interest-free loans for research. - **Digital Public Infrastructure**: Highlighted as a key factor in the economy's formalization. - **Poverty reduction**: 25 crore people lifted out of poverty in the past decade. - **Agriculture**: Strategy for self-sufficiency in oil seeds and expansion of Nano DAP application. - **Solar energy**: New Suryoday Yojana for rooftop solar systems to enable savings and support electric vehicle adoption.
The interim budget serves as a precursor to the full-fledged budget expected after the general elections, reflecting the incumbent government's achievements and setting the stage for the upcoming electoral campaign. The focus remains on governance, development, performance, and economic stability.

item.title: RBI action against Paytm: probable causes, effects, and what happens to your money
item.description: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has imposed restrictions on Paytm Payments Bank, barring it from offering key services like account creation and wallets starting March, due to "persistent non-compliances and material supervisory concerns." Customers can still withdraw or use their existing balances without restrictions. Paytm, a leader in India's fintech space with over 100 million KYC-verified customers, has been under RBI scrutiny since 2018, particularly for KYC compliance and IT-related issues. The bank's parent company, One97 Communications, has been directed to terminate its nodal accounts by February 29, with all transactions to be settled by March 15. In response, Paytm's shares dropped, and the company is taking steps to comply with RBI's directions, expecting a potential impact of Rs 300-500 crore on its annual EBITDA. Paytm will continue its merchant services and expand partnerships with other banks, while its offline merchant payment network remains unaffected. The RBI's stringent actions follow previous fines and directives due to regulatory non-compliance, including a halt in onboarding new customers in March 2022. Concerns over data access by China-based entities, given the tense India-China relations, have also contributed to the scrutiny. Paytm's founder Vijay Shekhar Sharma holds a part-time chairman position at the bank.

item.title: Biden says will respond to Jordan attack: Options US has, risks it must weigh
item.description:
The article discusses the United States' potential response to a deadly drone attack in Jordan that killed three service members and wounded over 40. President Joe Biden has confirmed the US will retaliate but has not disclosed specifics, aiming to avoid a broader Middle East war. The attack has prompted calls for a strong response, with options ranging from direct strikes within Iran to targeting Iranian-backed militia groups in Iraq and Syria. The US has previously conducted limited strikes against these militias and may consider a "tiered approach" involving multiple actions over time.
Officials believe Iran is responsible for supporting the militias behind the attacks on US forces. A direct strike on Iran is seen as a strong message but carries risks of escalation. Alternatives include targeting Iranian assets or leaders outside Iran, as was done in the 2020 drone strike that killed Quds Force leader Gen. Qassem Soleimani.
Congressional members are divided on the response, with some advocating for direct action against Iran and others urging restraint to avoid further conflict. Economic sanctions are also being considered as a non-military option to cut off funding to Iran and its proxies.
The article concludes with unrelated content regarding the Election Commission of India's actions against Sujata R Karthikeyan, which has been omitted from this summary.

item.title: What is ‘Vyasji ka tehkhana’ inside the Gyanvapi mosque complex, where a Varanasi court has allowed puja
item.description:
The Varanasi District Court has permitted prayers in the southern cellar of the Gyanvapi mosque complex, known as 'Vyasji ka tehkhana'. The court directed the District Magistrate of Varanasi to make arrangements for worship within seven days. This decision follows the administration's takeover of the cellar on January 24, after a court order on January 17 appointed the district magistrate as the receiver.
The case was initiated by Shailendra Pathak Vyas, head priest of Acharya Ved Vyas Peeth temple. The tehkhana, facing the Nandi statue in the Kashi Vishwanath complex, has been a site of worship for the Vyas family for over 200 years, but was halted in December 1993. The prohibition of worship in the tehkhana was linked to the Mulayam Singh Yadav government's law and order policies following the Babri Mosque demolition.
The petitioner, Shailendra Pathak Vyas, is the maternal grandson of Pandit Somnath Vyas and currently serves as the head priest at the Acharya Ved Vyas Peeth. The tehkhana was historically provided to the Vyas family for worship and has been in their care since 1809. During a recent survey, idols of Hindu deities were found inside, supporting the family's historical claims to the site. The article also mentions an unrelated political issue regarding the transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan by the Election Commission of India due to alleged misuse of public office.

item.title: How the post of deputy CM emerged, what powers it comes with
item.description: The article discusses the political significance of the Deputy Chief Minister (Deputy CM) position in Indian states, particularly in the context of Bihar's recent government formation. Nitish Kumar, aligning again with the BJP, appointed two Deputy CMs, signaling political strategies ahead of national elections. The role of Deputy CMs is not constitutionally defined but is seen as equivalent to a Cabinet Minister. Currently, 13 states have Deputy CMs, with Andhra Pradesh having the most at five. The practice has become more common since the decline of Congress's dominance post-1967. Historical examples include Anugrah Narayan Sinha, the first Deputy CM of Bihar, and others who later became Chief Ministers themselves. The article also touches on the history of Deputy Prime Ministers in India, noting that the title does not confer the powers of a Prime Minister. Lastly, it mentions President Joe Biden's remarks on the positive impact of immigrants in the US and his criticism of xenophobia.

item.title: Delhi’s property geo-tagging deadline extended: All you need to know about the MCD excercise
item.description: The Municipal Corporation of Delhi (MCD) has extended the deadline for property geo-tagging to **February 29, 2024**, offering a **10% refund** on advance tax payments for compliance. Geo-tagging, which assigns geographic coordinates to properties, is expected to enhance tax collection by identifying tax defaulters and unauthorized properties, thereby aiding urban planning and service delivery. Despite its potential benefits, residents have expressed concerns over technical difficulties, lack of awareness, and fear of government scrutiny. Other cities in India have also explored geo-tagging for various urban management purposes. Separately, the Election Commission has transferred Sujata R Karthikeyan, a bureaucrat and wife of a political leader, following allegations of misuse of office for electoral gains.

item.title: ExplainSpeaking: 4 aspects of govt finances that the Budget speech won’t tell you
item.description: The article discusses the upcoming interim Union Budget for India's financial year 2024-25, which will be presented by Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman. It is expected to highlight the incumbent government's achievements over the past decade, with the full Budget to be presented after the general elections in July. The article provides analytical tools to understand the Budget's claims, focusing on the significance of pie charts showing the government's income sources and expenditure. It notes an increase in government borrowing from 21% to 34% of total income since 2016-17 and a decrease in defense and subsidy spending. The article emphasizes understanding the difference between nominal and real figures, considering inflation's impact on purchasing power and budget allocations. It also explains the importance of the nominal GDP growth rate and fiscal deficit, highlighting changes in fiscal prudence over time. The article concludes by explaining Budget Estimates (BE) and Revised Estimates (RE), their comparisons, and their implications for understanding government spending and promises. It encourages readers to critically analyze Budget data and engage in informed discussions.

item.title: Test tube rhinos: Why rebuilding doomed species is a desperate race against time
item.description: The article discusses the efforts of scientists to rebuild the northern white rhino population through in vitro fertilization (IVF). They have achieved the first-ever rhino pregnancy by transferring a lab-made rhino embryo into a surrogate mother. The process of preparing a surrogate mother, particularly a southern white rhino, is complex and requires careful monitoring of the fertile window for implanting the embryo. However, even with successful IVF and surrogacy, the genetic viability of the northern white rhino population remains a challenge. One potential solution is to create sperm and eggs from stem cells extracted from preserved tissue samples. The article also highlights the importance of raising the first batch of IVF northern white calves with northern white adults to learn the social and behavioral skills of the species. The project is funded by the German government and other donors, but there have been questions raised about whether resources should be allocated to other endangered species. The article emphasizes the urgency of conservation efforts, as the northern white rhino was declared extinct in the wild in 2008.

item.title: US-China rivalry: Where does Thailand stand?
item.description: The article discusses a significant diplomatic event where Bangkok hosted a meeting between the US National Security Advisor and China's Foreign Minister, highlighting Thailand's neutral stance amidst US-China tensions. The talks covered various geopolitical issues, with further discussions planned between US President Biden and Chinese leader Xi Jinping. The event is seen as a diplomatic win for Thailand and an endorsement of Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin's government by Washington. The article also notes the strengthening ties between the US and Thailand, despite past conflicts, and the ongoing economic relationship between Thailand and China, exemplified by a new visa waiver agreement. Overall, the meeting underscores Thailand's role as a welcoming host for international diplomacy without taking sides.

item.title: Explained: The 2021 murder case of Kerala BJP leader, in which 15 got death sentence
item.description:
The article discusses the sentencing of 15 PFI-SDPI activists to death by an additional sessions court in Kerala for the murder of BJP leader Ranjith Sreenivasan. Ranjith, a 45-year-old advocate and BJP's OBC morcha state secretary, was an influential figure in the party and had contested the 2016 Assembly elections. He was also involved in welfare measures for coastal communities.
The background of the violence is rooted in the tensions between the Sangh Parivar and PFI in Alappuzha, which escalated in 2021 with several political killings. Ranjith's murder was a retaliation for the killing of an RSS worker, Nandu R Krishna, and was part of a series of tit-for-tat killings between the two groups.
The court's decision for the death sentence was based on the heinous nature of the crime, committed in the victim's home in front of his family, and the lack of potential for reform among the convicts, who showed no remorse and believed they were morally justified. The case is described as a "rarest of rare" due to the brutality and premeditation involved.
Additionally, the article mentions the ongoing trial for the murder of SDPI state general secretary K S Shan, with the accused RSS members currently on bail, and the appointment of a special prosecutor for the case. It also briefly touches on a separate issue involving the transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan by the Election Commission of India due to allegations of misuse of public office.

item.title: Why Centre plans to replace the Indian Stamp Act, 1899 with a new law
item.description: The Indian government is considering replacing the Indian Stamp Act of 1899 with a new bill to modernize the stamp duty system. The proposed 'Indian Stamp Bill, 2023' aims to address the current Act's shortcomings, such as the lack of provisions for digital e-stamping and uniform legislation across all states. The new bill introduces electronic stamps and digital signatures, aligning with the Information Technology Act, 2000. It also suggests increasing penalties for violations, with a maximum fine of Rs 25,000 and a daily penalty of Rs 1,000 for repeated offenses. The Ministry of Finance has invited public suggestions on the draft bill. Additionally, the article mentions the Election Commission's transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan due to allegations of misusing her public office for electoral gains.

item.title: How – and why – the Archaeological Survey of India surveyed the Gyanvapi mosque
item.description: The Archeological Survey of India (ASI) has released an 839-page report following a physical survey of the Gyanvapi mosque, indicating the existence of a Hindu temple prior to the mosque at the site. The ASI was directed by the Varanasi district court to investigate if the mosque was built over a Hindu temple. The survey involved non-invasive techniques like Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR), documentation, and photography, avoiding excavation due to the site's sensitivity. A 50-member team led by Alok Tripathi conducted the three-month survey, which did not include areas sealed by the Supreme Court. Hindu petitioners have approached the Supreme Court to allow the ASI to investigate an object found in the mosque's water tank, claimed to be a Shivling by Hindus and a fountain by Muslims. The ASI's report is said to be based on scientific techniques and is ready for judicial scrutiny, while the All India Muslim Personal Law Board disputes its conclusiveness.

item.title: Why Meghalaya’s new state anthem has led to a controversy over the state’s Jaintia tribe
item.description: Meghalaya marked its 52nd statehood day by releasing an official state anthem, which was not performed on Republic Day due to the absence of a Standard Operating Procedure. Controversy arose because the anthem, featuring Khasi, Garo, and English, excluded the Jaintia language. Jaintia groups demand the inclusion of Pnar, emphasizing their distinct identity and history, including their own freedom fighters like U Kiang Nangbah. The government's selection of languages for the anthem is based on the Meghalaya State Language Act of 2005, which recognizes English and Khasi as official languages, with Garo as an associate language in certain districts. The government argues that including Jaintia would require changes to the act and could lead to further demands from other tribes. Some emphasize the commonalities among the Khasi and Jaintia, citing shared myths and ancestry, suggesting a cohesive community. The debate highlights the complexities of cultural representation and language in the state's identity.

item.title: What is the cipher case, in which former Pak PM Imran Khan has been sentenced to 10 years in jail?
item.description: Former Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan and ex-Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi were sentenced to 10 years in jail for the cipher case involving the disclosure of a classified cable sent by Pakistan’s ambassador in Washington. The cable, which remains largely undisclosed, reportedly contained a US official's remarks on Imran's visit to Russia during the Ukraine invasion, hinting at potential consequences if a no-confidence vote against him succeeded. Imran has claimed the cable as evidence of a US conspiracy to oust him, which he first discussed publicly in March 2022. Following his ouster, the Pakistan Muslim League (N) government accused him of exposing an official secret, leading to an FIR and his conviction in another case. He remains imprisoned and is barred from the upcoming elections.

item.title: Why hybrid vehicles could be a cleaner solution for India than EVs, at least for the next 7-10 years
item.description:
HSBC Research suggests that India should focus on hybrid vehicles as a practical solution for the next 5-10 years to aid in decarbonisation and reduce pollution. Hybrids, which combine an internal combustion engine with an electric motor, are currently less polluting than electric vehicles (EVs) and petrol/diesel cars. The report highlights that hybrids emit 133 g/km of carbon, which is 16% less than EVs at 158 g/km, and significantly lower than petrol and diesel vehicles.
The transition to EVs is supported by tax incentives, but the adoption faces challenges such as the need for state subsidies, charging infrastructure, and the current reliance on coal-fired power plants for electricity. The analysis indicates that emissions from hybrids and EVs will equalize when non-fossil power generation in India reaches 44%. By 2030, even with a 40% non-fossil fuel share, hybrids will still be 8% less polluting than EVs.
The article also discusses the global lithium value chain and India's dependence on imports for EV battery production, suggesting the exploration of alternatives to Li-ion batteries. The summary omits unrelated content and advertisements.

item.title: What happened at the trial of Nathuram Godse, the man who killed Gandhi?
item.description:
The article provides a detailed account of the assassination of Mahatma Gandhi by Nathuram Godse on January 30, 1948, and the subsequent trial. Godse shot Gandhi at point-blank range at Birla House in Delhi, leading to Gandhi's death within minutes. Godse was immediately apprehended and later tried at a special court in Delhi's Red Fort. The trial began in May 1948, with Godse and his co-accused, including Narayan Apte and Vinayak Savarkar, being represented by counsel of their choice.
The prosecution presented a substantial amount of evidence, including 149 witnesses and numerous exhibits. The most significant witness was Digambar Badge, who was part of the conspiracy and later turned approver. The judgment, delivered on February 10, 1949, by Judge Atma Charan, convicted Godse, Apte, and others, sentencing Godse and Apte to death while acquitting Savarkar.
The convicts appealed to the Punjab High Court, where Godse, representing himself, maintained his stance as a patriot and did not express remorse. The High Court upheld the lower court's verdict on June 21, 1949, except for acquitting two of the accused. Attempts to appeal to the Privy Council were unsuccessful, and Godse and Apte were hanged on November 15, 1949, after their mercy petitions were rejected. The article was first published in 2023.

item.title: How to grow seafood outside the sea — and why a Govt lab in Kochi has taken up this project
item.description:
The ICAR-Central Marine Fisheries Research Institute (CMFRI) in Kochi has partnered with Neat Meatt Biotech to develop lab-grown fish meat. This collaboration, underpinned by a Memorandum of Understanding, is a pioneering initiative in India. Lab-grown fish meat involves cultivating specific fish cells in a lab to produce meat that mimics the taste, texture, and nutrition of conventional fish meat without harming any animals.
CMFRI will focus on genetic, biochemical, and analytical aspects, starting with high-value species like pomfret and kingfish. Neat Meatt will optimize cell growth media and scale up production. This effort aims to meet the rising seafood demand and alleviate overfishing, offering a sustainable, contamination-free alternative.
Globally, countries like Israel, Singapore, the US, and China are advancing in lab-grown fish meat technology. The industry is growing, with over 150 companies backed by significant investments. The US has even approved the sale of lab-grown chicken meat. This project positions India alongside these nations, aiming for a sustainable seafood future. The proof of concept is expected soon, and the initiative also aligns with global efforts to produce various lab-grown meats, promoting food security and environmental benefits.

item.title: The river-linking project Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh and Centre have signed MoU for, who it helps
item.description:
Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh have signed an MoU with the Union Ministry of Jal Shakti to implement the Modified PKC-ERCP Link Project, integrating the PKC river link with the Eastern Rajasthan Canal Project (ERCP). This project is part of India's national plan for interlinking rivers. The ERCP, significant in Rajasthan, aims to transfer water within the Chambal basin to address water scarcity in 13 districts. The Modified PKC-ERCP will provide drinking and industrial water to these districts and the Malwa and Chambal regions of Madhya Pradesh, as well as irrigation over an area of 5.6 lakh hectares or more across both states.
The MoU was necessary because the original ERCP was planned based on a 50% dependable yield, contrary to the standard 75% dependable yield required for inter-state river projects. This was unacceptable to Madhya Pradesh. After deliberations, a modified proposal was created to align with the 75% dependability, incorporating components from both states' suggestions. The integration of the ERCP with the PKC Link Canal Project was decided by the Task Force on Interlinking of Rivers in 2019 and approved in December 2022. The project's DPR is being prepared, and upon its completion, a MoA will be finalized to cover various aspects of water management and sharing between the states and the Centre.

item.title: What is UNRWA, and why have Western countries paused its funding amid Gaza war?
item.description: UN officials have called for a reconsideration of the suspension of funding to the UN Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees (UNRWA), following allegations of staff involvement in a Hamas attack on Israel. The agency, which provides essential services to two million Palestinians in Gaza, faces a reduction in services if funding is not reinstated. The US and other Western countries withheld funds after Israel's accusations, which included claims of Hamas misusing UNRWA resources and promoting anti-Israel sentiments. UNRWA has denied these allegations, confirming the termination of nine staff members implicated in the attack and clarifying the status of others. The agency is vital for the survival of Gaza's population, especially after recent conflicts, and risks running out of funds for aid work without restored financial support. The article also mentions President Biden's remarks on the positive impact of immigrants in the US, contrasting it with the anti-immigrant rhetoric of his predecessor.

item.title: Explained: The origins of ‘Aaya Ram, gaya Ram’, which Kharge used after Nitish U-turn
item.description: Nitish Kumar was sworn in as the Chief Minister of Bihar for the ninth time after his party, Janata Dal (United), formed an alliance with the BJP. This move ended their previous alliance with the Mahagathbandan, which included the Congress and RLD. The term "Aaya Ram, gaya Ram" was used to describe politicians who frequently switch allegiances, originating from the actions of Haryana politician Gaya Lal in the 1960s. After winning an election as an Independent, he joined Congress, then defected to form a new party, and switched sides multiple times within hours. This term has since become synonymous with political defection, which became more prevalent as Congress's dominance declined, highlighting the importance of smaller parties and independents in forming governments. The article also mentions political defections in the 1960s and a recent order by the Election Commission of India regarding the transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan due to allegations of misuse of public office.

item.title: Why UGC’s draft guidelines sparked outrage over ‘dereservation’ in faculty recruitment
item.description:
The article discusses the controversy over the University Grants Commission (UGC)'s new draft guidelines on reservation implementation in higher education. The UGC and the Union government clarified that reserved faculty positions for SC, ST, OBC, and EWS will not be opened to the general category, countering a public outcry over a chapter in the draft that suggested reserved posts could be dereserved in exceptional cases. The draft aimed to update guidelines from 2006, reflecting changes in government instructions and court orders to clarify reservation rules. It covered quotas in faculty posts, reservation rosters, de-reservation, caste claim verification, and student admissions.
The controversy centered on the de-reservation chapter, which allowed for dereservation of reserved faculty vacancies in exceptional circumstances, a departure from current practice where reserved positions are not converted for general candidates. The draft extended dereservation to Group A, B, C, and D posts, whereas the Department of Personnel and Training (DoPT) only permits it for Group A in exceptional cases.
The government responded to the backlash by stating no new instructions permit dereservation, and reserved posts must be filled as per the 2019 Central Educational Institutions (Reservation in Teachers’ Cadre) Act. The UGC chairman confirmed that dereservation will not be included in the final guidelines. The article also mentions a separate issue regarding the Election Commission of India's transfer of an individual due to alleged misuse of public office.

item.title: Latest All India Survey of Higher Education (AISHE): What it says on female enrolment, takers for Arts and Science
item.description:
The All India Survey of Higher Education (AISHE) 2021–22 report highlights a significant increase in student enrollment in higher education across India, with a notable rise in the number of women pursuing higher education. Here are the key points from the report:
- **Total Enrollment**: There's been an increase in total student enrollment in higher education from 3.42 crore in 2014-15 to 4.33 crore in 2021-22. - **Women's Enrollment**: The number of women enrolled has jumped by 32% from 2014-15 to 2021-22, with a remarkable increase at the PhD level. - **Gross Enrollment Ratio (GER)**: The estimated GER for the age group 18-23 years is 28.4, with Chandigarh having the highest GER at 64.8%. - **Gender Parity Index (GPI)**: The GPI at the all-India level is 1.01, indicating parity between genders in higher education. - **Program Enrollment**: The Bachelor of Arts (BA) program has the highest enrollment at the undergraduate level, and the Master of Arts (MA) program leads at the postgraduate level. - **Preference for Government Institutions**: A majority of students attend government universities, and state public universities have the largest share of enrollment. - **Graduation Statistics**: In 2021-22, approximately 1.07 crore students graduated, with women constituting about 50.8% of graduates. - **Diversity**: Around 35% of students belong to Other Backward Classes (OBC), 13% to Scheduled Castes (SC), and 5.7% to Scheduled Tribes (ST).
The report also discusses the graduation rates across different streams, with arts and social sciences leading the way. Additionally, it mentions the preference of students for government educational institutions over private ones. The summary omits unrelated content such as advertisements.

item.title: What is the Islamic Resistance of Iraq, which has claimed responsibility for killing 3 US soldiers in Jordan?
item.description:
The article discusses a drone attack on a US military outpost in Jordan, which resulted in the death of three US servicemen. President Joe Biden attributed the attack to Iran-backed militant groups and vowed to hold those responsible accountable. The Islamic Resistance of Iraq (IRI) claimed responsibility for the attack, which targeted Tower 22, housing around 350 US Army and Air Force personnel. The article also touches on the broader context of the Syrian Civil War, the rise of ISIS, and the involvement of various countries in the Middle East conflict.
The IRI is described as part of the 'Axis of Resistance,' a collection of groups supported by Iran against Western interests. The Washington Institute's analysis indicates that the IRI encompasses all Iran-backed militias in Iraq, including those involved in recent conflicts with Israel and Hamas. The article reports on the extensive attacks by such militias on US military installations in Iraq and Syria, as well as the targeting of commercial shipping routes by the Houthis, prompting military responses from the US and the UK.
The piece concludes with concerns raised by US Republican politicians about the Biden administration's handling of the situation, with some calling for strong military retaliation against Iran. There are fears that the escalating conflict could lead to a full-scale war, considering the complex regional dynamics and the presence of influential non-state actors. The article also briefly mentions an unrelated domestic political issue in India. Overall, the situation underscores the volatile nature of Middle Eastern geopolitics and the potential for further escalation.

item.title: Why the subsidy bill for Modi govt’s second term is much higher than the first
item.description:
The article discusses the shift in the Narendra Modi government's approach to welfare and subsidies between its first term (Modi 1.0) and second term (Modi 2.0). During Modi 1.0, the government launched various schemes for universal access to essential services while reducing the subsidy bill, despite increased public funding for these services. This was possible due to lower international oil and fertilizer prices, allowing the government to raise excise duties and limit fuel subsidies to LPG cylinders for low-income households.
In contrast, Modi 2.0 has seen a significant increase in subsidies and transfers, with major subsidies jumping from 1% of GDP in 2018-19 to 3.6% in 2020-21. This increase is attributed to a policy decision to fully fund food and fertilizer subsidies and the economic impact of COVID-19 and the Russia-Ukraine war, which led to increased public distribution system (PDS) offtake and MNREGA spending. Additionally, international fertilizer prices soared, doubling the fertilizer subsidy between 2020-21 and 2022-23.
Looking ahead, the article suggests that any rationalization of subsidies, such as targeted direct benefit transfers (DBT), may be postponed until the next government. The interim budget for 2024-25 is not expected to alter current prices, although there could be an increase in the PM-Kisan scheme's annual transfer ahead of the Lok Sabha polls. The article concludes with various unrelated topics, indicating a shift to other news items.

item.title: Why Nitish Kumar’s exit undermines Opposition’s 2024 caste pitch, sharpens anti-Congress plank
item.description:
The article discusses the political implications of Nitish Kumar's return to the NDA alliance, particularly in the context of the upcoming Lok Sabha elections. It highlights how this move has strategic significance for the BJP, as Nitish was previously an architect of the Opposition's social justice strategy against the BJP. His switch to the NDA is seen as a challenge to the Opposition's efforts to counter the BJP's Hindutva narrative with a social justice approach, a tactic used since the early 1990s.
The article also touches on the broader ideological battle between secular and communal visions in India, questioning the relevance of this dichotomy if leaders like Nitish can easily switch sides. It notes the disarray within the Opposition, with various parties announcing plans to contest elections independently, thereby weakening the united front against the BJP.
Furthermore, the piece reflects on the internal dynamics of the JD(U) and the BJP, suggesting that Nitish's presence in the NDA adds symbolic weight and could influence voter sentiment, especially in light of the Ram temple inauguration. The BJP views Nitish's inclusion as a strategic advantage that could simplify their electoral battle in Bihar and allow them to focus on other regions.
Lastly, the article provides background information on the author, Vikas Pathak, detailing his experience in journalism and academia, and mentions a separate incident involving the Election Commission's transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan due to allegations of misuse of public office. This latter point seems unrelated to the main political narrative of the article.

item.title: Nitish sworn in as CM for 9th time: Seven things to know about the Bihar leader
item.description:
Nitish Kumar, the JD(U) leader, has been sworn in as the Chief Minister of Bihar for the ninth time, marking his fifth alliance change in over a decade. Here are key points from his political journey: - **Early Political Career**: Nitish began his political career during the JP Movement and later formed the Samata Party with George Fernandes in 1994. He first allied with the BJP in 1996 and briefly became Bihar's CM in 2000. - **Resignation as Railway Minister**: He resigned as Railway Minister in 1999 following a train collision in West Bengal, later praised for introducing reforms like internet ticket booking and the tatkal system. - **Departure from NDA**: Nitish left the NDA before the 2014 elections due to Narendra Modi being named the PM candidate, citing the need for a "clean and secular image" for the alliance's leader. - **JD(U)'s Performance and Resignation**: Post the 2014 Lok Sabha elections, Nitish resigned as CM after JD(U)'s seat count dropped from 20 to 2. He returned as CM after his successor, Jitan Ram Manjhi, was expelled from the party. - **Personal Life**: Nitish's son, Nishant Kumar, is an engineer who stays out of politics and is financially wealthier than his father. - **Political Appeal**: Despite his history of changing alliances, Nitish is sought after for his governance record and appeal among certain voter demographics in Bihar. - **Tenure Comparison**: Nitish has had multiple terms as CM but has served for a shorter duration compared to other long-serving CMs like Pawan Kumar Chamling, Naveen Patnaik, and Jyoti Basu.
The article also mentions the Election Commission's transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan, related to a complaint of alleged misuse of public office. The BJP has accused her of using the Mission Shakti scheme to influence voters. However, this part seems unrelated to the main content about Nitish Kumar.

item.title: Why soup was thrown at the Mona Lisa and how it relates to the ongoing farmers’ protests in France
item.description: In Paris, two activists targeted the 'Mona Lisa' at the Louvre Museum to protest agricultural and environmental issues in France. The act, which involved throwing soup at the painting, was part of a broader movement involving groups like Just Stop Oil and Extinction Rebellion, advocating for sustainable food security and climate change awareness. French farmers have been protesting for better compensation, reduced bureaucracy, and protection from imports, partly by blocking roads with tractors. These protests are a response to government policies, including increased taxes on agricultural diesel and EU trade negotiations perceived as unfair. The French government has proposed easing some regulations and ending diesel fuel taxes for farm vehicles. Prime Minister Gabriel Attal acknowledged the farmers' plight and is considering measures against unfair competition from imports. The protests in France are part of a wider pattern of farmer demonstrations across Europe, sharing concerns over environmental taxes and fuel issues.

item.title: Around 28% of Americans have no religious affiliation: What their reasons are, who this group is
item.description:
The Pew Research Center's survey highlights a significant shift in American religious identity, with **28%** of U.S. adults now identifying as religious "nones"—those who describe themselves as atheists, agnostics, or "nothing in particular." This marks a considerable increase from the early 1990s when about **90%** identified as Christians.
The report, titled ‘Religious ‘Nones’ in America: Who They Are and What They Believe’, provides insights into the beliefs and demographics of this group. It reveals that **17%** of nones are atheists, **20%** are agnostics, and the majority, **63%**, believe in "nothing in particular." Notably, **19%** of nones are strict nonbelievers, while about half consider spirituality significant or view themselves as spiritual.
Regarding their stance on religion, **43%** of nones believe religion does more harm than good, while **14%** see it as more beneficial. The main reasons for their disaffiliation include skepticism of religious teachings, aversion to religious organizations, and a perceived lack of necessity for religion in their lives.
In terms of education, race, and gender, atheists and agnostics tend to be more educated than religious Americans, while those who believe in "nothing in particular" are generally less educated. The racial composition of nones mirrors that of religious Americans, and while nones are predominantly under 50, they are almost evenly split between men and women, with a higher proportion of men among atheists and agnostics.
The survey also found that nones are less civically and politically engaged than their religious counterparts, particularly those who identify with "nothing in particular." Scholars suggest that the rise in individualism due to industrialization and globalization may contribute to these trends, along with a growing distrust in organized religion, even as some maintain spiritual beliefs.

item.title: Uttarakhand Uniform Civil Code to be passed in February: How did it come about and what can be expected?
item.description:
The article discusses the upcoming passage of the Uniform Civil Code (UCC) Bill by the Uttarakhand Assembly on February 5. The UCC, a key BJP campaign promise from the 2014 general elections, aims to establish a uniform set of personal laws for all citizens, irrespective of religion, covering marriage, inheritance, divorce, and adoption, as per Article 44 of the Indian Constitution.
A five-member committee led by former Supreme Court Justice Ranjana Prakash Desai is set to submit its report before the assembly session. The UCC has faced opposition from parties like Congress and AIMIM, citing concerns over communal harmony and societal polarization.
Despite delays, the committee has incorporated over 2.5 lakh public suggestions and held 38 public meetings. The UCC intends to ensure gender equality, particularly in inheritance laws, and will address practices like polygamy and iddat, with strong input from Muslim women. It will maintain the current legal marriage age and introduce regulations for live-in relationships.
The enactment of the UCC in Uttarakhand may influence similar legislation in Gujarat and Assam. Goa remains the first state to implement the UCC. Additionally, the article mentions the Election Commission's transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan due to allegations of misuse of public office for electoral gains. The summary omits unrelated content such as advertisements.

item.title: As Maharashtra CM assures quota to Marathas, why OBCs are planning to take to streets and courts
item.description:
The article discusses the ongoing conflict over reservation policies in Maharashtra, India. The Maratha community is awaiting the finalization of rules for Maratha reservation, while the Other Backward Class (OBC) community fears that their 27% reservation share may be reduced. The proposed policy would allow Marathas to claim reservation within the OBC quota without exceeding the 50% total reservation limit set by the Supreme Court.
The issue is contentious because many Marathas in certain regions do not have Kunbi certificates, which grant OBC status, and therefore cannot claim OBC reservation. The state government has called for suggestions and objections to the policy until February 16, and it will take at least another fortnight before the rules are notified.
Chief Minister Eknath Shinde claims to have fulfilled his promise of Maratha reservations, while Deputy Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis has clarified that the process for obtaining Kunbi certificates has been simplified, but not extended to those without existing records.
Senior OBC leaders and activists, including NCP Minister Chhagan Bhujbal, are planning to challenge the government's decision in court. The OBC community is not opposed to separate Maratha reservation but is against sharing their reserved quota.
The article also recounts the history of the reservation policy, noting that the SEBC Act, which granted Marathas a 16% reservation, was struck down by the Supreme Court in 2021. The current total reservation stands at 52%, and the political implications of the OBC unrest are expected to influence the upcoming general elections.
The opposition accuses the government of deceiving both Marathas and OBCs by not fulfilling promises related to Kunbi certificates and OBC quota. The article concludes with the anticipation of legal challenges and the potential impact on the general elections. The unrelated content and advertisements have been omitted from this summary.

item.title: Death by nitrogen: Why this Alabama execution is polarising
item.description:
Kenneth Smith, an Alabama inmate, was executed using nitrogen hypoxia on January 25, marking the first use of this method in the United States. The execution method, which involves breathing pure nitrogen, has been touted as effective and humane by proponents like State Attorney General Steve Marshall. However, it has faced criticism for being cruel and inhumane. The execution process took approximately 22 minutes, during which Smith displayed signs of distress, leading to a public outcry. Despite this, state representatives maintained that the execution proceeded as expected.
Smith's lawyers argued that the method was experimental and could violate the constitutional ban on cruel and unusual punishment, but their attempts to halt the execution were unsuccessful. The U.S. Supreme Court, with dissenting opinions, allowed the execution to proceed. The debate over the death penalty in the U.S. continues, with arguments about its retributive justice and deterrent effects, although research suggests it has no deterrent value. The controversy extends to the methods of execution, with lethal injection facing its own set of challenges. Currently, capital punishment is legal in 27 states, with executions paused in 7 and at the federal level, while still retained by the U.S. military. The article also briefly mentions political developments unrelated to the main topic.

item.title: Inclusion of ‘sage-soyare’ makes Maratha activist Jarange-Patil call off quota protest: What this means, what its impact will be
item.description: The article discusses the withdrawal of Manoj Jarange-Patil's protest following the Maharashtra government's inclusion of the term 'sage-soyare' in a draft notification. This term refers to relatives from the family tree and its inclusion is expected to simplify the process for Marathas to obtain Kunbi (OBC) certificates. Previously, the caste of a child was determined solely through the paternal line, but with this change, affinal relations and maternal lineage will also be considered for issuing Kunbi certificates. This is particularly significant for Maratha families in Marathwada, where obtaining historical Kunbi records has been challenging. The government's move is seen as a response to difficulties faced by these families and is subject to public suggestions and objections until February 16. A legal battle over the interpretation of the draft is anticipated. Additionally, the article mentions the transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan by the Election Commission of India due to allegations of misuse of public office.

item.title: Explained: The ICJ ruling on the genocide case against Israel for its actions in Gaza
item.description: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) has ruled that Israel must take all necessary measures to prevent genocide in Gaza, although it did not order a ceasefire. The court confirmed its jurisdiction over the case brought by South Africa, which accuses Israel of committing genocide. The ICJ has ordered six provisional measures and acknowledged a prima facie dispute between the parties regarding the Genocide Convention. The court highlighted Israel's military operations in Gaza, causing significant civilian casualties and displacement, and expressed deep concern over the humanitarian crisis. Despite calls for a ceasefire, legal experts anticipated that the court would not mandate such an action, as it could compromise Israel's self-defense. The ICJ's rulings are binding but not enforceable; however, they influence international bodies. The final decision on whether Israel is committing genocide may take years. Separately, the Election Commission of India has transferred Sujata R Karthikeyan due to allegations of election influence.

item.title: Why European Union is shifting from being the global tech regulator to AI innovation advocate
item.description: The article discusses the European Commission's and India's efforts to foster AI innovation. The EU has set rules for startups to access supercomputers for AI development, following the EU AI Act aimed at trustworthy AI. India plans a similar approach, considering a public-private partnership to build high-capacity data centers for startups. The Indian government is also outlining an AI Mission with a significant budget to develop 'sovereign AI' and offer compute-as-a-service. The goal is to build 10,000 to 30,000 GPUs under the PPP model and 1,000-2,000 GPUs through C-DAC. Various incentives are being explored to encourage private computing centers, aiming to create a digital public infrastructure for startups to use at lower costs. The article contrasts this with the US, where companies like OpenAI and Google lead AI innovation without needing government-offered hardware services. The EU's AI Act, which includes safeguards and restrictions on AI use, has faced criticism, but it sets clear rules for law enforcement and consumer rights, with strong penalties for violations. Real-time biometric surveillance by governments is restricted to serious threats like terrorist attacks. The article also mentions a political issue in India, where an official was transferred due to alleged misuse of public office during elections.

item.title: From 2021 civil suit to 2024 ASI survey report: A timeline of recent issues in Gyanvapi dispute
item.description:
The article discusses the ongoing legal dispute over the Gyanvapi mosque, which intensified in 2022 when five Hindu women sought permission to worship at the site, claiming it was built over a Hindu temple. Key developments include: - **August**: Filing of a civil suit by the women and the mosque committee's challenge based on the 1991 Places of Worship Act. - **May 16**: Completion of a videographic survey revealing a contested structure within the mosque. - **May 20**: The Supreme Court's transfer of the case to a district judge. - **September to November**: Various legal challenges and orders, including the dismissal of pleas by the mosque committee and the rejection of requests for a scientific survey of the contested structure. - **May to August**: Orders for a scientific survey and an ASI excavation, with subsequent legal challenges and an interim stay by the Supreme Court. - **December 11 to January 25**: The ASI survey's completion and the court's review of the ASI report.
The article also mentions an unrelated issue regarding the Election Commission of India's transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan due to alleged misuse of public office.

item.title: The temple that Aurangzeb razed: Evidence from history on Gyanvapi and Kashi Vishwanath
item.description: The Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) has found evidence suggesting that a large Hindu temple existed before the Gyanvapi mosque at Varanasi. This conclusion is based on scientific studies and corroborated by historical texts. The temple is believed to have been destroyed by orders from Emperor Aurangzeb, who aimed to promote Islam and suppress other religions. Aurangzeb's policies marked a shift from Akbar's more inclusive approach, imposing higher taxes on Hindu traders and abolishing them for Muslims. The destruction of temples, including the Vishwanath temple in Kashi and the Keshavdev temple in Mathura, was part of a broader strategy to eliminate centers of non-Islamic teaching and ideas considered subversive by orthodox elements. Some historians suggest that the destruction was also a punitive measure against those who supported Aurangzeb's rival, Shivaji. The current Kashi Vishwanath temple was constructed adjacent to the mosque site in the 18th century by Queen Ahilyabai Holkar. The mosque's patron is unknown, and it does not appear in Mughal records. The article also discusses the incorporation of parts of the destroyed temple into the mosque's structure, possibly as a statement of Mughal authority.

item.title: ASI opinion on Gyanvapi mosque: How the court is likely to view the report
item.description:
The Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) submitted a report to the Varanasi district court, which was later shared with both Hindu and Muslim litigants, confirming that the Gyanvapi mosque was built over a pre-existing temple. The report's significance lies in its potential as expert evidence in the ongoing litigation over the Kashi Vishwanath temple-Gyanvapi mosque complex. The courts will need to decide if the ASI report is conclusive and what the existence of a Hindu temple means for the religious character of the mosque as of August 15, 1947.
The ASI's findings, like those in the Babri Masjid-Ramjanmabhoomi case, can be interpreted differently by the parties involved. The Supreme Court, in its 2019 decision, stated that title cannot be based solely on archaeological findings and must adhere to legal principles and evidentiary standards.
The maintainability of such a suit is contingent on the Places of Worship Act, 1991, which preserves the religious character of places of worship as of Independence Day 1947, with the exception of the disputed structure in Ayodhya. The Gyanvapi district court has upheld the maintainability, and the Supreme Court has made oral observations that the act of finding the religious nature of a place is not barred by the Act.
A constitutional challenge to the 1991 Act remains pending, and its fate could significantly affect the relevance of the ASI report. The Supreme Court has previously indicated that the 1991 law is a basic feature of the Constitution, emphasizing the State's obligation to uphold secularism and equality of all religions. The Act is seen as a legislative measure to protect secular values and prevent retrogression.
Lastly, the article mentions the transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan by the Election Commission of India due to allegations of misuse of public office, which is unrelated to the main content of the article.

item.title: Judge vs judge: How a spat between two Calcutta HC judges reached the Supreme Court
item.description:
The Supreme Court of India intervened in a case of alleged irregularities in MBBS admissions in West Bengal, staying all proceedings at the Calcutta High Court after contradictory orders were issued by different benches. A special sitting was held due to serious allegations made by Justice Abhijit Gangopadhyay against Justice Soumen Sen, accusing him of misconduct and acting under political influence. The matter is set to be taken up by the Supreme Court on the following Monday.
Justice Gangopadhyay had initially ordered a CBI inquiry into the case, citing a 'large picture of corruption' and the state's failure to arrest an individual after an assault on ED officials. Despite not being requested by the petitioner, he deemed a thorough investigation necessary. However, a Division Bench stayed this order, emphasizing the state's right to a fair investigation and questioning the need to involve the CBI without a specific plea.
The situation escalated when Justice Gangopadhyay defied the Division Bench's stay order, proceeding with the handover of documents to the CBI. The Division Bench responded by declaring his actions void and extending the stay on the CBI inquiry.
In a dramatic turn, Justice Gangopadhyay accused Justice Sen of misconduct, alleging that he was acting for a political party and had influenced another judge to dismiss cases involving a political figure. He called for the Supreme Court to reexamine the orders involving the state and questioned Justice Sen's continued presence at the Calcutta High Court despite a recommended transfer.
The article also mentions the Election Commission of India's transfer of an official due to allegations of misuse of public office and political involvement in elections. The BJP has accused the official of using a government scheme to influence voters on behalf of the BJD. This part of the article seems unrelated to the main legal controversy but highlights ongoing political disputes in the region.

item.title: What are incestuous ‘sapinda’ marriages, and why has Delhi High Court reaffirmed the ban on them?
item.description:
The Delhi High Court upheld the constitutionality of Section 5(v) of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, which prohibits sapinda marriages among Hindus unless permitted by custom. Sapinda relationships are defined as being within a certain degree of lineage, with the prohibition extending up to three generations on the mother's side and five on the father's side. The court dismissed a petition challenging this section, stating that unregulated partner choice in marriage could legitimize incestuous relationships. The petitioner's marriage had been declared void due to being a sapinda marriage without established custom. The court found no merit in her argument that the prohibition violates the right to equality, as she failed to provide stringent proof of an established custom allowing sapinda marriages. The court also noted that partner choice can be regulated and that the prohibition does not violate the right to equality.
The article also compares the legal stance on incestuous relationships in several European countries and the United States, noting that some have less stringent laws compared to India. For instance, France abolished the crime of incest for consenting adults, Belgium and Portugal do not criminalize incest, and in the US, incestuous marriages are banned but relationships are allowed in some states. The article concludes with an unrelated note about the Election Commission of India ordering the transfer of Sujata R Karthikeyan due to alleged misuse of public office.

item.title: ASI report says temple existed at the site of Gyanvapi mosque: 5 key takeaways
item.description:
The Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) has concluded in its report that a Hindu temple existed before the Gyanvapi mosque was constructed. The key findings from the ASI report include:
- An inscription on a loose stone indicates the mosque was built during Emperor Aurangzeb's reign, with repairs noted in 1792-93. Recent surveys show parts of the inscription have been scratched out. - Historical records suggest Aurangzeb ordered the demolition of non-Islamic religious structures, including the Vishwanath temple at Kashi. - The survey documented 34 inscriptions from reused stones of the original Hindu temples, in various scripts, indicating the prior structures were dismantled and repurposed. - Names of Hindu deities and terms of significance were found in the inscriptions, suggesting the religious importance of the pre-existing structure. - Pillars and pilasters examined during the survey were identified as parts of the original temple, with some figures mutilated for reuse in the mosque. - The original temple had a central chamber and additional chambers on all sides, which now form part of the mosque's main hall. Decorative elements from the temple were altered or destroyed to fit the mosque's design. - The main entrance to the central chamber, adorned with animal and bird carvings, is now blocked, and sculptural remains were found in cellars made from reused temple pillars.
The report provides evidence of the mosque's construction over a pre-existing Hindu temple, with architectural and inscriptional remnants supporting this conclusion. The unrelated content regarding the Election Commission of India's actions has been omitted from this summary.

item.title: ASI hands over Gyanvapi mosque report, says ‘prior Hindu temple existed’: Tracing the RSS view on the dispute
item.description: The article discusses the ongoing legal dispute over the Gyanvapi mosque complex. The Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) reported finding evidence of a Hindu temple predating the mosque at the site. This is significant in the context of claims that the mosque was built over the destroyed Kashi Vishwanath temple. The report has historical and political implications, reflecting the longstanding tensions and religious claims over the site. The RSS, a Hindu nationalist organization, has been involved in similar disputes since 1959, focusing on the "return" of Hindu temples. The article traces the evolution of this dispute, highlighting key moments and shifts in focus, particularly the RSS's stance on Ayodhya, Mathura, and Kashi. It also touches on internal Hindu societal issues and the broader political landscape, including the BJP's position and the RSS's current views on the need for further temple-mosque disputes. The article concludes with an updated explainer on the history of the dispute and the author's credentials as an investigative journalist. President Joe Biden's comments on immigration and xenophobia are unrelated to the main topic and are not included in the summary.

item.title: FPI disclosure norms deadline extended: Why is SEBI seeking investor data?
item.description: The Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) has extended the deadline by seven months for Foreign Portfolio Investors (FPIs) to comply with additional disclosure requirements. These disclosures are aimed at entities holding significant portions of their equity Assets Under Management (AUM) in a single corporate group or with substantial holdings in the Indian equity market. The move is to prevent misuse of the FPI route for round-tripping by promoters and to ensure transparency in substantial acquisitions and public shareholding. FPIs not meeting the initial deadline will have additional time to provide details or reduce their holdings. Certain categories of FPIs, like sovereign wealth funds and regulated public funds with diversified holdings, are exempt from these enhanced disclosures. The measures follow concerns over potential market disruptions and are part of broader regulatory efforts to monitor high-risk financial activities and foreign investments, especially in the wake of policy changes during the Covid-19 pandemic to prevent opportunistic takeovers of Indian companies. Additionally, there's a mention of a political figure's transfer due to alleged misuse of public office, unrelated to the main financial regulations topic.

item.title: Why was January 26 chosen to be India’s Republic Day?
item.description: The article discusses the significance of January 26 in India's history, marking the day the Constitution came into effect and the country's transformation into a republic. It traces back to January 26, 1930, when the "Poorna Swaraj" declaration was made, demanding complete independence from British rule. The date was chosen for Republic Day to honor this declaration and the subsequent struggle for freedom. The 1920s saw significant developments, including the rise of influential leaders and the Simon Commission's appointment, which led to widespread protests. The Nehru Report's call for dominion status was met with mixed reactions within the Indian National Congress, with some leaders demanding complete severance from the British Empire. The turning point came when the British reneged on the promise of dominion status, leading to a united front for a fully independent republic. The article concludes by explaining why January 26 was chosen for the Constitution's enactment, reflecting the spirit of the "Poorna Swaraj" resolution and India's journey to self-rule. The piece also mentions President Joe Biden's views on immigration and xenophobia, highlighting his support for immigrants' contributions to the US. This summary omits unrelated content and focuses on the key historical and contemporary points presented in the article.

item.title: From Ram to Akbar to Gandhi: Artwork on the Constitution, who painted them
item.description:
The Indian Constitution is renowned for being the world's longest written constitution, distinguished not only by its comprehensive text but also by its artistic illustrations. Each of the 22 parts features hand-painted images reflecting various historical periods of India, from the ancient Indus Valley civilization to the modern freedom struggle, including depictions from epics like the Ramayana and Mahabharata.
The illustrations were crafted under the direction of Nandalal Bose at Santiniketan, while the Constitution itself was handwritten by Prem Behari Narain Raizada. The artwork captures India's rich geographical diversity and historical narrative, though it does not directly correlate with the constitutional text.
Nandalal Bose, a prominent figure in the nationalist movement and an associate of Mahatma Gandhi, led a team of artists, including his students and relatives, in this monumental task. The artists received modest compensation for their work, and the calligrapher Raizada requested only to have his name inscribed on each page as his remuneration.
The Constitution's images serve as a visual journey through India's history, religion, and culture, featuring significant figures like Mahavir, Buddha, Emperor Ashoka, and Rani Lakshmibai, among others. The artwork also pays tribute to India's freedom struggle, with scenes depicting leaders like Gandhi and Subhas Chandra Bose.
Art historian R Siva Kumar and DAG CEO Ashish Anand emphasize that the illustrations, while not directly linked to the Constitution's content, offer a vision of India's history and are expected to endure for centuries, reflecting the spirit of the nation.

item.title: Emmanuel Macron is Republic Day chief guest: The bright arc of India-France ties
item.description:
The article discusses the enduring partnership between India and France, highlighting the 25th anniversary of their strategic partnership and the visit of French President Emmanuel Macron as the Chief Guest for India's Republic Day celebrations in 2024. It reflects on the historical ties, with former French President Jacques Chirac's visits and support for India during critical moments, such as India's nuclear tests in 1998.
The strategic partnership is underscored by cooperation in defense, space, and civil nuclear matters, with significant advancements like the procurement of Rafale jets and collaboration between ISRO and CNES. Economic ties are also strong, with substantial French investment in India and bilateral trade. The digital collaboration includes the launch of UPI in France and the development of supercomputers.
Education and community engagement are other pillars, with initiatives to increase the number of Indian students in France and recognition of mutual degrees. Tourism between the two nations is robust, and France supports India's international aspirations, including a permanent seat on the UN Security Council.
The article concludes by noting the opportunity for Modi and Macron to discuss mutual interests such as global conflicts and cooperation in defense and security during Macron's visit. The historical context of Chirac's admiration for India and Macron's previous visits set the stage for further strengthening of the bilateral relationship. The unrelated content and advertisements in the article have been omitted from this summary.

item.title: Gyanvapi case | The test ahead: Law on places of worship, and the challenge it faces
item.description:
The article discusses the ongoing legal proceedings regarding the title suit of the Kashi Vishwanath-Gyanvapi mosque site. The key points are:
- The Places of Worship (Special Provisions) Act, 1991, is central to the case, as it prohibits changing the religious character of places of worship as it was on August 15, 1947, except for Ayodhya. - The Supreme Court, while not yet ruling conclusively, has observed that determining the religious nature of a place is not barred by the 1991 Act, provided the ascertainment is limited to the state of affairs as of 1947. - A constitutional challenge to the 1991 Act is pending, with the possibility of being referred to a larger bench, but the Centre has not responded yet. - An Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) report submitted to the Varanasi court suggests the existence of a Hindu temple before the mosque, but its reliability and implications for the mosque's religious character in 1947 are yet to be determined. - The article references a similar ASI report from 2003 used in the Babri Masjid-Ramjanmabhoomi case, which the Supreme Court found inconclusive in determining whether a temple was demolished to build the mosque.
The article also mentions unrelated content, such as other news headlines and a political issue involving the Election Commission of India, which are not directly related to the main topic.

item.title: Why a Chemistry professor suggested adding salt to tea for the perfect cup
item.description:
A new book called "Steeped: The Chemistry of Tea" by Michelle Francl has caused a debate between Americans and the British regarding the best way to prepare tea. Francl suggests adding a pinch of salt to tea to reduce its bitterness, which sparked disagreement. The US Embassy in the UK clarified that adding salt to tea is not official US policy. The UK's Cabinet Office responded with humor, stating that tea can only be made using a kettle.
Tea is beloved in Britain since it arrived from China during the colonial era, while the US is primarily a nation of coffee drinkers. Both tea and coffee have a slight bitterness due to caffeine and tannin compounds. The salt tip seems to work because taste receptors on the tongue prevent the brain from confusing bitter and sweet flavors. Mixing salt with bitter compounds can mask the bitterness. However, the exact mechanism behind this is not well-known.
Francl's book explores over 100 chemical compounds in tea and provides brewing advice. She recommends using short and stout tea cups to retain heat, heating the cup separately for more aromatic compounds, and preferring loose tea over teabags for better circulation of tea leaves. Microwaves are discouraged for tea preparation. When using tea bags, large ones should be used and steeped quickly with dunking and squeezing to reduce sour-tasting tannins.
To avoid curdling, warmed milk should be added after pouring the tea. Francl also suggests adding a small amount of lemon juice to remove floating scum formed from chemical elements in the tea and water. The book connects the chemistry of tea with fundamental scientific discoveries, such as Emil Fischer's Nobel Prize-winning work on caffeine and George de Hevesy's isotopic tracing research.
In unrelated news, an IAS officer in Chandigarh ordered the sealing of establishments and suspension of liquor licenses for ten major vendors. As a result, the Home department transferred him out of the Excise department.

item.title: January 26, 1950: How India observed its first Republic Day
item.description: On January 26, 1950, India became a sovereign and democratic republic, marking the end of British rule in the country. After two years of independence, the newly drafted Constitution of India came into effect, replacing the British-era Government of India Act of 1935. Dr Rajendra Prasad became the President of India, and the Constituent Assembly became the Parliament until the first general elections took place in 1951-52. To showcase state authority and prestige, India continued the tradition of military parades started during the British Raj. The Republic Day celebrations included a grand military parade in New Delhi, with participation from the armed forces and the Delhi Police. The parade featured a 31-gun salute, celebratory gunfire, and aerial displays by Indian Air Force planes. The President's horse-drawn carriage was flanked by the President's Bodyguard, and after the event, the President returned to Government House. Despite the celebrations, leaders recognized the challenges ahead, as inequality persisted in social and economic life. In a speech, Dr B R Ambedkar emphasized the need to address this contradiction for the success of political democracy.

item.title: US signals cooperation with China on AI safety: what could happen, and what could it mean?
item.description:
The article discusses a shift in the United States' stance on AI collaboration with China. Despite previous restrictions on tech transfers to China, the U.S. has agreed to work with Beijing to manage AI deployment risks. This change follows two key events: the signing of the Bletchley Declaration on AI standards and a meeting between Presidents Biden and Xi Jinping. Concerns about AI's potential for cyber attacks and misinformation are driving this cooperation, especially as many countries face elections.
The article also notes that the U.S. and China are on par in AI development, with China possibly taking the lead in implementation. It highlights China's advancements in AI models and facial recognition technology. The U.S. intends to maintain AI development oversight without slowing progress, recognizing the intertwined nature of U.S. and Chinese AI research ecosystems.
The potential U.S.-China AI collaboration could influence other regions, including India, which is leveraging technology for governance solutions like Aadhaar and UPI. India's approach to AI regulation is seen as a mix of European citizen-focused and American innovator-focused models. The emerging U.S.-China consensus on tech development and regulation could provide a new template for global AI governance. The article concludes with a brief mention of political developments in India unrelated to the main topic.

item.title: What are Odisha’s famous black tigers, and why is the state planning a safari around them?
item.description:
Odisha's Chief Minister, Naveen Patnaik, has announced the development of a melanistic tiger safari near the Similipal Tiger Reserve (STR), which will be the first of its kind in the world. This new safari aims to showcase the rare and majestic melanistic tiger species found exclusively in Odisha. The plan has received approval from the technical committee of the National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) and is expected to be ready for visitors by October this year.
The STR, located in Odisha's Mayurbhanj district, is Asia's second-largest biosphere and the only habitat for melanistic royal Bengal tigers in India. These tigers have black and yellow interspersed stripes due to a unique lineage with higher-than-normal levels of melanin. However, they are more accurately described as being pseudo-melanistic since they are not entirely black.
Research conducted by the National Centre for Biological Sciences (NBCS) suggests that a single mutation in the Transmembrane Aminopeptidase Q (Taqpep) gene results in the broadened or spread stripes seen in the Similipal black tigers. Genetic analyses indicate that these tigers may have originated from a small founding population and are inbred due to their isolation from other tiger populations.
